review_body: Great location the metro station is about 3 minutes walking, and the zone is a very nice one, the japanese garden outside is very nice, the food very good, the rooms very clean but the most special is the service of the personal all are very kind and very helpfull, they makes you feel special

Beautiful gardens, clean and tidy, friendly staff, incredible views. I stayed here for 6 nights and enjoyed every minute of it. The 40th floor bar has a great night time view, the restaurant next door allows you to see all the way to Fuji San on a clear day.The garden is relaxing and quiet, in such a bustling place. I will stay again

St. Neots, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed at the garden tower during my family vacation in December. Nice room though bathroom was very small for a king room. Big hotel ( 1400 rooms ) with beautiful landscape garden. Lots of dining options with more than 20 restaurants to choose from. Great concierge desk if you need help to plan sightseeing and shopping trips. Special mention for chief concierge , Ms Eriko Kawakami who made meticulous arrangement for our trip to Otemba premium outlet mall. That was the highlight for my wife. I would definitely stay at this hotel on my next trip.

The New Otani is my "new" favourtite old-school Japanese business hotel in Tokyo after the renovation of the Okura.The rooms are not modern, but this is offset by the excellent service, the large garden, location, and value for money.I stayed in the Garden Wing, and the large room had seen a minor renovation. There is decent WiFi, cable TV with CNN/BBC. Beds and bathroom are comfortable and modern.There is a large selection of restaurants and shops in the hotel (even a postoffice). I ate at the Garden Lounge, which is great for views of the garden. There is a Lawson's in the office building, which is open until 11pm in the evening.Lastly, the hotel is ~3 mins to the entrance to the subway and another 5 min to the trains.

Ordered a single room at the Main Tower with omakase plan and got switched to a 3-bed room at the Garden Tower without extra fee. This hotel is HUGE. It comes with its own Japanese garden (with waterfall), shopping mall, spa, supermarket, convenience store, various restaurants, etc. The decoration was old-fashioned, and most of the staying guests were elegant senior couples, so the atmosphere was quite relaxed and cozy. Most of the staff were efficient and polite. The French restaurant was authentic and delicious. The live performance at the night lounge was very comforting and inspiring. The room was clean and comfortable, especially when the air conditioner control did respond to my adjustment.Although there didn't seem many sightseeing spots in the neighborhood, I hardly need to go outside since I can get almost everything I need here. The only thing I wanna complain is that I wasn't able to enjoy the breakfast since I got a plane to catch and had to leave at 6 AM. Other than that everything was satisfying.

We stayed in the hotel back in October. It was AWESOME. The staff was super friendly the bars in the hotel were upscale as the whole property is on the higher end. There is a huge on site garden, but you are a short walk from the Imperial palace and the National Diet. Perfect location for tourists close to main attractions shopping eating and metro lines. I cannot wait to go to Japan again. My girlfriend was there for business and I tagged along for pleasure and to make the most of her time off there.

Mr. Otani’s decision to keep the Samuarai Japanese garden in the grounds of the hotel means that we can all enjoy an excellent garden a gem away from the hustle and bustle of busy Tokyo! The waterfall is a sight to behold. The breakfast restaurant between the two hotel towers has a superb garden view, do ask for a seat by the window if you are visiting. Staff extremely friendly, courteous and helpful while serving delicious food both Japanese and western. Well done! Only downside was one swim will cost you £35 in a relatively small pool.

We stayed at both the Main and the Garden Tower during this trip. I thought the rooms were large for Tokyo, nicely appointed, very clean, and very comfortable. I appreciated having a place to sit besides on the bed. The Main is fancier—the Garden Tower closer to the subway. The Main was a little more updated.And the staff are superlative. We left our big bags, so that we could travel light to Kyoto. When we returned to Tokyo, the staff had already put our bags in our room. Everyone was so helpful, professional, and courteous.The breakfasts, which we had at the beginning of the trip, were amazingly good, with a wide choice of Western and Japanese items that you can mix and match. The restaurants are very expensive, but there are many restaurants within a short walk, including some nice ones in the mall right across the street from the exit at the Garden Courtyard that is nearest the subway. (Right by that large flower sculpture.) It is nice to have a drink on the 40th floor—of course, it is an expensive pleasure, so you might want to go during happy hour.And I really love the Japanese garden, which we walked through almost every day. So beautiful.The location was also great—right near a subway and well located between attractions to the East and west. I also appreciated being able to take the airport limousine right to the door.All in all, great hotel.

My husband pulled out all the stops to surprise me and give me the best for our anniversary! This hotel was one of his amazing surprises and expressions of love to me. It is rather lavish in size and class, and the staff...superb. We never got to go through the whole building as it was too large and our schedule of events didn’t permit. Well, now I have another reason to indulge again at the New Otani.

We stayed in this hotel in total for 8 nights spread over three trips as part of the RWC. Each time we were in a different room and the views from each were amazing, we had Mount Fuji one time, then the next the beautiful gardens and then the rose garden.We did encounter an issue with the air con in 1 room, which they tried to sort out but couldn't so within half an hour we were moved to another room.The hotel is massive and was easy to get lost, the meals and drinks were very expensive, it was only a short walk to the nearby bars and restaurants to get much cheaper options.Breakfast was included in our deal and you can have this at the different restaurants, we opted for the buffet on 40th floor as it seemed less busy and the views were amazing. There was plenty of choice both hot and cold and Eastern and Western cuisine, lots for vegetarians too.The rooms were all very large with all the amenities you could want and more, lots of hanging space and drawer too. The showers were very powerful and always lots of hot water.There are plenty of places in the area to walk too, the Imperial Palace, many temples, lots of shops, bars etc. There were always taxis out side and fair to airports was fixed and about 7000 yen to Haneda.The hotel was packed during our staying as full of rugby fans and the Welsh team, also lots of dignitaries due to the enthronment of the new emperor.

Princess Cruises set up our stay at the New Otani as part of a "Land/Sea" cruise. For us it was perfect for our needs, with excellent views, and convenient dining.The room was clean and ready as we arrived and was kept clean and ready by the hotel staff during our stay. The bathroom was good size and conveniently laid out. The internet was always ready to go and fast as well as the TV. Breakfasts were included as part of our Land/Cruise tour and we ate at each of the 2 venues. I think both dining rooms shared the same buffet breakfast menu. The 18th floor (could have been a higher level) dining room's views looked over a downtown area on one side and the Palace on the other. Good (but not "to die for") meals at both restaurants were included during our stay, with items most Westerners prefer. I happen to really enjoy eating local food and I was not disappointed.There are several other restaurants as well as shops in the lower levels. We only dined at one (The Rib Room Steakhouse - which I will cover in another review) but while it was very good it was also very pricey. There are a number of other restaurants located somewhat conveniently outside of the Otani (The Aux Bacchanales, our favorite and a great value - which I will also cover in another review) as an option.Bottom line, the room was clean and comfortable, their breakfast buffets very good AND with attractive views ... so the New Otani really fit out needs.But make sure to take a walk through their gardens before you leave. If you dine in the Otani's Garden Dining Room you will have a great view of it. Nice to look at from a distance. But more enjoyable to experience in person and up close.

It is part of the vast New Otani, that is composed of the main Building, where all conference rooms are located, and the Garden Tower, with its 40 floors of rooms and a beautiful garden.Rooms are spacious and confortabile, nothing's remarkable but of high quality. I have tried 2 out of the many restaurants insieme the hotel and I wouldn't suggest any..

This hotel is enormous and is spread across three towers so it can be difficult to find your way around. In addition to around 20 restaurants serving virtually every cuisine you could want there are a substantial number of luxury shops across two of the lower levels. With a bit of luck you should also be able to locate a convenience store at the other end of the hotel and coffee shop (beneath the third tower which provides office space). We stayed 7 nights and I'm still not convinced that we found our way to every restaurant, shop or lounge area in the hotel and grounds. Surrounding part of the hotel is a 400 year old Japanese garden, complete with waterefall, which is well worth exploring.In terms of location it's only a short walk to the subway (but only if you find the right entrance which is next to the luxury car showroom) and a couple of old streets which provide numerous restaurants, pubs, bars and stores. The Imperial Palace and station are also within walking distance if you're fairly fit.Our bedroom was high up in the Garden Tower and like most in Japan it was on the small side with insufficient storage space for a long stay (we had to use one of our suitcases as a 'drawer') but it did have good views of the city and had everything we needed including a large comfortable bed and air conditioning. The bathroom was good with quality toiletries and everywhere was spotlessly clean. We had breakfast in both the Garden Terrace Restaurant which looks out over the garden waterfall and in the panoramic restaurant on the 40th floor. The latter offers stunning views but the choice of breakfast items was a bit limited. Breakfast in the Garden Terrace room was excellent with a massive choice of good quality items. We only had dinner once in the hotel, due to typhoon Higibis which forced us to stay in for 24 hours, and we found it expensive - a beer started at £15 and a single course was around £25. We ended up paying about £150 per person for a 3 course meal & a shared bottle of wine. Throughout the small army of staff were very helpful and most spoke English.Overall we very much enjoyed our stay and I would happily resturn although I might consider booking a suite if it was for a long period.

We had an amazing stay at a lovely room, the stafe were great and very helpful with everything, specifically the nice concierge ladies who helped us with everything we needed. We had the good luck to be on "look down" during the typhoon in this wonderfully pampering hotel

I have stayed at worse and I have stayed at better. The hotel officers everything you would want from a 'big city' hotel, with very friendly and helpful staff (who can converse in English). The down side is it is a little bit dated but still very adequate.I would ask for a room as high as possible as the views are impressive and we only discovered the bar and alternative breakfast venue on the 40th floor at the end of our stay - which I would recommend. The gardens are also pretty cool for a 'wonder around'.

Finding a decent hotel in Tokyo that won't cost an arm and a leg is akin to finding a Dodo bird in Brooklyn.Most hotels in Tokyo offer small rooms and outrageous prices especially if you travel as a family.After weeks of searching for a decent four or five star property I remembered that my old boss used to stay at Hotel New Otani back in the early nineties. We checked the website, found a room that could accommodate 4 people at about $500 a day and off we went.First of all let ne say that the name of the hotel is a bit of a misnomer. The last time anyone could call this hotel new was probably about 40 years ago. The carpets, the furniture, the electronics were all vintage 1985.This hotel is huge. Check this out, it has 35 restaurants and bars. That's right thirty five!It also has its own park, an indoor and outdoor pools with some weird rules etc. An airport shuttle takes you to the hotel. A taxi from Narita costs $250 A decent dinner for 4 will cost at least $140Four restaurants serving breakfast. We checked out 3 of them. Decent selection which kind of gets old after a few days. Please note that only one restaurant has an omelet station.Service was hit and miss. Everyone tried to be very helpful but their approach was strange to say the least. Four people sit at the table, waiter brings 3 glasses of water...One day house keeping made the beds and that was all they did. No joke. Trash was not taken out, fresh towels were not provided. After we complained, the manager apologized profusely but again...Since this is an old hotel, it offers bigger rooms than the modern Tokyo hotels. Our suite consisted of a living room with a sofa and a bedroom in which they put 3 beds.Small bathroom with a high tech Japanese toilet, no separate shower. An odd sink outside the bathroom.Location was not bad. Five minute walk to the subway station. The problem with Tokyo is that it is insanely spread out so it is impossible to walk anywhere, you have to rely on public transport.Overall, I would recommend this hotel, especially if you travel with a family. It is not a five star despite their rating on trip advisor and in the United States it probably would not even be a 4 star property, but then again we were in Tokyo and pickings were slim unless you wanted to spend close to 1K per night.

Old, tired and horrible. Your heart sinks when you arrive. Everything from decor, service, room interiors and food is 30 years out of date. Unfortunately not in any good way. Nasty carpets, corridors that remind of a penal institution. The hotel feels like it’s been in terminal decline since about 1987.It is an excellent example of why people like Airbnb. To make it worse, it’s expensive. You feel cheated staying here. You don’t see guests or staff smiling in this institution. The general manager prowls the reception trying to work out how to ring a few more yen from each guest. Without doubt the worst hotel of our stay in Japan and Tokyo. There are some great hotels in Ginza district which is close by. Be nice to yourself and stay away.

Very disappointed. The cost to stay in the hotel I would expect much better service. I booked 2 rooms for 2 couples, at check in we are told we can only have twin beds in both rooms for the duration of our stay. Or the option of a smoking double room. Staff and manager not sympathetic or helpful. Eventually managed to get double room for second and third night. No compensation like a free breakfast. Just very disappointed and would not recommend this hotel. Smaller hotels seem to have much friendlier staff and better service.

The hotel is well situated to some restaurants as well as the Metro Station.The only downside is there was a smell of stale cigarette smoke in the passage way to my room on 31st floor. I was not asked whether I wanted a smoke free room. Japan does not seem to have the same smoking laws as my country which bans smoking in public areas.The upside was the hotel gardens and the breakfast was very good. Beware of the closing time of 10am as they pretty much ask you to leave at 10:01.

Very small roomVery small window Old bathroomVery oldfashion fourniture Sept 15 ...no longer pool until next year !impossible to take avantage of the warm temperatureVery very expensive The unique advantage is the location

Hostess talked so softly you could not hear her. I ordered smoked salmon, a club sandwich, and a glass of wine. After 10 minutes I flagged down a server and asked what happened. She asked another server and eventually I could see three servers scratching their heads and then one of them rushing to the bar. Still waiting. I asked what happened and the server just said sorry. Still no wine and I am sure my food was not ordered either. As I walked out I saw the hostess who took my order and told her nothing I ordered from her came and no one seemed to even have the order. She said something in a whisper that was unintelligible. Left in discussed but had a wonderful meal and wine in Akasaka Mitsuke Yokocho street.

Reserved this hotel, five months in advance, for our final day in JapanFirst surprise was that our daughters’ room wasn’t adjoined to oursSecond surprise was that we didn’t have free access to the pools of this hotel. Instead we had the choice between paying $20 per person (per day) to gain access to the outside pool, or $50 for the indoor spa pool.This outdated and oversized hotel is in dire need of a face lift; the rooms feel like from another era.The bath shower head in our bathroom, (room: 5432) provided hot water when turned to ‘cold’ and burning hot water when turned to ‘hot’.All foreign channels on the aging TV were systematically translated in japanese.

Check-in was flawless, and our first interaction with the exemplary level of service from the staff. The room was large, particularly for Tokyo, and well equipped. Booking two months in advance for a room in early July the price was remarkably reasonable.

This hotel was chosen for us as part of our son’s wish trip. We had a triple room, 3 twin beds. Ned’s were hard as a rock but we slept well despite it. Staff was very friendly, hotel clean and neat. Most staff spoke English for the tourists. Huge place, with shopping and restaurants inside. We got delayed and had no trouble getting it stay and extra night.Pleasant experience

Great location, metro train station 2 minutes walk.Metro takes you all over the city in next to no time.Hotel was superb, great room with city views, breakfast buffet was to pick from 2 main restaurants and were delicious, staff were very helpful and polite. Overall a great experience

We were there for 4 days. Hotel and services were top rated. It is an extremely large hotel in different parts. Staff was very polite and lots around to aid if needed. Food was very good and restaurant on top floor gave a great view of the city. Very enjoyable stay.

i stayed at the New Otani as my work colleague recommended it. I arrived late but check in was easy. The front desk was very helpful and let me borrow an iphone charger since i left my on the plane. Room was spacious and well decorated. Breakfast room service was delivered promptly. Overall, a great property (albeit quite large) and reasonably priced for Tokyo.

Third time here tells its quality in my mind. Good service (only exception is this time bell boy in limo bus service station), good restaurant (sushi restaurant is excellent & lobby cafe is good), good enough hotel room (big enough & water pressure for shower is high, but a bit mal-function on the washlet) and marvelous hundreds years garden are the things brought me back. Location is good enough with easy accessibility to go everywhere in town. Wanna try its Teppanyaki next time (beautiful small restaurant inside its stunning city center garden) & buy a small painting from its small gallery (too rush in & out this time for it).因為他的品質夠好才會來住第三次，服務夠好（唯一例外是這次機場巴士上車處的服務生）、好棒的餐廳（握壽司餐廳一流、大廳咖啡很棒）、算是舒服的客房（房間還算夠大、沖涼水壓很強、但是這次免治有點接觸不良）、幾百年歷史的日本大花園沒次都讓我心曠神怡，就是這些讓我再度回來；地點還算不錯，鬧中取靜、容易前往東京各處，下次要來吃他驚人花園中的鐵板燒餐廳，也要來買他小畫廊中的畫（這次每天都太趕了）。

Spacious room, comfortable bed/pillows. In-room safe, tea/coffee making facilities, mini-bar. Air-con ok. Complementary water x 2. Free decent Wi-Fi.Complementary bathroom toiletries. Good shower pressure. Hair-dryer.Frosted glass bathroom door which is inconvenient in the middle of the night if anyone uses the bathroom!! We stayed in 5 hotels in Japan & all bar 1 had glass doors/windows in their bathrooms, how bizarre!!We used the breakfast buffet restaurant on the 40th floor with views overlooking Tokyo & misty views of Mount Fuji. No egg station but decent coffee.The gardens are nice. A koi carp had died at the side of the pond & the hotel cat caught it & went home full that night.There are dozens of dining & drinking options but, imo, they are way too expensive. We ate at the Tomcat restaurant on our first night but after that we ate outside the hote complexl.Had a drink at the Skybar on the 40th floor, nice night time views over Tokyo. Expensive.Akasaka-Mitsuke subway station is a few mins walk away. There are 3 streets of restaurants & shops in this vicinity.Stayed 3 nights as part of a Riviera Tour.

I stayed here in May with two friends and the size of our room, on the 37th floor, was great for three people with three single beds and a good-sized sitting room. It was, however, rather dated with chipped paint and wallpaper but it was clean. The staff were very helpful and so polite - both checkin and checkout were easy. The hotel was well situated - close to the subway and small cafes and restaurants if you don’t want to eat at the hotel. The gardens were the standout! They were incredible! We were there for the roses which were beautiful but that waterfall!

Older part of the hotel but still well maintained. A number of restaurants within the hotel but pricey. However as it’s centrally located there are loads of restaurants to try within walking distance . Staff are obliging, rooms are clean n comfortable. You get a choice of 3 restaurants for breakfast but the 40th floor gives u an aerial view of Tokyo which is nice. Choice for breakfast is good Will recommend

a nice hotelThe Garden Tower is the older side of the hotel..but nonetheless , its still comfortable and the rooms are bigger than your normal Tokyo Hotel roomsThere are 3 places for breakfast.. so customers are spoilt for choicesThe hotel is quite convenientShinjuku is 4 to 5 metro stops awayAnd there are also lots of food opposite the hotel

We liked that we could easily walk to the train station, and there were lots of places near by to eat at night. We did not really like the beds and the noise. We had 2 rooms with an interconnecting door, travelling as a family of 4 with teenagers, we prefer this setup. However, the interconnecting rooms only had 4 single beds, this is not ideal. I think that interconnecting rooms are usually used for families, so a queen/king in 1 room with 2 singles in the other is the best, but apparently New Otani dont agree.The staff at concierge were very helpful. The rooms were clean and tidy, but not luxurious. Every morning I woke to a strange noise coming from somewhere?? not above?? definately not next door, it was odd, and didn't last a long time, just long enough to wake us all up every day.Breakfast was good and well signed, for a Coeliac traveller it is great to have the allergens listed, so I knew what was Gluten Free and what to avoid. We tried both the restaurant at the top with amazing views as well as the one on the ground with the gardens. Preferred the view and the service at the top.Not sure if we would choose to stay again based on bedding arrangements.

This hotel is beautiful. It is centrally located! The room was spacious, the bed is so comfortable, great bathroom. We can walked across the street to a mall with so many restaurants. The service was excellent

Room was nice, but beds were extremely small. Service was excellent and hotel is very conveniently located, within five minutes walk of the Subway. Hotel has a lot of nice shops within the building itself which was nice.

The hotel is in a good location for the metro and local restaurants. The views from the rooms on the upper floors are spectacular. Make sure on at least one of your days you take breakfast in the restaurant on the 40th floor and on another day in the Garden Restaurant. The service in the hotel of course impeccable.

We stayed here for a few nights while on a tour with Riviera Holidays from the UK. Having been briefed to expect smaller hotel rooms than we might usually find, The New Otani was a real surprise. We had a very large room on the 27th floor, exceptionally well appointed, all amenities which we could expect. We had breakfast in the 40th floor restaurant wihich gave us a view of Mount Fuji on our first morning. The hotel is very close to an amazing selection restaurants. Make the time to explore the hotel gardens.

We had three adults sharing a room and we found it to be very spacious. Good beds, good temperature control and the bathroom was large. The only problem we encountered was the toilet as all the instructions were in Japanese. By the end of our tour we were getting better with the toilets. The elevators were fast and we found if we took the one elevator up and then switched to the other elevators it was faster to get to the restaurant for breakfast. Breakfast was a mixture of Asian and Western. We found their sausages to taste more like hot dog weiners. Service was good and the view of Mount Fuji was good until the clouds rolled in. We didn't eat in any of the other restaurants as we found they were quite pricey. We wandered the streets around the hotel and found excellent small restaurants with reasonable food for Japan prices. This hotel does cater to tour groups, so be aware that it will be crowded. The gardens were lovely to wander through.

We’ve stayed at the New Otani Hotel on several occasions, and it’s never disappointed. On this visit we were allocated an upmarket family room with a separate sitting area, which was spacious and comfortable. Views from the room, on the 37th floor of the Garden Tower, were spectacular. One of the highlights of the hotel is the beautiful Japanese garden; no stay here would be complete without a leisurely stroll along its pretty pathways. Our only slight disappointment was breakfast in the Garden View restaurant. Admittedly it was very busy, but many of the choices were in short supply, and the staff seemed to be somewhat overwhelmed.However, we were hugely impressed by the way in which our luggage was handled. We were able to leave several bags in the Garden Tower when we checked out, and in the early evening they were transferred to the bus that was taking guests to Haneda Airport. Terrific service!

This hotel is just beautiful. It is very big and can take a day to get your bearings and find your way around. The garden was the highlight for me. This ancient garden has been retained as the hotel was built around it. Many features of Japanese gardens are featured in this garden...waterfall, koi pond and numerous very old stone lanterns. It’s a lovely place to relax and watch the wedding couples being photographed in this traditional setting. There are great views of the garden from the Garden Lounge Restaurant. This restaurant has wonderful food and it’s worth the price to experience the lunch time buffet.I had a single room. There was tons of room for me. I had a lovely view across the garden to a sprawling panorama of Tokyo .There are beautiful exclusive boutiques to window shop or stretch the budget.The staff are all charming and attentive.A truly gorgeous hotel.

I have stayed here on several occasions over the past few years and I have enjoyed it on each occasion. There are several areas which could be improved, breakfast for example seems to have slipped in quality, fruit juices are too weak, bacon is soggy and dull, scrambled eggs are lacking in flavour and rather gluggy. The associated facilities, 5restaurants and bars but they will be reviewed seperately.

We'd first booked a hotel/hostel in Ebisu. A friend of ours who frequently stays at The New Otani recommended we change hotels. Booked on hotels.com and the rate was fantastic! For $30 CAD more a night than our first choice, we got so much more. The Main building was full so we were only able to stay in the Garden Tower.Worked in Tokyo for many years and really appreciated the location. Out of the mayhem, quiet, but central to several subway and train lines. Thought the location was fantastic.The room was nicely done, high floor, view of Tokyo Tower, spotlessly clean and welcoming. Twin beds. The bathroom, albeit small was fine. Especially loved the large tile inset in the shower showing old Edo. The bed, as most in Japan are, was much too hard for me albeit there was a mattress pad on top to soften it a bit. Was better but honestly I think the beds could be improved. Absolutely loved the garden. Beautifully done and a brilliant waterfall. We left at 9 am and back at 11 pm everyday so didn't experience any of the restaurants or bars. I would wholeheartedly stay here again. Thought it was great value for two guys travelling, sharing a room. Comfortable, clean, had it all and a beautiful tile of Edo. Perfect.

Nice size room for two with view of Tokyo Tower.Amenities abound-breakfast included in our stay and it was very good. Choose the tower buffet with excellent views of Tokyo. Garden a big plus. A bit confusing to get around at first.Many restaurants, all very expensive.Beware-my room reeked of smoke and, unfortunately, no other room was available.If this is an issue for you then try to make sure you have a non-smoking room, if they exist at all.Was very pleased with my stay, all in all.

The hotel is huge with over 1400 rooms over 3 inter connected buildings. It is very difficult to navigate to restaurants and the outside world.That said the rooms are in good condition and comfortable. You need to allow plenty of time for breakfast, due to the queues. We tried the Tower Garden restaurant for an evening meal and whilst delicious, it was extremely expensive.The Japanese garden beside the hotel is kept in beautiful conditions and are a lovely sanctuary from the bustle of Tokyo.

Beautiful hotel with amazing view and traditional japanese garden. It would of been 5/5 stay however, one baggage attendant / shuttle service booking lady at the shuttle service reception “ishii”wasnt particularity nice. No smiles and abrupt. Gave her the benefit of the doubt (her personality perhaps). However, she treated japanese customers very differently.Other than that it was a great stay. Other staff were very welcoming. Upgraded to “new edo” room with early and late check in. Try to request the new edo room if you canVery spacious and looking over the garden.You definitely feel like u are in luxury hotel

The area of otani is amazing! Close to everything and East to go anywhere with the close metrostation. Imperial garden is nearby so you really feel you are in the central of tokyo. At first when i got to otani i felt luxury, there is a rolce Roys shop in the hotel buildning, Fancy restaurants. The checkin was perfect, went super fast and i got to the room in less than 5 mins. The room is quite nice and depends on what view you get. The bathroom for me was a huge dissapointment, was smal and not so luxury i thought it would be. The bed was big. One more Thing, if you have a tatto you are not allowed to swim in the pool. The garden is amazing at this hotel you must go see it! Its nothing like i’ve seen before And restaurants there aswell. So its 3 diffrent buildings. Tower are the smaler cheap rooms. I recomend you upgrade to the main or executive. I did not get a wow factor from the Tower. Hope you enjoy it!

My wife and I have just spent six nights here on our first visit to Tokyo ...... to see the cherry blossoms which were in full flower. We stayed in a garden suite (Count Suite) on the 37th floor overlooking the Imperial Palace and loved it! Tokyo is a daunting city and we were happy to be staying out of the madness that is the mass of humanity that swarms the more tourist favored areas. The proximity to the metro stations made traveling all around the city easy and stress free (the metro ticket machines are simple and easy to use). Our suite was large, very comfortable and well appointed (Bulgari accessories in the bathroom). Breakfast was good without being overly impressive. There is an excellent little supermarket on the ground floor from which we bought food and wine for supper most evenings ........ food and drink in the hotel is expensive. This really was an excellent choice that I’m happy to recommend.

Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Wow! This hotel is massive!The rooms and towers were a bit confusing but you get used to it after a few days. The room layout was nice and the bed was super comfortable. View from the 33rd was amazing, with Tokyo tower in the background.Loved the robes and slippers provided. Was nice to have warm, toilet seats in the middle of the night. The supplies available for use was more than ample: toothbrush, hair comb etc and no need to ask front desk.Enjoyed breakfast on the 40th floor, everything was provided and the food tasted great.Most importantly: the staff were spectacular! All the staff we came across were super friendly and accommodating, spoke English so there was no language barrier. There’s a subway station just a 2 minutes walk outside of the hotel. I will definitely stay here again with no hesitation!

Great location., close to rail service and shopping. Great service. The staff go above and beyond. Hotel is very clean. The 400 year old garden is just beautiful. The shops and restaurants in the hotel are awesome. Loved staying here.

The hotel is very pleasant and there are many luxury shops and restaurants located in the complex but restaurants in the complex can be expensive. It should be noted that the hotel is not centrally located and a taxi ride ( single journey approx 2000 yen) is an option for journeying into the city to find a wider choice of more affordable restaurants but this adds to the cost of dining out. If accommodated in the Garden Tower it should be noted that the entrance to the Garden Tower is at least a 10 minute walk through the joining lobby from the main entrance of the hotel. The hotel decor is well presented and hotel staff are very courteous and helpful with check in, luggage transfer and providing refreshments in courtesy rooms whilst waiting for rooms are to be made available for occupancy. One particular point of mention is the concierge desk in the main entrance which is very helpful in arranging city tours, restaurant reservations, transport etc. Overall a very pleasant visit to this hotel and definitely worth a recommendation.

The hotel grounds is massive with numerous restaurants, shops, and beautiful outdoor garden. The room was very clean, good sized, well-maintained and great amenities. The buffet breakfast and Japanese breakfast were delicious.

First time in Tokyo, I stayed in this large hotel, which is conveniently located close to a shopping centre and the metro. Staff were very friendly and helpful. The highlights were the Japanese garden and breakfast in the restaurant next to the lifts in the lobby area. Arigato!

The hotel is massive, a little dated however comfortable and clean. It very near the metro and there is a district with lots of restaurants near by. service is superb as you’d expect in Japan. the Japanese garden is lovely, particularly if you get a garden facing room from which you can see it from above but also all the parks in the distance too. stunning views - I was on the 16th floor. would stay here again as it’s so easy and central.

Although expensive, this hotel has shopping areas, restaurants, convenient stores, etc within the hotel.Rooms were very clean and organised. Staffs were extremely courteous and friendly. Housekeeping was Superb and friendly too. Very near to Subway and shopping malls. Highly recommended.

I stayed here for 2 weeks and really loved my stay. The hotel is clean, the staff is helpful and very efficient with delivering to your requests and the position of the hotel is very convenient to move around Tokyo (2 stations nearby in less than 10 min walking distance). There are plenty of restaurants across the road from the hotel and a Starbucks nearby - couldn’t complain about lack of choices there! The airport shuttle bus leaves from the hotel and goes to the airport in about an hour (including a couple of other hotels’ stops along the way) for a fraction of a taxi cost. My only complaint was the static electricity shock I experienced when inside the hotel- I don’t know if this was just the dry cold air as it’s winter, or the carpets on the floor which seemed synthetic, but touching the lift buttons or my room’s door was sometimes quite unpleasant because of the static shock. Not sure what the hotel could do about that though!Overall, I enjoyed my stay and I would stay again.

Spent 4 night is this hotel which was very comfortable. It is a older hotel therefore the rooms are bigger. The only thing is the décor, very dated, but everything works fine. I liked the area because its more of a business district, therefore feels quieter but located near many restaurants. The hotel has a very beautiful garden which can be visited. The location is very good because it is served by at least 5 metro lines which made moving around tokyo very easy.

New Otani Garden Tower was an oasis in the middle of hectic and crowded Tokyo The area was like being in another country. Spacious and clean streets with lots of trees. We took the JR Train from Tokyo station to Yotsuya station via Marunouchi Line. It took 12 min. Then walked 670m along two main roads. You can also take a taxi that will charge buckets for the short ride. The room was large with decent views of the district and some of the nearby buildings, and the beds and other furniture very comfortable. Sleep quality was great on floor 18. The bathroom was superb with plenty of free toiletries. The minibar didn’t have great choices but was ok. Staff were incredibly polite and helpful. The shuttle bus was a bit slow stopping at many hotels on the way to the airport (50 minutes to terminal 1), but very convenient and priced around $10.The hotel grounds were impressive with two buildings, manicured gardens and 30 restaurants!! But here was the catch: While hotel rates were very reasonable for the quality service received, the on-site restaurants and bars had exorbitant prices. Nonetheless we had the best stay of our entire world trip through 8 countries at the New Otani Garden Tower. Highly recommended. Wish we could have stayed longer

We stayed in hotel New Otani garden tower for 2 nights. Check in was smooth and quick as we arrived late afternoon. Staffs are friendly and attentive. We had room overlooking the Japanese garden, water fall and city view which was very nice. Room facilities were great and internet connection was good. Our package include Buffet breakfast - you can choose one from 3 different venues. We tried two different places - garden lounge which is on the same floor as lobby and one at 40th floor with the city view. It can be very busy in the morning. The garden lounge has more food choices compared to Bella Vista (40th floor). Hotel is located in huge complex so you can get confused easily. They provide newspaper outside the door every morning which was nice. There is beautiful Japanese garden with waterfall outside the breakfast place garden lounge . It is good place to walk around after breakfast and good photo opportunity. For public transport, the Akasaka mitsuke station is only 5-10 mins walk from hotel. Overall we enjoyed our stay and happy to come back.

We booked this hotel because of its historical garden. It was no disappointment. We got a room with garden view. A morning walk in the garden relaxed and refreshed our soul and body. Breakfast was not included in our booking. However, it was not hard to find eateries inside this hotel complex. We also visited the Tokyo Garden Terrace opposite to the hotel. There are fine restaurants there and a supermarket.

We stopped here for 2 nights. This is more a complex than a simple hotel. It’s Big. Location is good. Service and staff were great. The traditional garden is astonishing, set an hour aside for a walk there, you won’t regret it. Rooms are well sized and well appointed. Not new, but still good and meticulously clean. The staff have excellent English skills (and probably others as well). Multiple restaurants and bars on premises, each catering for different budgets and tastes. The top floor buffet breakfast has great views. Try it. The sky bar on the 40th floor is also worth a visit to enjoy the view. Try it. The Kyubey sushi restaurant on the same floor was simply wonderful. Do yourself a favor!

Well located for accessing business and tourist locations. A large hotel which is a little tired but still comfortable. About 10 restaurants on site, and an eating district 5 minutes walk. Have stayed here before and employees are very helpful

Beautiful Japanese garden is worth exploring. Breakfast buffets have great views of the garden. the hotel is looking a bit tired with some cracked tiles etc. Lots of on-site shopping to experience while you're there. Expensive shops though.

Hotel New Otani Tokyo is one of the most venerable Hotels in Japan. I have menbership of Hotel New Otani Tokyo, The locationl is conveniently nearby many attractive shops, restaurants, and tourist attractions in Tokyo. And the hotel also offers elegant spacious guest room and comfortable service. The menbership will satisfy everyone.

seriously, this place is huge. You never see the same member of staff twice. The rooms are fine, comfortable and clean but I still wouldn't recommend this place. queuing for breakfast at whatever time you try is a pain and the hotel 'gyms', well the 2 exercise rooms, (see photo) are just inadequate even for a small hotel. don't be fooled by the pictures on the web site - these facilities are all at an extra cost! I can't think of a good reason for staying here

Very pleasant, efficient and helpful staff. Hotel is well situated to restaurants and subway. Also has airport bus that picks you up at the hotel. Staff picked up our luggage from our room, brought it to the bus, and loaded it for us too. Rooms are clean, quiet and comfortable. Lovely garden on the property too. Highly recommend.

Hotel New Otani offers spacious rooms with well appointed bathrooms. We spent only one night here but thought the service was excellent and the grounds beautiful. It is a large hotel and conference center, as well as an event venue. The princess of Japan was holding her wedding reception here several days after we left. The restaurant had a beautiful view of the grounds, the food was good (not great) and somewhat expensive, but if you arrive a weary traveler, it is well worth the money.

With no dis-appointment I was happy to stay in this hotel again and it lived up to the standards I expected. The rooms are nicely appointed with large bathrooms. The concierge service has bailed me out this trip and the previous trip. They will find out the information for you if they are aware of it.

This is a very nice hotel with a very good location, close to embassies and corporate business area.The hotel is very big, have couple of lobbies entrances and about 10 restaurants and plenty of stores inside the building.The hotel team is very friendly and open to make their best effort to make us feel like home.I would stay here without any doubt in my next trip.

The Garden Towers hotel starts on the sixth floor from the Main hotel, and then a walk past shops etc. to the reception for the Garden Towers and separate lifts. The outdoor pool is very large but is only open for about two months of the year The indoor pool is on the 3rd floor of the main hotel, but only 4 people are allowed in at a time, and costs about £40 a time, even for hotel guests. If you join the New Otani Club, the pool can be used between 7 am and 10 am for half price. You will also receive reduced price for breakfast. The Japanese Garden, within the hotel, is very picturesque as is the rose garden which is very fragrant when they are in flower.Our room was quite spacious and modern, with distant views of the Tokyo tower,. The TV channels were mainly news channels in various languages. Hotel is very close to underground station , with easy access to most of Tokyo, remember which entrance, so can easily return to the same one.

The most lasting impression is the size of this hotel, it has ~1800 rooms I think, but all the associated surrounds is massive. Its huge and actually quite difficult to navigate all the halls/corridors, lifts, escalators etc. to find where you want to go. e.g. trying to find the way out to the nearby subway station can be confusing - signage in English could be improved.However its definitely quality accommodation. Its beautifully kept, not just clean, but polished, there are polite staff everywhere and it has lots of facilities, though TV channels could be improved.Room is very generous by Japanese standards - the size would put most to shame. e were in the Garden Wing and were amazed at the walk from the main reception area (almost 100m).We got our room at what we considered a very good rate for Tokyo but beware of the extras - in-house restaurants, breakfasts, dining etc. are mostly frightfully expensive. There are maybe 2 in house restaurants (of the 38?) that are reasonably priced but you have to search them out. If you want to eat on a budget go to the nearby area around the train station, there are cafes and convenience stores there.The proximity to the metro line is good for getting around Tokyo but I would recommend that if you are arriving by train to Tokyo Central you catch a taxi with your luggage as the subway line doesn't run from Tokyo central station. Also when leaving if you have an early flight don't rely on the bus service as it won't get you to Narita for a 9.30 am flight - back to Tokyo Central and catch the Harita Express.An absolute mind boggling hotel due to its scale - I can only assume its not 5* because it is so huge it doesn't quite have that homely feel.

We were astounded at the size of this place, given the land value in Tokyo. Three separate buildings and a beautiful Japanese garden. We stayed here as part of a tour group. The rooms were really good, with astonishing views. And the service was exceptional. There are several restaurants in the complex, including a great sushi bar which we thoroughly enjoyed. And there’s a great bar on the top floor, with a sensational view. Mind you, it’s certainly not cheap, which we kind of expected in such a 5 star place. Not sure I’d choose to stay here again. There are probably other hotels that are just as nice, but maybe not so up market. This place is definitely top drawer.

I stayed for three nights during a business visit to Tokyo. The rooms are old and tired, the TV has minimal channels (and virtually nothing in English) and the hotel services are painfully old-fashioned. For instance, you have to bring a breakfast voucher to the restaurant even though the computer already says that you have breakfast included. When I didn't have my voucher, I was asked if I could go get it. You have to sign a form to borrow an ironing board, and you have to log back into the wifi every time your have been away from the signal. Also, the prices are ridiculous. The cheapest glass of red wine in Trader Vic's is £20, and you have to pay £22 to use the gym or the pool. Paying to use the gym is not reasonable in a luxury hotel. The breakfast on the 40th floor is very average; cheap ingredients (only plain sliced white bread for the toaster). The buffet breakfast in Satsuki (in the main building, and you can eat there using your breakfast voucher instead of the Garden Tower) is far superior. Finally, the level of English among the staff was very limited. I know that this is a very famous traditional luxury hotel in Tokyo, but if it wants to be competitive with the big international brands then it will have to change.

We enjoyed our stay at this hotel very much. The location is excellent: very close to a subway station as well as many restaurants and cafes nearby. The room was not very big, but was very well appointed and clean. Robes and slippers were provided, which is common in Japanese hotels and very nice. The service at the hotel was very good.We really enjoyed the breakfast (we joined hotel club which gave us a good discount). The breakfast buffet was very good and we had a view of Tokyo from the 40th floor and even saw Mt. Fuji in the distance.This hotel has a very nice garden - make sure to visit it if you stay there. If you make a reservation well in advance you will get a very decent rate. I suggest booking even a year in advance if possible.

This 5 star hotel comprises of 2 hotel towers and 1 office tower. We stayed in the Garden Tower with views over their Japanese Garden. The hotel is so big that even though we were on the 25th floor the room number started with a 45 which was a touch confusing.The room was supposed to be a non smoking room however a previous guest must have smoked in it as there was a smell of smoke trying to be disguised with a deodorising agent and not to effectively either.Although housekeeping did a fantastic job of keeping the room very clean it was rather dated and in need of a spruce up. There was only 1 bedside table and light so the other person missed out. Someone decided that the black/red cushions on the chairs looked good… they didn’t and looked totally out of place with the beige/faun theme of the room.The towels were great as were the toiletries (except no body lotion) bathrobes were supplied too but there were no hooks to hang them up on. The Japanese bidet was an experience…The view over the Japanese Garden (within the hotel grounds) was great and the Koi were so large in the ponds that you could see them easily.The staff were helpful and friendly although asking something out of the unusual caused a bit of confusion. It’s about time hotels had some sort of breakfast system in place for guests departing before the restaurants open.Breakfast was thankfully included in our rate from 2 locations, 1 on the top floor of the garden tower where you are supposed to be able to see Mt Fuji on a clear day (can’t see that happening very often) this restaurant was very dated and the food nothing special for a buffet style set up, just the usual stuff. The 2nd was overlooking the Japanese Garden, so a lovely location but again the buffet was nothing special and whoever chose the chairs obviously never sat on them as although they look good they are far to low to eat from at a table and are better suited to relax in with a drink of some sort.If you want to explore Tokyo the hotel is very close to a station on the Ginza Line which can take you to some of Tokyo’s main attractions.So in conclusion, if they undertook a refurbishment, not just of the rooms but the whole hotel including food offerings they would be 5 star.

Stay at this hotel last week. Many good hotels have a unique facility that stands out, but few have all these unique facilities coming together under one hotel! This hotel has its own shopping centre with a wide variety of shops & restaurants (about 200 in all, I was told!), a beautiful 400-year-old Japanese Garden, a sprawling Rose Garden, etc. I stayed at the Garden Tower and had a room with a beautiful view of the Japanese Garden and the city! The rooms were spacious by Tokyo standards, very clean and well maintained. The beddings were very comfortable and we asked for a King-sized bed, but what we got were what looked like two queen-sized beds joined together to give a super-King-sized bed!The staff were fantastic - and all those I spoke to could understand and speak good English, and they were all friendly and attentive, and always helpful.The location was excellent, just a short 5 min walk from the Akasaka-Mitsuke subway station. The station is also an interchange for several key lines that connect to practically all parts of Tokyo - you won't need a taxi at all (unless you have some difficulties with walking, of course). Overall, a great stay and will come back if I'm in the area again :)

The room in this property is very well maintained although it is a bit old, for instance you will still access the room using a normal key rather than card or app. Size is decent and it is very convenient walk to the train station of Akasaka-Mitsuke where Marunouchi line can take you to places such as Ginza and Shinjuku in no time. Staffs are very courteous and willing to go over the extra mile. Amenities are very basic but room is always very clean. Overall, I feel it is a very comfortable stay and strategic place for those who are commuting around via train.

New Otani is a must whrn you visit Tokyo, has everything you need, this time we book at the Garden Tower, and they surprised us, welcoming are always great in Japan but New OTani Staff is incredibly good at it. Food at the buffette was great, they had a metro station in aboyt 50 mts from the door of Garden Tower, you can book at the spa or better yet a dinner with a view.Please try to book at this hotel it will worth every yen you spend here.

Large hotel in a convenient location, with awesome gardens that make it worth a visit alone. Rooms are a reasonable size, and whilst everything is exceptionally well maintained - the decor is a bit 90s (at best) and needs a facelift. Breakfast was OK, but not great. I thought it was a bit rough that access to the gym / sauna was at an extra cost (and a significant one) and for nothing that great in any case.

We stayed 3 days here and found it very convenient for touring Tokyo. The staff here takes care of your every need. There are a ton of shops and restaurants within the hotel as well as a great shopping area right outside the hotel. Tokyo subway is right outside the lobby. We stayed in a suite which had plenty of room however the rooms are in dire need of an update. Carpet had stains and a musty smell. I would recommend staying in the main hotel instead of the tower which is newer

One of the best hotels I ever been to. A very comfortable and clean hotel, with very good service staff, good breakfast, beds a little hard for Norwegian bodies, but apart from that an excellent hotel in the upper class.

Staying 6 days and I decided to go this hotel for the situation in Tokyo, the garden and the swimming pool. Situation is perfect : you can go every where from Akasaka mitsuke station. Garden is really romantic and incredibly peacefully in the heart of Tokyo! There is also a river with small boots and fishers. I was upgraded for a bigger room with view on the garden. Wonderful view on the garden and Tokyo. By night is magic. (See pics)Unfortunately, I was not able to go on swimming pool because it was closed. The reason is that is not anymore the summer !! But the weather was hot and sunny. Too bad. Especially because I sent email before for asking conditions to access to the swimming pool. Nobody told me anything. Even more, during checking no one said something when I asked for swimming pool. I really don’t understand why the hotel didn’t mention that in the room or when you check in. Moreover, they closed during holidays in Japan... don’t understand the interest to do that .... and easy to improve. Another point easy to improve: king size bed is great, especially in Tokyo! But why not have 2 nightstands? There is plenty of place beside the bed but only one (master) nightstand. The most important is the quality of the service and, except the swimming pool problem, the staff there is high professional and friendly!Special thanks to Garden Lounge team !

My wife and I travelled to Tokyo for our honeymoon and picked the hotel new Otani as a treat to ease ourselves into the holiday. From the moment we arrived the experience was amazing, we were very lucky to be upgraded to Executive Zen room which was amazing the room, the view the service could not be faulted at all!

This hotel had wonderful views from both the room and the breakfast buffet. Service was perfect even lavender pillows if requested. Every detail was in place. Great boutiques through out and close to the subway which is very easy to figure out in this magnificent city.

The New hotel is a large international class hotel in a central yet quiet Tokyo neighbourodd; It has been renovated and it's really impeccable (except perhaps the breakfast room, which can be crowded). It is less slick that the Hyatts but has a local flavor that adds to its charm. Very nice japanese garden makes for a beautiful the view.

What a great place and wonderful experience. Centrally located and within easy reach of downtown Tokyo. Staffs were very friendly and always ready to help. Loads of restaurants and shops downstairs. The Japanese garden at back was just wow.

This proved to be the perfect hotel for us. After a long haul overnight flight we wanted to relax and not have to wander far for an evening meal. We had booked a triple room and were advised when we checked in that the room was no longer available and we had been given a free upgrade which was a great start. The room itself elicited "wows" from all of us as it consisted of a sitting area with one bed, a dressing table corridor with two rooms leading off it (a loo and a wet room) which led through to a large double bedroom with walk in closet. The window in each bedroom provided amazing views of the city. The garden was lovely and there were numerous food options within the hotel. The subway was about a 10 minute walk away. In the morning we ate breakfast in the restaurant on the top floor as it was included in the price and found the food tasty and hot. Thank you New Otani for making our first night in Japan truly memorable!

Very nice hotel, friendly staff and nice rooms.BUT, standing in line for 15 minutes to get breakfast ruins your morning. If you need the early breakfast (start 6am), prepare to stand in a long line...

Business hotel with terrific views and typical for its class service. Good mix of restaurants and shops in the complex, plus, the famed New Otani Hotel garden. This part of the hotel also has the charming surprise of being able to book a personal Japanese tea ceremony quite inexpensively.

The New Otani is a huge complex with more than 2000 rooms and some 40 restaurants in all. Big, beautiful garden and a shopping complex in the lower floors. Not a very ‘personal’ place in other words. But it works. Staff are extremely professional and friendly. Rooms are big, and you have lovely views on most sides of the complex.We did not try any of the restaurants (as there are plenty of options nearby). Subway is just a couple of minutes away. Location is good and quiet.It does not get 5 stars in my review because of two things:Decor is very dated. I don’t think this place has been changed a lot since the time it was built (60-s). The pool area was a huge disappointment. Crowded, pool full of screaming kids, sunbeds tighter than on a cruise ship - and expensive! Even as a guest of the hotel you had to pay Y2000,- per visit.

Personnel highly committed to meet with customer expectations. Very high quality on services delivered, very good hotel where to stay in Tokyo: large and cleaned rooms, services delivered and facilities, breakfast were awesome. I was really enjoyed for having spent time here I'm willing to get a new experience there and will certainly book a room for my next business trip in Tokyo.Many thanks to the staff !

Without the stunning 400 year old gardens and large swimming pool, this hotel we would have to classify as modern, dull and good but not special. However the rarity of a Pool in Tokyo and the beautiful aspects across gardens and parks more than compensate for the otherwise rather plastic hotel.The hotel design suffers from having the accomodation wing a long tedious walk from the reception through a glitzy overly-expensive shopping arcade with the usual ( we find boring) array of big name brands.However the basement level Supermarket is a pleasant haven to browse through and is very reasonably priced - good food and drinks to scoff in your room!As a special treat, we really recommend the formal Cakes & Tea buffet in the afternoon - superb quality overlooking those incredible Gardens.Service was ( as always in Japan) first class. Great city views from higher floors.We have 3 children, so would be happy to go back - but not for the hotel accommodation - just for the Pool and Gardens - and would eat out ( apart from Tea) or in our room.

The staff are top notch, the service is fantastic, everything is spotless. Short walk from Asataka Misuke station. 1 word of advice, do not eat in pool area big insult. The food area about 5 minutes walk back under the expressway has a very high variety so take the time so much cheaper then the hotels. Train trip to Tokyo central is 5 minutes on the Ginza orange line or red line. Join the club, makes the facilities free at no cost. Beautiful gardens to explore.

We stayed at the Hotel New Otani, Garden Tower July of 2018. Had one room for my wife and I and one for our two teenage kids. First, this is just a really nice hotel. Very well appointed, very friendly staff, lots of restaurants. It is in a terrific location for someone wanting to visit Tokyo - a 5 minute walk to two subway stations that can take you anywhere in Tokyo. A nice couple of shopping/restaurant streets also just a few minutes walk. The room was a very nice size - about the size of a typical US hotel room and from my research, much larger than the typical Tokyo hotel room - we fit two people with two suitcases and two backpacks in each room and had space to walk around. I think they had about 5 different choices for breakfast, though we chose the main lobby buffet several times and were quite happy with it. Good selection of Japanese and Western dishes. They have a bar that is open till pretty late so you don't have to go out if you want a night cap. And even though it has over a thousand guest rooms, you did not feel like you would get lost in the crowd. We made use of the concierge several times to make restaurant bookings and never had to wait. Also tried out the pool (which we did have to pay extra for which was a little surprising as a hotel guest) and it was a nice refresher. We would definitely book this hotel again.

This garden is only accessible to New Otani Club members and is alone a reason to become a member. I was lucky to have a Club room in the main Tower 8th floor overlooking the Rose Garden. It was worth every penny! I will be back

My husband and I stayed in the Main Tower of this hotel in 2000 and 2001 and have good memories. Our Garden Tower room was equally comfortable and the staff is as attentive as we remember from the past visits. We enjoyed a full Western and Japanese breakfast in the 40th floor restaurant with a spectacular view of the city. We also ate in the Garden Lounge for dinner one night and, again, the food and service were excellent.

We had a good experience at the New Otani. Staff is very attentive and do strive to give you the best possible service. There are several Metro station within walking distance. The breakfast is very good with Japanese and international alternatives. The gardens are spectacular. The rooms have good space and are ultra clean.

I stayed in this hotel in 1975 and had the opportunity, this April, to stay once again as I remembered the luxury and wondered how it had aged over the forty three years.Firstly, the location is great, it's tower block rooms overlook the Emperors Palace and the huge 400 year old private Japanese garden of the hotel. It is magnificent and huge. There is a small restaurant hidden away in the garden.Inside is five star plush. The room we were given in the tower block was extremely modern and spotless.Eating in the Garden Cafe is an experience. Elegant, comfortable and a stunning view through the wall of windows.

I always stay here when visiting Tokyo, for good reason. Yes, it's a little older, but for the price it is by far the best value full service hotel I have found in Tokyo. It is centrally located, the rooms are large (for Japan) and clean, and the staff are wonderfully helpful. I was lucky enough to upgraded to a suite for no extra the last time I stayed, but the standard rooms I usually book are still very good. The "gym" consists of a few treadmills and stair-climbers, so the body builders out there might find that off-putting. Having stayed in many hotels in Tokyo over the past 30 years, New Otani is the only one I keep coming back to.

We spent 6 nights at Hotel New Otani Tokyo. We needed help to rent a baby stroller and concierge staff were very helpful. We received the stroller upon our arrival. All services were really good. Our kids received a warm welcome. Hotel staff were very friendly and helpful. The hotel did a great job maintaining such a fantastic garden. The hotel is conveniently located within a short walk from Akasaka-mitsuke train station. Will definitely come back for Sakura season next year.

The main draw of the room was the fantastic views of the city. We had large room which was very comfortable, clean and well kept.We only stayed one night but we enjoyed it. The location is within easy access to public transport so easy to get to and from. The gardens were stunning and fantastic for a morning walk after our stay. We didn't have the breakfast but there were plenty of shops and places nearby.

I stayed in the Otani garden hotel over a weekend with my college-aged daughter. The hotel was very nice, and the staff very friendly and helpful. From the initial greeting, to check-in, and getting around, the staff was very quick to be helpful. The garden on the hotel ground is a nice break. The breakfast spread was great. The sushi was also excellent. The hotel was a reasonable walk from the subway station, so it was a good jump off point for exploring Tokyo. I would highly recommend the hotel.

The last time I stayed at this hotel was more than 20 years ago on a business trip, and I remembered fondly the quality of service, and the gardens. I have not been back to this part of Tokyo since, though I have been to other parts of Japan.This time i stayed for a long weekend 4D/4N and I loved it. The staff is still friendly, polite, helpful, thoughtful; and for seniors, these qualities matter. Everything in the room meets the guests' needs. The only things missing which I asked for, were an ironing board and iron , and body lotion. In the end I decided I didn't really need them.The Tokyo Metro subway is just 5 minutes away, which was very convenient. The airport shuttle stops at this hotel. So it was a double plus.We will definitely consider staying here again because of the transport convenience.

Been staying many years here the location is good but the price is high for the room standards offered needs a good update on product 3600 yen for a burger is a bit of a hard amount to justify as well Room had insects which is due to old furnishings Pity problem is the hotel is highly occupied

I came to the Hotel New Otani 13 yrs ago when the famed Capitol Tokyu Hotel closed its doors for renovations. While the hotel has been an OK comfort over the years, it has never matched the quality of the Capitol Tokyu Hotel and it's regard for their regular guests. This was never more evident than on my most recent trip. I arrived at the hotel early and checked in early, as I have done numerous times over 13 years. Upon check out I find that the hotel charged me a full days rate for checking in early. No one had ever told me I would be paying a full days rate, nor had I ever been charged that before. The desk agent then said I signed for it when I checked in. Understand, I'm half asleep and sign wherever they tell me to sign when I check in, as it's normal....I'm not reading the fine print. So, I had no clue I was being charged a full days rate. I asked to have them waive the fee or at least cut it in half, which I would have agreed to, but they said no with no exceptions. I have NEVER experienced such disregard for a guests patronage to a hotel for 13 years....not in Hong Kong, New York, Germany or any of the many places I frequent numerous times a year for the past three decades. To say the least, this hotel cares about nothing but money and their greed. No discern for their loyal guests. To this I say SCREW YOU! I will gladly take my business back to the new Capitol Tokyu Hotel and all of my business relationships that travel with me. I will not tolerate it. So, to all who are wondering about the Hotel New Otani, I say please do yourself a favor and go stay at ANY of the hotels in the Akasaka area, but not this one.

Stayed 3 nights (I last stayed here in the 1970's). Nice room, spotlessly clean, all amenities. Fabulous garden, and the hotel is centrally located. Great staff, very good selection of restaurants and cafes within the Hotel. My sole unease was the size of the hotel; the lobby and walkways were always crowded.

This my second time staying in this hotel. The key attraction of this hotel is their beautiful Japanese garden with ponds, waterfall and several restaurants located within the garden. At night, it is beautifully illuminated. Strolling in the garden is a must do. Breakfast is a available with the room. You have choices of international or Japanese. The revolving restaurant at the tower block offers good view of Tokyo and on a good weather, you may also see Mount Fuji. The Garden Court and Nadaman Japanese restaurant offer view to the garden. The hotel is also within 5-8 mins walking distance to Akasaka Mitsuke subway station which is approx 5 station of less from Ginza, Harajuku, Omestando, Shinjuku and Shibuya. The route is not sheltered though. There are many affordable restaurants in Akasaka.My recent stay is the standard triple room at the garden tower. The decor and facilities are a bit dated but it is a good size room for three. If you book the room directly from the hotel, do cater for 10% service charge, 8.8% consumption tax and ¥300 accommodation tax. This works out approximately additional 19.6% of the room price.

Near subway station. Easy access to all part of Tokyo. Good size room for Tokyo. Staffs were very helpful. Beautiful garden. We are very happy with the hotel except "Garden Tower buffet". It is not worth the money they charge. Skip the restaurant..

The hotel is huge, beautiful and luxurious, especially the lobby and restaurant area. A bit crowded during breakfast. Very beautiful Japanese garden as well to stroll around. Everything is very clean. The location is great as well, to walk around and also the metro is very close (if you choose the right exit, it is metro Akasaka-mitsuke). It is a pity though that the rooms are not as luxurious as the hotel in itself, they would need to be updated (although apparently part of the rooms are updated and parts are not, so maybe I was just not lucky).

I stayed at the New Otani Garden Tower on my recent business trip to Tokyo. I stayed there in the past and appreciated its location - very close to the Akasaka district, full of restaurants and other amenities. As, it was not my first time there I have seen different type of rooms. All of them are of a decent size and very functional, although their look is a bit dated. This time I was upgraded to a suite and I had a huge amount of space. Staff is always very friendly and responsive. The Hotel offers a selection of places where you can have breakfast, from the more traditional Asian, to more Western one. I tended to stick to the Garden Terrace which has a fantastic view over the traditional Japanese Garden. The hotel offers different fitness room too, although they are not open 24 hours. All in all, it is a very nice place where to stay in Tokyo - highly recommended for excellent value for money

We stayed here for 1 night. They hotel was very clean and the staff were very helpful and friendly. Like many hotels within Tokyo, the food and drinks within their own restaurants were fairly pricey, however if your getting over jet lag and not feeling up to venturing outside of the hotel grounds, then there is plenty of cuisine choices to choose from. The gardens that surround the hotel are definitely well worth a walk round, very tranquil.

The Garden Tower is a highrise with multiple rooms and a garden Court with multiple restaurants. Connected to the rest of the New Otani hotel by hallways at several levels, it also provides access to the beautiful gardens that surround the hotel. This is an excellent hotel with a large number of dining options.

There are so many modern and fully equipped hotels in Tokyo that one wonders what the allure of New Otani is. It is like steeping back in time which has its charm bit as the hotel lacks simple amenities like a functioning modern fitness center. Additionally, what hotel charges for their fitness center, crazy. It was clean, well located but I would not stay here again.

The hotel is very nice and the rooms were large, clean,comfortable and quiet.The japanese garden which is part of the hotel is super. The location is excellent. Close to Akasaka metro station and shops and restaurants.The only dissonance was that we had booked at The Main but were given rooms in the Garden Tower. However, as the Tower rooms were nice it wasn't a big deal.

This hotel was my first choice in Tokyo and it didn't disappoint. The garden off of the old main building is a wonder. I spent hours there in quiet contemplation of the carp that seemed to sense my presence. The breakfast that they provide is superior to oes Ive had at other luxury hotels. All-in-all a very pleasant stay.

Even if the hotel is to big to feel homey, is very clean, comfortable, big rooms with nice perspective and the staff is very friendly and polite. Luxury shopping opportunities for last minute gifts, from jewelry to nice packed sweets are very convenient. The hotel breakfast place has a view to the Japanese garden but the food selection, even though is more than sufficient is far from being mouth watering as one could expect considering the price.
