Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The New Otani was the first leg of a japan tour, and set our expectations. It is a massive hotel, with rooms in 2 towers, and c40 restaurants on site. Clean, reasonably well appointed rooms, if begining to get tired, bathroom with a shower in the bath, and like most of the hotels we stayed in, heated toilet / bidet - an experience. It was close to the Akasaka region, with lots of small eateries, and close to the metro to get about Tokyo. Lovely gardens and the road outside the hotel had some of the best displays of cherry blossoms we saw on our tour

The hotel, or at least the Garden Tower, is old and tired, and even most of the staff has a US mentality of non-kindness, unbefitting Japan. The high-end breakfast restaurant Satsuki is an exception, but it is part of the main building operations, not frequented by the bus tourists that corrupted service in the tower. The hotel is nicely situated and its availability is its claim to faim. No 4* service with ambition to outperform. Tower rooms are bland and outdated, with airco systems and telephones befitting a 80-ies retro party.

This hotel has a great location. The rooms are big, clean & well maintained. In true Japanese style, the staff are excellent. English is no problem. Swimming pool is huge & heated. Special mention to the Tour desk Concierge, who are all very helpful.

We stayed as part of a tour group. On our arrival, the staff were really welcoming and couldn’t do enough for us. The hotel is well placed, close to the metro line and at the junction of a couple of main streets. Our room was comfortable and quiet, withholds the usual amenities you would expect of a hotel of this size and style. The restaurants are lovely and the staff incredibly attentive. The only thing that let the hotel down during our stay, was the a lack of attention by the domestic staff when they failed to leave us clean towels and a bath mat. Otherwise, we would recommend a stay in this hotel.

As a professional executive consultant with multiple thousands of nights in hotels in many different countries, this hotel ranks as my personal favorite worldwide. I’ve had the pleasure of staying here several times during 2018 and given the choice between Starwood’s best, The Ritz Carlton or anywhere else would simply no longer be an option. This is it, from perfect Japanese omotenashi from curbside assistance to the top managers, from the amazing choices and quality of restaurants to the incredible attention to detail for every guest... these guys have it nailed. Strongly suggest you try their new Edo style single room if you’re a solo traveler. The Japanese gardens on premise are a slice of heaven on earth as are the spectacular views from the rotating SkyBar.

An excellent, full service hotel with friendly and attentive staff, very helpful concierge, good size rooms (ours had a garden view from the 22nd floor and a king size bed), a business center, many restaurants (breakfast buffet is impressive - and a bit expensive)... Well located near 2 subway lines. A vast complex with 2 towers.

We stayed here as part of a large group. The hotel is 3 towers. A lot of walking is involved as the hotels cover a large area, there are lifts or escalators to all areas. The room was not huge, but we didn't expect that in a city hotel, but were well appointed and clean. There are numerous restaurant s and snack bars available. We had a drink in the top bar of the Garden Tower with lovely night-time views. Breakfast was buffet style with more than enough to choose from. The gardens of the hotel are very pretty both in the day time and at night. We did not use the pool as to do so would have cost about £30. The staff were very helpful and friendly. A good base from which to explore Tokyo.

Unbelievably busy hotel with masses of people everywhere. Not a place for some quiet in Tokyo. Well located near to many major transport routes and attractions. Glorious Japanese traditional garden well worth spending time. Rooms werevery small with little space to move, bathroom similarly small. Breakfast restaurants SO busy. Most mornings queues lasted 10 - 20 minutes just to get in to the restaurant. Good breakfast selection

I thought I had booked a garden-facing room but upon arrival (8pm) I wasn't allocated one. Upon closer examination of my booking form, I saw in the small print that this was only requested (I had booked through the hotel website). This was a bummer for me for it was the reason I chose the Garden Tower vs Main Building. However, on the plus side, the garden is indeed beautiful (cherry blossom season), there are many restaurants to eat from and it is very accessible to the subway. Service was good, staff polite and efficient (it's Japan after all!), even though I thought the room needed some updating.

Positives:- good location walking distance to JR and subway lines a couple of stops from Shinjuku and Shibuya-beautiful gardens-friendly staffNegatives:- Such a huge hotel but only two tiny gyms, and I mean really tiny with only a couple of treadmills and bikes and no weights room, totally inadequate for the size of the hotel. -rooms are very small, some people at check in where trying to get a room with queen or king bed but didn't seem to be having any luck, most rooms are two single beds with small bathroom. Understand this is in line with local hotels so if after more spacious rooms best going with one of the International hotels. - hotel is a little tired and showing its age.

Stayed here as part of a Tokyo marathon travel package. Pleasantly surprised. This hotel transports you back to the grandeur of the 1960's. The era of James Bond, "You only live twice". The wallpaper, carpets and decor are perfectly preserved. Rooms are dated but well maintained and spacious by modern standards. This hotel is huge. It kinda feels as big as a Las Vegas/Macau casino hotel. There are a mind blowing number of restaurants to choose from. Service was good and attentive. Buffet breakfast has good selection of food. Outside Japanese garden was quite large, very pleasant to walk around and picturesque. Enjoyed my stay here.

The deco of the hotel is retro look. Staff is friendly and most of them speaks English. Very beautiful garden. We booked two nights for a mini-suite for triple sharing. The room is about 37 sq M. very spacious! The additional bed is a proper wooden frame bed, we love it!There is a step above ground to the bath room, please take care if you get up in the middle of the night. The hotel provides pyjamas and toiletries are of good quality.We have breakfast at the lobby level cafe over looking the beautiful garden. We also went to level 40 for breakfast on the second day. The food on both locations is good, with wider selection at the lobby cafe. The hotel is accessible by two metro stations. If you plan to take a train to explore Tokyo, it is recommended to stay at Garden Tower as it is about 10 minutes walk to Akasaka-Mitsuke metro station Exit D (look for Marunnouchi line M13). There is evaluator and escalator from from the metro station to Exit D. If you suffer knee pain, we do not recommend you use Yotsuya station, which is across the road of the Garden Tower as it has many flights of stair cases to walk to the platform. From Shinjuku to the hotel, look for metro station Shinjuku-Sanctome M09 where there is elevator down to the platform. Overall, the hotel is value for money.

When staying in the New Otani Complex all the staff is available to you including concierge service solved many transportation issue with in Tokyo. I highly recommend this hotel; even close to (short walk) to a great selection of eating establishments.

Great location, really pleasant and clean rooms. Extraordinary staff. All of the staff are incredibly helpful and generous with their time and advice. I will always head to Hotel New Otani Tokyo Garden Tower, when i next travel to Tokyo.

Clean, tidy and friendly. However this once premium hotel is desperately in need of a refresh. Yellowed toilets and archaic electronic bedside tables turn this place into a Japanese museum. It’s a good location but I can’t help feel your money could go much further and get something more representative of Japan today

Stayed here as it was the official hotel for the Tokyo marathon. Nice rooms with comfortable beds. Plenty of room to spread out. Staff were really helpful and available all the time.Several places available for breakfast but queues could be long, particularly at the top of the tower.The Gardens are lovely

We had a chance to stay at both Otani the Main and the Garden Tower. The room size don't look different. Both are nice. Nice breakfast on the top floor (on a good clear day, you can see Mount Fuji view). Lobby is small.

Stayed there several times during Xmas and quite liked it, the rooms are spacious and loved the ensuite bathroom. Breakfast (not free, paid extra) had a great Japanese choice and the historic garden was amazing. The Chinese restaurant was great. The only hiccup was some suspicious noises sounded like hammering / renovation above our floor which woke me up at 3am. Thought it was supernatural initially. Rang the front desk but the manager came. The noise stopped after that so likely man-made !

Hotel is spacious for Tokyo. It has its own garden with waterfalls, which is great if you have time to stroll around. We didn’t have much. Only checked it out on the first day.Hotel has a confusing setup. There are numerous entrances. Two buildings connected by a walkway along the restaurant area. The check-in is at the main (old building) area. You then have to walk a long way to the other tower to take the elevator to your room. We stayed at the Garden Tower, which I find farther from the garden, but actually closer to the the subway, which is great. But you have to pass through what looks like an office building and exit to the street.By the way, something weird happened at the restaurant. We bought some pastries, which they did not allow us to eat because they said it’s only for take away. We bought it because we wanted to eat it!Overall, good value for Tokyo, but could do much better.

1. Spending one night in Tokyo due to work commitments. Most of the time staying at Hilto Tokyo.2. Hotel is about 30min from Haneda Airport yesterday. The traffic was light due to weekend.3. Hotel located near restaurant, train station & shopping complex. It all under one roof.4. I’m allocated on the 14 floor at Tower side. Room is decent in size & full with modern amenities, blend with wonderful Japanese decor. Compliments well. Limited viewing due to building on both side.5. Hotel staff are wonderful & friendly. All that I encountered, charm with Japanese Hospitality. Well done & kudos everyone.6. Walk about at hotel vicinity yesterday, it chilling and windy yesterday.7. Checkin Out in an hour time. Enjoy my short stay here. (View from my room).

Like for likes , and do not compare Hotel New Otani Tokyo with the super luxury hotels such as the Pen, the Ritz etc. (The latter ones charge at double to triple of the New Otani)And you get a hotel which over delivers or one that will not to disappoint given what one pays.New Otani does not boast any modern or contemporary design that Tokyo establishments have become so good at. The infrastructure and the door designs will remind you that this hotel has been around for a long time. It does Not mean however that they have not refurbished or re-decorated where it has been needed . (Eg clean and new enough curtains and carpet in our Deluxe room in the Main Tower. Eg , a not opulent but well-thought through bath room that comes with a “pretend” window that has Washi Paper on it that gives a nice touch ...). I saw some fotos of their new Shin-Edo rooms, which I reckon would be a success.What it does have, which few hotels in Tokyo or anywhere can rival, is space. In a metropolis like Tokyo, space is a huge luxury, just the size of its lift lobby will attest to it. & Many of the restaurants come with stunning views , we have enjoyed great breakfast spreads with Tokyo at our feet.Plus its famous garden which has been around hundreds of years .Add to that the myriad of shops (again, look through the throw back in times feel for the contents within), I felt as if being on a nice cruise with many many rooms and too many good restaurants to count . This hotel might work particularly well for big families or big groups who holiday together . Did I mention that the pricing is unbeatable ?

Big and clean room. All staff are courteous and efficient. Great view from the garden tower. I saw Mount Fuji from my room on a clear day! I especially like to option to switch breakfast for lunch (perfect for a Sunday!). There are many varieties of restaurants to choose from as well. I stayed in the Garden Tower and was lucky to get there from Akasaka-mitsuke subway station (so it's only a short walk). If I had gotten there via Yotsuya station, the walk would have been much longer. So, take note of which building you're staying in.

Stayed at the Garden Tower for 3 nights in Nov’17. I took the Airport Limousine directly to the hotel and was brought to the Main hotel reception to check-in. It was check-in time so there was a queue, but there are quite a number of staff attending to you. Front desk staff and bellhop were very helpful and speak good English. Advise would be to walk over to Garden Tower reception to avoid queue for checking in.We met a very unfriendly and not helpful housekeeping staff. We had 2 connecting rooms and bellhop offered to call housekeeping staff to unlock the connecting door. Staff came and did the job. We then asked him for extra towels, but had a difficult time communicating with him in English. My English is not fantastic but it’s my first language in school. I could not understand him at all. I tried to explain what we want again and tried to make out what he was saying. He became impatient and frustrated, and said rudely “Japanese or English, only 2”. This is the first time I’ve encounter such rude hotel staff after so many trips to Japan. I was really shocked at his behavior. In the end, I gave up and asked for my towels at the reception, and reception staff was great. Overall, a very nice hotel although there’s a lot of walking to do. Nice garden downstairs and great views from room. I was lucky enough to get a room with Mt Fuji view. Buffet breakfast was average, nothing to rave about. Location of the hotel is great, just a few minutes walk to Akasaka-mitsuke station. Lots of shopping and food options above train station. Nice shrine around the area, Hie Shrine. The hotel is also centrally located, just 4-5 stops away from Tokyo Station, Shinjuku or Shibuya. Possible to walk to Yotsuya JR station too, but a further walk.

Conveniently located in Chiyoda close to subway and plenty of dining options available nearby. Hotel is very big and connected to the New Otani main building. Staff attentive. Rooms dated. Room was very very hot - called down to fix and the staff fixed the heat immediately, but the next day the room was hot again. Rooms are a bit dated.

So comfortable. Very friendly helpful staff. Everything works and no tipping. Excellent restaurants to choose from actually on the premises. Great choice for breakfast. Lots of shopping opportunities and wonderful carpet

review_body: Very comfortable room, great views (from 17th floor) across Tokyo. Amazing choose at breakfast. Staff were exceptionally helpful and courteous. The hotel has a beautiful Japanese garden on the ground floor. Great rotating restaurant/bar on the top floor. Very good location for lots of interesting restaurants nearby and only a few stops on the metro to downtown Tokyo.

Corner room that had views from Mt Fuji all the way to the garden below and beyond. Inter-connecting room for 4 guests which made it very spacious.Great service, as originally booked non-smoking but one of the rooms was smoking, so the hotel moved us within 15 minutes. Amazing level of service, and professionalism.Even though it is getting old, the rooms are still well maintained, and very clean. Cannot hear other guests outside the door either which is a testament to the solid building.Went to Trader Vic's for some happy hour drinks and ribs- it's a throwback in a fun way as all the clientele seems to be 60year old salarymen in suits. Great cocktails.The other great thing about staying at the New Otani is the many restaurant options. Kyubei in main building is much better than Kyubei in the garden Tower.Complimentary parking too.

This is a good hotel at a nice location. The rooms are of reasonable size, beds comfortable, and the hotel staff is very helpful and courteous. The rooms are probably due for some polishing, but you should still have a pleasant stay here. We had a room with a view of the Tokyo Tower and a part of the city, and it was nice.For folks planning to use the metro, the Akasaka-Mitsuke station is a very short walk away. There's a number of restaurants in the hotel building itself as well as in the neighborhood. You won't go hungry!The large Japanese garden adjacent to the hotel building is very nice and idyllic. That's definitely an extra that most other hotels can't boast of.

Nice hotel in the centre of Tokyo - my wife and two kids felt very welcome here! Our rooms were slightly smaller in size than I expected but they were well cleaned at all times. The choice of restaurants in the hotel was impressive, although breakfast was incredibly expensive for a family of four. The hotel has a wonderful garden which we very much enjoyed. The level of service however is something I would like to commend more than anything - thank you for making our stay special with your attention!

The New Otani is definitely a hotel that caters mostly to business clientele. However, we stayed here over New Year period and the clientele certainly changed to include more families. I would say this Hotel is expensive and definitely geared towards a more mature crowd.You can see why this hotel attracts a more mature crowd as it is very traditional. There is literally staff everywhere to answer queries, assist you with the lifts, bookings etc.It does have that old world feel to it with the level of service they provide. A lovely touch was many of the staff were dressed in traditional Kimono for the NY period, whether this was an optional for staff or something Hotel management required I actually felt this was a nice nod to tradition. The shopping available again, is geared towards a more mature market however there is quite a lot on offer.The hotel complex is huge and you do get a workout walking throughout the hotel. We stayed in the Garden Tower on the 22nd floor, the view wasn't anything special however the room had a generous king sized bed, a large desk, and full length mirrors installed in the wardrobe. The bathroom room is a small but you can't really complain, the fittings are well maintained and very clean.They don't scrimp on providing toliteries either ( this is a pet peeve of mine, when you only get one set of tolietries to last you your stay). Clean robes are provided daily which is a lovely touch.The Hotel is a short walk to Asakasa-Mitsuke station so reaching shopping districts like Ginza and Shibuyu is quite easy. Asakasa-Mitsuke station has an information centre where you can purchase your Pasmo card from the friendly staff. Like most of Japan, the New Otani Tokyo is efficient and has exemplary service. On our last day, the Hotel kindly arranged for us to become members to th New Otani club so we could make use of the club lounge whilst we waited for our airport transfer which was late afternoon.The Restaurants are expensive so be prepared to spend some money if you prefer to eat in your meals in a Hotel setting. We visited the Tower Buffet for dinner one evening and although the views are lovely I found the service here one of the only places where service was a little slow. We enjoyed a New Year's Buffet at Trader Vic's and it was really really nice. This was all arranged at the last minute by Concierge. The beautiful 400 year old garden the Hotel is built around is great to experience both in the evening and daytime. Stay here for a bit of peace and quiet amongst the bustling Toyko.

We booked a room to take 3 adults at the Garden Tower. The room was a bit dated but super clean, comfortable and spacious for the 3 of us. The hotel has many restaurants and we had breakfast at the 40th floor of the tower with spectacular views of Tokyo and surroundings. This is our 3rd stay at the New Otani and will stay here again the next time. Excellent service all round. Excellent connection to the Tokyo underground train network at the Akasuka-Mitsuke station which is a short 5 minute walk away.

The New Otani is part of a very large complex of three towers that contain not only hotel rooms and convention space but offices, restaurants and shopping areas.The complex has multiple restaurants and many different types of food. We enjoyed the buffet breakfast all three mornings of our stay, once in the Garden Lounge and the other two mornings in the Tower Buffet up on the top floor. Both had expansive offerings of both Asian and Western cuisine. The Tower Buffet does open an hour earlier than the Garden Lounge.The rooms were an adequate size but not overly large. Our twin beds were a bit low to the ground but were comfortable enough. There was one nightstand between the two beds but at least it had electrical outlets.While there was a luggage stand, there really wasn't anywhere but the floor that I could open up my clamshell luggage and keep it open for our stay. Not sure what the answer is for that but this is not the only hotel where I've had that issue.The bathroom was large enough and had the electronic toilet features like I'd seen at the airport (though without the privacy button that played music like the airport toilet had!). By contrast the room's thermostat was not electronic but performed its function well enough. The A/C here did the best job of keeping the room cool during my entire Asian trip.Our room had a connecting door with our friend's but management must unlock the doors if you want to join the rooms.Our room was high enough to provide us with a lovely view of the area. An English-language newspaper was provided to us each day as well, which was nice. I was surprised to find fewer English-language TV channels than we'd had in China. Often I never turn the TV on when I travel but my roommate for this trip checked it out in every city we visited.The staff was terrific and very eager to assist, even going so far as having a staff member waiting outside the elevators in the lobby so they could push the UP button for us!In addition to all the restaurants in the hotel itself (on multiple levels) nearby is the Akasaka district which had loads of dining as well as shopping. We enjoyed just walking through the area and soaking up the sights, sounds and smells of the area.There's also a subway/train stop just outside the hotel which would make this a very convenient place to stay almost no matter where else in the city you went. The stop is about a five-minute walk from the closest hotel entrance but keep in mind it can take ten (or more) minutes from their to the proper elevator tower in the hotel, depending on which tower your room is in. It's a big complex and the map you receive at check-in is definitely helpful.If I ever come back to Tokyo I would be happy to stay here again!

This is about my third time at the New Otani. I came with my wife and son and got myself a triple room with three beds and a sitting room so we weren't tripping over ourselves during our stay. It's not every hotel that offers this type of accommodation.Besides the room, the service here is always attentive and courteous. There are also a great number of restaurants to choose from, both in the hotel and in the basement arcade.The only drawback of this hotel is its somewhat isolated location, something which is easily cured by a short walk to the nearest subway station Akasaka-Mitsuke. The Ginza line will quickly take you straight to the entertainment and shopping areas of the Ginza, Shibuya and Omotesando.

In a country justly renowned for grace and service, the New Otani takes the experience to a new height, and the Garden Tower in particular was delightful. The location is "perfect" -- ~2 km East of Tokyo main rail station. At breakfast in the 40th floor Buffet Room the views included sunrise (in December) to the East and sparkling Mt. Fuji to the West. The food was as diverse and satisfying as any I've enjoyed. Was there anything less than perfect -- well, go to Starbucks for real coffee ;-) But I promise -- you'll want the New Otani to be your only hotel.

It is generally hard to find bad service in Japan, but unfortunately the New Otani is terrible. You don’t want to have an issue here as they are not trained to handle complaints/issues in a professional manner and communications are difficult given limited English that is spoken. In an international hotel I do expect at least a subset of the staff to be able to communicate properly in English. You combine that with old infrastructure and I strongly recommend staying somewhere else. If you need to be in this neighborhood than stay across the street at the Princes Gallery. Before providing more color on my two main issues here are my other views: breakfast is okay but served in a great location on the top floor, the Japanese garden that is part of the property is wonderful, the voucher system for meals is archaic, the rooms are too small and the ceilings too low, location is good, subway close by, ...Service issue: I was supposed to have two connecting rooms as I was traveling with my family and we have young kids. I confirmed ahead of time and then again in person when I had arrived two days ahead of my family. In each instance I was told that was no problem. When my family arrived and we were supposed to switch to our connecting rooms they didn’t have them for us. They were unapologetic and for hours told me they didn’t have any solution and we had to live with it. I refused to accept this and ask to speak with ever more senior managers. At one point they offered a solution where, if I pay an additional couple thousand US dollars, they could organize a suite with connecting rooms in the main wing of the New Otani hotel. When I asked whether this was normal procedure to have their customers pay for the hotels mistake they told me yes and this was the only solution. It wasn’t until I demanded to speak to the GM and started moving my family to the Prince Gallery Hotel across the street did they find a solution for me (the Prince Gallery btw is an outstanding hotel)Infrastructure: this hotel was originally built in the 1960s for the Olympics, today the rooms are generally too small and the ceiling too low. They also haven’t invested enough in IT and so you have to use an old fashioned voucher system to access your various restaurant options. It all feels very dated.

Very good location in Akasaka with plenty, really plenty, restaurant choices. Wonderful garden and nice amenities, including small but well equipped gym. Normal rooms for Japanese standards. prices also within Japanese standard

After a stay of several nights at the New Otani Garden Tower, I have no hesitation in recommending this excellent hotel as an exceptional place to stay in Tokyo for both business and holiday travelers. My room was large and comfortable, with a number of amenities, including a climate control system that was easily operated from a convenient wall thermostat. The room featured a desk, chairs, a sofa, a fridge, a safe, tea makings with a hot water dispenser, and OK lighting, which was easily controlled from multiple locations but unfortunately didn't cover all parts of room. The quick and efficient housekeeping service provided two new complimentary bottles of water each day.The room offered ample drawer and closet space, where I found, among other amenities, a long-handled shoehorn, a whisk broom, and two sets of robes and slippers. The bed was quite comfortable and was adjacent to a handy control panel for clock, sound, and lighting. In-room wi-fi was included as were many channels of free TV that mostly offered Japanese language broadcasts, but I was able to find some English language news channels as well.The bathroom was excellent in every way, especially the bath and efficient shower, along with a high-tech Toto toilet offering multiple user options such as a heated seat. Very quick hot water was available at all hours. Bathroom amenities included an auxiliary phone, hairdryer, shower caps, body wash, and tooth brushes. In addition to the exceptional guest rooms, the New Otani boasts several high-quality restaurants. I enjoyed excellent buffet breakfasts with ample hot and cold choices in the top level of the Garden Tower complex (with a striking view of the Tokyo skyline) and at the Garden Lounge on the main corridor between the principal sections of the hotel. A Japanese breakfast was available at a restaurant on the first floor of the Garden Tower.I found the English-speaking front desk staff to be friendly and helpful, and I especially appreciated the quick action from the Garden Tower front desk on my only special request -- to open and reset the room safe that a previous occupant had left locked.Shops and recreational facilities in the hotel’s public areas are easily accessible. Very much worth visiting during your stay is the stunning centuries-old Japanese garden conveniently located near the Garden Lounge off the long corridor between the two principal areas of the property.I was quite happy with all aspects of the New Otani Garden Tower and would be very pleased to stay there again the next time I visit Tokyo. One caveat: The overall property’s two principal sections are spread out horizontally over a very large area, so bring your walking shoes if you want to explore its many impressive features, from the Main Section to the Garden Tower and everywhere in-between. And if you enter the property from the bus/taxi entrance to the Main, be sure to take the escalator up one level to the receiption area before navigating the long walk to the Garden Tower. It’s easy to get lost if you attempt to get there through the lower-level corridor.

My wife and I have stayed in a number of Tokyo hotels . The rooms are always tiny . Not in New Otani . Generous sized room , bigger than most hotel rooms in London .Everything you might need is supplied in bathroom ..shampoo ,razor ,toothbrush etc The rooms might seem expensive but shop around and you can get really good value .I would advise booking a few months in advance as quite a bit knocked off price.Also avoid Japan public holidays as prices shoot up .Before travelling well worth applying for New Otani club card via hotel site .Its a loyalty scheme ,doesnt cost anything but there are a number of benefits . Eg .we had 1000 yen off price of breakfast each morning . We arrived about an hour before check in time so whilst waiting the receptionist showed us to the club lounge (on 3rd floor) given coffee and cake ! Free bottled water , newspaper every day (in English ,Japan Times)The hotel is enormous ,many restaurants and shops . Apart from breakfast we didnt eat there as a bit too expensive .If you go out of Garden Tower exit (not main entrance , which is opposite end of hotel)turn right ,cross bridge ,(Nagatacho Station entrance is across road on left) go across zebra crossing you will come to street with a Wendys shop on corner.The street is full of places to eat and drink . We found a couple of good bars to drink in .Also directly opposite Garden Tower exit is big complex with places to eat or have coffee .Some people have complained of location but the station is only 3 minutes away . Use the Tokyo public transport app Hyperdia and you will easily find your way around .The highlight for most people at hotel is the traditional garden which is truly breathtakingly beautiful .When I have more time will put some photos on of it .Breakfast in the tower buffet restaurant is reasonablely priced and the view of the city is fantastic (40th floor) , Good variety but dont expect 'the full English' your in Tokyo . My main tip would be to use the Garden Tower exit when going out and about as the Main entrance is is a little bit away from Nagatacho station and the shops,bars in Akasaka .

Stayed here in the garden tower for 4 nights in early November, super large room with views of the city, good food,lots of in house shopping and restaurants, and a stunning Japanese garden. Well situated near metro stops.

Recommend this hotel as a place to stay for your visit to Tokyo. Close to metro and many, many restaurants and bars. The hotel is in the Akasaka area of Tokyo and offers you a good base for exploring the city. Walking is safe in this area and there are many small roads with a great selection of eateries (tapas, Portuguese, French, Chinese, Starbucks, KFC and tradition sushi)

The staff here were so charming and well organised. The rooms were comfortable and enough lifts so there was never much of a wait. Great range of body washes and facial lotions and personal items in the bathroom. Kettle and tea bags in the room but we found Japanese hotels tend not to leave milk capsules so we bought fresh and stored it in mini bar. Plenty of dining options, we tried the international buffet in the revolving restaurant and the breakfast buffet on 40th floor. Not cheap but food of a good standard and lots of choice. For light breakfast / snack we tried Tulleys coffee shop in Garden Court block and just next to that there is a convenience store for other snacks and we could use the ATM in there with our visa debit to obtain Yen. Visit the Japanese garden for a bit of fresh air when the sun is out.

The Hotel New Otani comprises three buildings: the original hotel that was built for the Tokyo Olympics in 1964 which is now called the Main, the Garden Tower and the the Garden Court. All three buildings are inter-connected. We stayed at the Garden Tower on the 37th floor with incredible views. One of the breakfast areas is on the 40th floor, but you have the choice of eating at several more restaurants in the hotels. Our room was quite spacious with a living and sleeping area, a walk-in closet and a very large bathroom with shower, tub and two wash-basins. It also has a writing desk, several chairs, arm-chairs and a sofa. Of course there is a flatscreen TV set, free WiFi and tea and coffee-making facilities.The landscaped park which goes back 400 years is home to ponds with koi, an artificial waterfall and several restaurants. Take a stroll through this garden and you'll forget that you are in Tokyo, a city of 35 million inhabitants.If you don't feel like having all your meals in the hotel, it's a 5-minute-walk to Akasaka-mitsuke where you'll find many restaurants, cafés or bars.

The hotel has a great location. It's near by metro station and there are many restaurants around.The room is good, comfortable and clean.You have many options to have breakfast in their different restaurants inside of the hotel. The best one is in the restaurant that you can see the beautiful and peaceful Japanese garden. Oriental and ocidental breakfast are available.Spend some minutes walking in the garden. It's really beautiful!Staff are really kind and can speak well English.

Firstly although the hotel is located in the centre of the city, it's a long way off the property to a nearby train station. Breakfast times there were always long lines waiting regardless of the time. Food was ok not a huge selection. Staff were ok. Not bad but not good. Just average. If I was to stay in this area again I wouldn't stay here but I'd choose something that doesn't feel so isolated and huge.

I stayed here with my partner for one night in September and only wished we could've stayed longer! On arrival we were offered a room upgrade and stayed in the Duke suite which is on the c. 40th floor. The suite was out of this world (especially the views - where you could see the whole city, even out to Mount Fuji!), made all the more enjoyable by the kind gesture of the hotel.The staff are very friendly and attentive and the hotel is very well placed for getting around Tokyo (we were able to walk to Ginza and out East from there).As many others have written the gardens are absolutely wonderful and a credit to the landscaping/gardening team at the hotel. We would definitely stay again!

We greatly enjoyed our stay. The hotel was beautiful and the room was very comfortable and nicely appointed. We also had a great view. The breakfast buffet was wonderful. The garden is amazing. An added plus is that the hotel is next to a major metro line.

We stayed on the 15th floor and the room was comfortable and clean. We did not have the best view and the furniture was a bit dated. Breakfast on the 40th floor had a great view over the garden and the city. The buffet breakfast was reasonable, but the bacon was always cold. All the staff were very courteous and attentive. The Japanese garden was beautiful.

This is a well located hotel, everything is close: The subway, nice local places to lunch or dine, museums, etc. The staff is very friendly and everyone is looking for a way to help you.The rooms are very big for Japanese standards, and also with nice amenities and spectacular views of the city or the garden.The food in the restaurants is very good, they offer a mix between traditional Japanese food and classic western food.If you are taking tours, they also offer several options and the buses for the main tours stop directly at the hotel, very convenient. I strongly recommend this place if you want to have a nice and quiet relaxation after a full day of visiting places or doing business.

I stayed there for about a week during a business trip and it was a good hotel to stay.It has good breakfast options, a business center with some services, good concierge service and they care about their customers.You can have a good view from the bar or a restaurant on the 40th floor and visiting the hotel garden is a must - you will enjoy your walk through authentic japanese garden with waterfalls and if you are lucky enough you might see some guys doing wedding pictures is Japanese traditional dress, an exciting bonus!Well, there are a lot of shops in the hotels, almost 3 floors of and you can also rent and dress in those costume yourself but the price is about 80 000 yen. Also, almost all the shops accept cash only(((((((((( in yen of course ( that was really not convenient at all.I also used concerge service for finding some places in Tokyo and nearby and they did help me very much, I really appreciate it. I Also used business rooms for meetings with some catering and it was also a pleasant experience, kudos go to the business center guys too.The only thing was that I was changing the room at the hotel during my stay because my booking was too late and downgrading your room is always bad, like the rooms at the 29 floor were good while the rooms at the 17floor are still good but when your neighbours are taking shower or bath you can hear the water going down in pipes, that was the only thing i hated.A place worth staying, also if you need 24hour printing, brouchiring and more - there is a 24 hour Kaitos or smth like that near Starbucks just across a street

The hotel was very good.It had many Laurie in the rooms,they were spacious and comfortable. It was very well staffed with courteous and helpful people.We had long queues for breakfast but all three had magnificent views of either the sky line or a beautiful Japanese garden.The garden was well worth going into with great pools with Koi carp. A real asset!The only negative was that the hotel is huge and it is a long way to walk down the endless corridors to get to your room.

We stayed at the New Otani Hotel for four nights recently during a tour of the south of Japan.The hotel is vast but the rooms and amenities are easily accessed by lifts and escalators.Very central to shopping and restaurants,the gardens are a must to see so peaceful and beautiful. The view from the restaurant on the 40th floor was amazing.I really enjoyed my stay there.

We drove there, the underground car park is big and free. But we really struggled to find our way to reception through the mass of shops!Hotel is HUGE! Load of people everywhere! Lots of shops! We only ate in the Garden restaurant which was really good, western options at lunch were great.Swimming pool is free is you sign up to their free rewards club, but in reality wasn't worth visiting as busy and not that great.On arrival at the room the curtains were closed I think this is to add drama which it does, the view was amazing from the tower over the Japanese garden to the city!Although trip advisor lists the two hotels as separate they are completely linked you almost wouldn't notice! Room had a bath which was nice after a 12hr flight! Hotel does feel a bit isolated form the main city cost us 17000JPY for taxi to Roppongi

The Hotel and the garden are amazing and it is outstanding in complete Tokyo.The view of the higher floors is fantastic. The bar and the breakfast in the highest floor of the main building give you so beautiful impressions and topple everything.Thanks for the always friendly and lovely stay, I will come back again.

This is a large property with 2 buildings. We stayed in the Garden Tower. Our room was good size, modern, clean. Although in a busy area, room was completely quiet. TV had CNN in English. Ice machine on the floor. Had breakfast buffet, available with Western style or Japanese, many choices, very good preparation. No complaints.

We asked for a non smoking room and were given a room on a smoking floor it was dreadful. They moved us to another room but there was still a smell of smoke and our clothes smelled dreadful. We ordered food in the Italian restaurant it was inedible and we sent it back and ate outside of the hotel, Breakfast was varied but pretty ordinary. The use of the pool cost extra.

This was my 2nd stay at this hotel. It is conveniently located near the subway station, staff is very friendly and helpful. The breakfast is good. I liked the garden view very much. I would return to this hotel.

I stayed here on business last month for 4 nights. I have also stayed here previous years. The location suits me very well as it's close to work as well as having many restaurants and bars within walking distance. The gardens attached are magnificent if that is your thing. I had breakfast daily on the top floor of the tower which has a 360 degree view of the city. Very impressive. I have tried other hotels in Tokyo but I keep coming back to this one.

With great anticipation, we spent 3 nights at the Ortani Garden Tower in Tokyo, before continuing on a transpacific cruise back to Vancouver. The hotel was built in the '60's , so it needs some remodeling. The buffet breakfasts were good, and help you through the day until dinner time. Tokyo is an expensive city , so be prepared. The Ortani has free bottled water, great bathroom toiletries < shampoo , conditioner, soap, bath gel, comb, cotton swabs, brushes, shaver and cream, gargle, toothbrush and paste, and shower cap. You can leave these items home, and use that space for goodies to bring home. There is even a kimono for your use. There are stores for buying needed forgotten items. The room is pretty good sized, with bed, chairs, sofa, and table. Ask for a view of the beautiful waterfalls and Japanese gardens. A pretty good place, especially if part of your vacation package.

The Hotel New Otani harkens back to the 1970s with its decor but the rooms are large by Tokyo standards. Japanese service is always excellent and the concierge managed to get us reservations into a number of hard-to-get-into restaurants.The gardens, needless to say, are most beautiful especially during the sakura season, which is when we visited.Very well situated to the metro system too. Most convenient. We'll definitely stay here again when we visit Tokyo.

We enjoy the New Otani for the outdoor pool. Even though it was mainly cool (for a Japanese summer) and rainy during our stay, we went swimming everyday. My kids actually preferred the rainy days to the sunny days BECAUSE there was no-one in the pool on the rainy days. Outside was cool/ cold with the rain---but the water is lovely and warm. The rooms were lovely and breakfast nice.Service great.

Decent size rooms and while the hotel is relatively old, the rooms seem to be renovated. Well connected by Tokyo an underground station quite nearby which is on one of the many train lines in Tokyo. Not in the busiest portion of Tokyo but well connected to the airports and bus pick up point for Tokyo sight seeing tours. Have not seen other hotels in Tokyo but pricing seems to be mid - to high range.

If you want to visit Tokyo this is a great hotel to do so. Very close to main metro line, great view from top floor bar, clean and large rooms, lots of restaurants at the metro station, not too far from Royal Palace, Ropongi, Mejii, Harajuku, Shibuya...)

The New Otani Garden is a beautiful building, with two towers, with a lot of stores and restaurants inside.It is very well located, close to busy streets and a metro station. Rooms are spacious, the bed is huge and comfortable. The staff is as friendly as it gets. Breakfast is served at three different locations in the building, we only tried the restaurant on the 40th floor and could not recommend it more; not only the views are amazing but the food and variety is great.

It was a great stay. One of the best stay in Japan. This hotel is old but well maintained. Their garden is worth visiting if you are keen to Japanese garden. Hotel staff is very friendly and helpful. Room is very clean and comfortable. We had breakfast at the main and it was superb!!! We really enjoyed staying there. We would love to come back.

The hotel consisted of two large towers, several restaurants and a host of shops. The grounds contained a Japanese Garden that was immaculate. There was also an outdoor swimming pool though there appeared to be a cost to use this facility.I have never seen as many staff willing to help in a hotel before, nothing was to much trouble.It took a while to get orientated with numerous elevators, exits and corridors.Breakfast was served on the 40th floor of the tower, giving commanding views over the city.Food and drink wasn't cheap, but it was very good quality.

Our room was a great size, with a bath and shower.The bed was very comfortable as well. We enjoyed views over the traditional Japanese gardens underneath, as well as a glimpse of the outdoor pool.All of the staff were very friendly, and spoke English too.There were also a variety of stores on the ground level to peruse.The hotel is also within close walking distance to the Subway station.

This was our first time staying at the New Otani Hotel. we thoroughly enjoyed our stay. The Hotel was beautiful, clean, and centrally located. Most impressive was the terrific level of service from the staff . Their willingness to help and make my stay wonderful was exemplary. I would highly recommend staying at this hotel.

The positives- excellent location in akasaka mitsuke. The garden tower entrance is a 3 minute walk from exit D of akasaka mitsuke station. Behind the metro station are several lanes of bars, restaurants, shops. Great food options. Easy access to airport (airport limousine bus stops at the hotel) whereas keisei skyliner you have to take the metro and walk far- a bit of a hassle if you don't know where you are going. The hotel has a beautiful 400 year old traditional Japanese garden. The staff are very helpful and friendly and speak English very well. On our last morning we had a great view of mt Fuji in the distance. The negatives- we had to complain 3 times that our aircon was not cold enough. Themostat might have been broken but actual room temp was basically 25degrees Celsius but aircon was at lowest setting. Got uncomfortably warm every night. They replaced a filter and did other stuff but it was never cold. We were 2 adults and 2 kids, they knew to bring extra towels once we checked in- but every day after housekeeping always forgot. We would have to call every day for 2 extra towels. Upon check out- found out our kid had accidentally watched 5 minutes of a pay per view children's movie - since there are no TV channels in English... everything is dubbed in Japanese. It was not very clear on the screen that this movie would cost us 1600yen (8USD). I was shocked at the price- and annoyed since he only watched it for 5 minutes. Despite their apologies for the aircon issues- they didn't make any effort for service recovery. I should have insisted they reverse the charge for the movie but we were late for the airport and had to leave. So, after a nice visit in Tokyo we left with a somewhat negative impression of the hotel.

Our family love this hotel for decades and we stay here every time we came back to Tokyo. They have a exceptional service and it is located in a very convenient area in Akasaka. They have a beautiful garden that has a millennial history and you can't imagine that you are in the middle of Tokyo!

We've stayed at Hotel New Otani (in The Main) before, but we're new to the Garden Tower. Our room was on the 30th floor with a view of the garden, Akasaka palace and city - truly a breathtaking view. We always find the staff at this hotel to be extremely helpful, polite and genuine. We requested a non-smoking room, and it was confirmed at check-in that we were on a non-smoking floor. Sadly, someone had done quite a lot of smoking in there. When we told the front desk, they said they would take care of it while we were at dinner. On our return, we found a spray bottle of deodorizer. Not exactly how we thought the problem would be resolved. Our room had a king bed and was clean and comfortable, but the air conditioning was inadequate. It averaged 75 degrees, running full blast with the curtains closed during the day, yet the hotel has a plush down comforter on the bed in the heat of summer with no top sheet. The best part of staying at this hotel is the 400 year old garden. It is spectacular, and we enjoyed walking in it and gazing at it from our room and at breakfast. Breakfast in the restaurant overlooking the garden was a highlight of our days, and the buffet selection was excellent with great coffee. Try the sesame salad dressing - it's delicious. It's sold in the hotel, but it took consulting several helpful employees in order for us to find the shop it's sold in. That's mostly because this is a massive property. Taking the airport bus back to Narita, the staff stood outside and waved to those on the bus. I thought this was more of the friendliness that we've come to love in Japan, but when the bus stopped at other hotels to pick up passengers, nobody waved goodbye. It sounds trivial, but that last experience best describes the warmth one experiences while staying at the New Otani. Are there more modern, more luxe properties? No doubt. But the personable service and the incredible garden are why we keep returning.

We stayed in the Garden Tower which was booked by our cruise line. I imagine the area of suites would be absolutely wonderful, in one of the other areas of the hotel, but our room was small, though perfectly fine and clean. I think if we had not come from a bedroom suite at the Fairmont Peace Hotel in Shanghai, we would have been more satisfied. But I can't say enough about the staff, and the people in general. So helpful, polite and eager to please. We could not have been happier with the concierges throughout the hotel who helped us immeasurably by guiding us in the process of shipping our large luggage on to Nikko Narita, so we could happily travel to Kyoto and environs for five days without lugging the unneeded larger bags. They made it painless and did so happily. The shops and restaurants could keep you satisfied if you never left the hotel!

Comfortable but small rooms. Tasty breakfast and beautiful garden. Hotel not part of Western hotel group so you get a Japanese experience. Locals recommended it to me. I have stayed a few times. Hotel is quiet and relaxing. No bar scene of some of the other Tokyo hotels. Feels like a more traditional Japanese stay if that is what you are looking for.

A huge hotel with great facilites. We had a suite and it was spacious and clean with all the amenities needed for a comfortable stay. As in most big hotels, the restaurants and bars were very pricey but if you are prepared to walk and look there are lots of options. We found a Tullys coffee shop near and this was great for a quick, light breakfast. Whilst the staff seem friendly enough, this place can feel impersonal but that is the nature of this style of hotel. The garden in the complex is spectacular. From our room on the 36th floor we could see the Tokyo Tower, the Skytree and on a clear day, if you craned you head around the corner, Mt Fuji!

The Hotel is well organized, the staff is extremely kind, the rooms clean and spacious... but there is no one sitting room or living room: only reception, lift and rooms, many corridors and the famous garden outside, like a post card that you can see out the big glasses. No life, no atmosphere. I don't recommend you, You can only sleep, or dine, if you agree the high prices... Gianni di Bologna

One of the nicest hotels I have stayed in. Very clean and spacious room, helpful staff good laundry and good food. Bars a little expensive but very pleasant. Garden breakfast buffet was superb. Will use again for certain

We stayed in the Garden Tower, a corner room which had great views. Very comfortable bed and all amenities for tea and coffee and nice bathroom. The hotel is large with shops and several restaurants but the staff are kind and very helpful. The roof top bar is excellent at night for the lights and views, but rather expensive, gin and tonic $25 each!!!!!!!! Breakfast a disappointment as there was no chef to prepare fresh cooked eggs and the scrambled eggs were dreadful, poured out of a plastic bag and dry on the hotplate. Crispy bacon never works because they cover it up with a lid so it is horrible, limp and chewy. A varied buffet mostly catering for Asian tastes. We tried the two different restaurants one on ground floor level and the other at the top of the hotel but they were both bad for breakfast quality.The Tempura restaurant was excellent and very authentic.The hotel is situated nicely for access to the underground train system which works well to get around the city and also for walking to the local restaurants and shops. We enjoyed our stay here.

Stayed 4 nights in the Garden Tower - lovely big room on the 34th floor with magnificent views over Tokyo, including the Imperial Guest House. The biggest surprise was tea/coffee making facilities plus a good range of toiletries and items such as a hairbrush, toothbrush etc. The bed was huge and very comfortable. We ate breakfast every morning in the restaurant on the 40th floor, again with beautiful views all round. A good range of food for breakfast, except for the fruit which was all tinned. Coffee better than we have had in other hotels. The only downside in the hotel was the high cost of drinks and meals in the restaurants. However, there is a wide range of other restaurants and eating places within a few minutes walk of the hotel. The metro is also very handy. The garden is absolutely exquisite and beautifully maintained. Well worth spending some time in it. this is probably the largest hotel we have ever stayed in, but once you get used to the system of lifts and escalators, it's fairly easy to find your way around.

The Hotel New Otani in Tokyo is an excellent hotel. It is huge, and has several restaurants. The gardens are superb, the revolving restaurant is excellent. It is close to other places in Chiyoda - restaurants, shops, bars and clubs etc.

We stayed here for four nights in May on a Riviera tour of Japan. The Garden Tower is the more downmarket part of this huge hotel complex but still excellent. Much recommended. Central location, helpful staff, good (pricey) restaurants and shops.

Recently stayed for 2 nights with an upgrade to a beautiful room in the Garden Tower. Excellent service from all the employees who were constantly smiling which made you smile as well. Dining was quite expensive but good choice of venues.The garden was stunning, so many shades of green and restful sound of water.From our experience would recommend.

Located in the business district, The New Otani Hotel is one of the best hotel we have visited. We stayed here for 3 nights. The staff is the best. Always smiling and helping out. We never saw an employee that looked like they didn't like their job. Modest size room, squeaky clean, with a great view from the 24th floor. The hotel has several pricey restaurants. Our stay included breakfast. We found a Wendy's two blocks away. The Japanese Garden is beautiful. There is a large pool on the ground, but guests have to pay a fee to use it. Shopping is 2 block away. The Wi-Fi is fast and free.

The New Otani Garden Tower is located super-conveniently in the center of Tokyo, just minutes on foot from a Metro station served by 5 different lines and hence a perfect base for exploring Tokyo and also getting to the different train stations.The Hotel itself is located in a traditional Japanese garden, which offers an oasis of calm and beauty in the middle of a large skyscraper city.The room in the Garden Tower was spacious and well equipped. Although some of the interior might be slightly outdated regarding modern criteria, it gives the place a feel of authenticity and soul. Everything is absolutely well-maintained and nothing looks tired or worn.The view from the room on clear days offering a view of the garden, the surrounding city scape and Mount Fuji as well, was very impressive.The breakfast served in the Tower restaurant had a wide variety of choices and was of very good quality. Unfortunately the choice and service from the restaurants during day service was not as good, as during breakfast times. The simple request for a vegetarian meal (for some strange reason they put meat into the vegetable quiche), was answered by a “We can’t change anything on the menu” and “You could have a Caesar’s salad”. A Caesar’s salad is by definition not a vegetarian option. I was very disappointed by this attitude of service/kitchen staff.The New Otani also has a very nice outdoor pool, which is a real asset for the hotel. Entrance fees (strange enough that they exist for hotel guests), are waivered if you sign up for the New Otani guest relations card. Unfortunately the opening times of the pool are strange. It only opens during Golden Week and in July and August and then opening times are limited to 9:00 to 16:30. I witnessed twice that they closed down the pool at 16:30 sharp, even though it was still packed with people. I personally would have loved to take a dip in the early evening after exploring the city.Overall the New Otani was a great choice for exploring Tokyo, however service levels especially in the restaurants was slightly disappointing.

I used to wonder whether are there any hotels in this big city that has large room but reasonable price ? Yes , this hotel is the answer . Somehow I do not know what is the differnce between room types , but I could see Fujisan from my room window . The hotel itself has a beautiful big garden and there is another public garden nearby too . A shrine is near and easy to walk to also . A big store selling a lot of IT things is just 2-300 meters away .

Tokyo hotels are expensive but if you want to find a reasonable hotel, centrally located with great service, I can highly recommend this hotel. It is even less expensive than the main hotel. Rooms are not big but adequate. The service is one of the best and if you get out of the tower entrance, one can easily walk to the subway Akasaka Mitsuke and from there to anywhere in Tokyo with good transfer capabilities. I would first recommend going to Asakusa, a popular tourist spot. All signs are in English and train announcements are also repeated in English. Once you get a hang of it, you'll do well.

Was here for 3 days prior to a cruise. This is a very large hotel but very efficient and clean. Staff are helpful and polite. Only ate here once - a bar snack - the prices are outrageous. There are many placed to eat nearby and the concierge will give you a local map showing them. If you are taking a bus tour be aware that the tour buses are reached via an escalator down from the main lobby. The gardens of the hotel are very pleasant and worth walking round.

During my stay last month at the Garden Tower, I lost my bracelet and apple accessories. Your housekeeping dept answered my email promptly. Many thanks to your Lost and Found dept for the tracing and safekeeping of the bracelet esp when it was lost it in the public area. Many thanks to your room division (housekeeping) for searching the lost items and the subsequent arrangement of the picking-up. Once again, thank you for the great service!!

After checking in we realized that although we ordered a room with one double bed we received a twin bed room. I went down to the lobby but after a long waiting time they informed that the hotel is fully booked and we can get a double room only two days later. The room was large but too hot, the air condition didn't work and the windows don't open. when I complained they said the air condition doesn't work at winter time (it was late April), strangely enough it was working the next day. The bed was too soft, and the whole room felt old. Only two electric outlets in the room with many extension cables connected to them, unaesthetic and unsafe. On the other hand the Japanese garden is beautiful and the view from the breakfast restaurant on the 45th floor is very nice.

1. I'm in Tokyo again. This time for a night. Staying at different hotel. New Otani Tokyo Garden.2. It surrounded with a lot of amenities. Restaurant, Boat Ride & Shopping Centre. The room assign to me facing Garden. Beautiful.3. As per normal, wonderful hotel staff with Japanese Hospitality. They politely, warm & welcoming. Always amaze with Japanese Culture.4. Hotel is about 30min bus ride from Haneda Airport & traffic was light as this week is golden week. A lot of holiday.5. My room is decent in size with full modern facilities and Japanese design.6. Short stay, but always happy to win Tokyo.

We had originally booked in the main, but were i guess upgraded to the Garden Tower on arrival. The room was very comfortable, plenty of space and very clean. I will say the AC did not get very cold, it may have not been turned on as it was still cool out, and this wasnt a deal breaker, I just tend to like it really cold at night since hotel covers tend to be on the warm side. The bed was a thinner mattress than I am used to, again not a deal breaker I know my preference for pillow top mattresses wont be met everywhere. and the beds were plenty comfortable. The room was two twin beds, slightly larger than I would say a US twin bed is, and perfect for us in sharing the room. Since we were there at Cherry Blossom time the room had some special extras, that I do not think are there year round, but could be. We had some bath soaks left for us each night with Cherry Blossom scents, and they are awesome. I packed the ones we did not use to take home and use, cause they were amazing. The cleaning staff were great, we left the do not disturb up one day since we had hand washed some laundry ( long trip, short on packing space) and we didnt want they cleaning around it, so they called us at night to see if we needed turn down or fresh sheets/ towels since they had marked the room as un- serviced. The breakfast included with our stay was good, but the restaurant was over crowded each day and if you did not arrive early enough there seemed to be quite the line. Despite the line we did have very friendly service, food was refilled on the buffet quickly and we never had to wait to long for our tea and coffee at the table. The location was quite close to a metro stop, so it was easy to get around the city, and the taxi drivers we used all knew exactly where to take us, even if they had limited english. We did carry a card with the hotel name in Japaneses to help us get around, always a good idea when traveling.

We were looking for an affordable hotel in Tokyo, and we found it! This hotel is huge and the rooms are a great size - very authentic. There are so many restaurants and they do this great high-tea every day. But the best part are the gardens and I was lucky enough to be there during Cherry Blossom season. If you're looking for an affordable hotel in Tokyo, this is the place!

We stayed at the New Otani Tower as part of a Riviera Tour Group therefore the hotel was chosen for us. As many have said the furniture is from the 1960's when the hotel was used as a base for the Olympic Games, however it was a well maintained room, adequate in size with excellent service from all staff. At first sight it can be daunting because of the size but you quickly understand the layout. Food in the hotel is ridiculously expensive but numerous reasonable priced restaurants are within 5 minutes walk. The formal gardens in the hotel grounds are well worth a visit

This is a huge hotel. So many floors to explore. But the best of all is a Japanese garden just at your doorstep. That was enjoyable indeed.The staff was friendly and efficient. Most of them could speak English.The hotel itself was beautiful and I enjoyed the art scattered all throughout. The restaurants within the hotel were all great and for sure, we will stay here again when in Japan. I have to note as well that it was pleasing that there was a Christian chapel within the garden, with a designated pastor. Thanks Mr Otani for including this in your beautiful hotel.The only comment i have is that each night we wanted to have some in room dessert but there were not a lot of choices in your in-room menu.

3 stars for the location, the garden and the view.. other than that I found it below the expectations service is less than what you usually see in TokyoBed is not comfortable at allBath room is oldThe lobby for the garden tower looks like a two stars hotel lobby

A lovely hotel which has a lovely shopping arcade on its sixth floor. It has lovely large-sized rooms, excellent breakfast and very courteous staff. Breakfast is available on the 6th floor as also on the 40th floor. The 6th floor restaurant overlooks a lovely Japanese garden which belongs to the hotel itself. This garden is the USP of the hotel besides the other being of the location. The hotel is located at a stone's throw away from the Japanese DIET. All in all, a hotel I would use again for my groups - it is value for money !

Great views and experience. Property very well kept and staff very proper. Hotel a bit too stuffy for my taste and slightly pretentious. I prefer quick and efficient interactions with the front desk that are meaningful. My bags transferred through 3 sets of hands and about 15 minutes, just to get to my room, all the while insisting I would be fine to handle my own bags. Great selections for food and drink. Surrounding places nearby offers nice options off site.

This hotel is part of the New Otani compound at the heart of Tokyo surrounded by beautiful, expansive Japanese gardens-- a great treat in a concrete city. Room are on floors 22 to 40 of the tower / lobby is on 6th floor. The views from the room are great with Tokyo skyline and views of the imperial gardens. Room are a bit bland and windows oddly smaller that expected but still lending great views. Bathrooms old fashioned but convenient, and Shiseido product offered.Convenient location at Akaska Misuke. Some 100m to subway.

We have stayed here twice and we love it, big room , great breakfast , the most amazingly beautiful garden no matter what time of year and super friendly and helpful staff, we stayed here in late march and see the garden, I highly recommend it !

When searching for a typical tourist hotel in Tokyo, with land at a premium, the main theme for a room is 'small'. Not so at the New Otani. Travelling with our daughter we booked 2 rooms and were given a suite, located on one corner of the building, with views in two directions. Some reviews refer to rooms as dated, that was certainly not my opinion for our room. The hotel itself is huge, consisting of two wings linked by a walkway used for retail outlets and a restaurant, overlooking the beautiful Japanese dating back 400 years. During our visit the outside pool was not in use, possibly as a result of an earlier event for which equipment was being cleared away. With a metro station located 10 mins walk away, numerous restaurants and a shopping area nearby, it is well located to explore the city. Good choice!

The New Otani Hotel is one of the older landmarks in the hotel scene of Tokyo. Compared to the new modern stars of Tokyo's vibrant and top class hotel scenery, it can't compete with the amenities of the newer and more fashionable hotels of the big international chains. It's location close to the thriving Akasaka district and in the proximity of the Imperial Gardens, which are an oasis of green in the mega city of Tokyo, make it a good place for getting around town. The New Otani has it's very own zen-garden including a small lake or rather a pond full of koi fish. The garden is the outdoor connection between the two main buildings of the hotel. One can also use the sunlit gallery to traverse from one building to the other. The gallery is also the location of the main buffet restaurant overlooking the garden with it's massive glass front. The rooms are rather small and a bit dated but offer enough comfort for most business travellers. At first the New Otani does not feel like something special but once you notice the details of the design, the setting, the garden the bar at the main building one can imagine that this place must have had its glory days when it was younger. Wondering around the premises it almost feels like seeing a beautiful but old woman who aged in grace. One can imagine how strikingly beautiful she was when she was younger and she still has not lost her attraction albeit the shine is somewhat dimmer. Would I recommend it? Yes. Would I come back? If I had the choice between the New Otani and some of its pricey, younger competitors I would probably chose the latter just because Tokyo is the place, where you expect to be in a modern, urban environment sort of glass and glitter and steel and the future.... On a sunny day go to the restaurant at the top floor of the Garden Tower to see incredible views of Mount Fuji. This is breathtaking and one of the many hidden charms of this grand old dame of Tokyo.

Located in the plush neighborhood of Akasaka, Hotel New Otani is a significant statement in Tokyo's high end hotels. The view from their restaurant (Garden Lounge) is to die for. Just take a walk in their Japanese garden (yes, there's a big one inside the hotel) and it'll make your day. The rooms are tastefully decored, and while the hospitality could do with some upgrade, they were efficient in a way most Japanese are. Thoroughly enjoyed my stay therein.

Stayed here for a week in December, 2016 for a business trip. The room was clean and comfortable, if a bit dated, and the bed was very comfortable for a hotel bed. The breakfast buffet was excellent, but expensive. However this hotel complex is very large with multiple attached malls, and there was both a coffee shop and a Japanese convenience store located downstairs for cheaper options. The location is good in central Tokyo. I would definitely stay again.

It is cold in Tokyo & I am warm & cozy inside this excellent property which sprawls a great area. It ticks all the right boxes for me. It has shopping,a Japanese garden & restaurants too. To sum it up I recommend this place.

We stayed 4 nights in a triple room. This hotel is extremely large. The garden are beautiful and definitely the highlight of the hotel. Check in was efficient and friendly. Room was spacious for Japanese standard. Everything was functional and clean but dated. This hotel is in the business area and is close of the underground. There is a swimming pool but you have to pay to get in but if you join their loyalty scheme you can get in for free. Staff was friendly and extremely polite. Everything during our stay was satisfactory but I doubt we will return again. I feel there are better places to stay.

Huge hotel, still the real Japan. Well located in Tokyo. Rooms (I had again a corner room) are good, well issolated and very decent beds. Restaurants are good, breakfast can be somewhat messy (40th floor). What really surprises me is that in ordet to take a swim in The SPa you need to pay 50 USD (5000 yen) as you need to buy a membership before entering. That's not what I would expect they would demand from a (loyal) hotel guest in this price range.

The new Otani Garden Tower hotel is a typical well managed business hotel. For Tokyo perspectives the rooms are really huge, furniture design is rather old and could do refresh, but rooms are clean and tidy.Hotel features several restaurants and bars which are even for Tokyo style rather overpriced. Breakfast at tower restaurant might feature view on Mount Fuji but still to expensive.If you have business to do in Chiyuda it is still a great place.

This hotel has the best service. From the time we stepped off the shuttle staff was there to assist with luggage and to direct you to registration. Every staff I met was very professional, friendly and helpful. The hotel is in a great location, in walking distance to two subway lines, stores, restaurants and Sophia University. The area is scenic and a joy to just walk around. The hotel has a Japanese Garden on property that is beautiful; you will visit it more than once. The waterfall is breathtaking and is a great backdrop for pictures. The room in the hotel was clean and spacious, however, it did not live up to expectation. When you enter the beautiful, well decorated lobby with upscale stores as you walk to your room, you expect so much more. Room service is quick and the food is good. Tully's is on property and an excellent place to unwind and enjoy a cup of coffee. Do try the strawberry doughnut-Delicious and the mint iced tea was refreshing. If you need a manicure ask for Okuda in the nail salon, you won't be disappointed. There is a Family Mart, similar to 7 eleven, with an ATM.

I organized a conference at this hotel. Property was nice, but not outstanding or memorable. Staff and service was quite positive and at times outstanding. However, the facilities were just good with little to make it stand out, certainly a surprise based on the $$$$ we were spending in this location. the accommodations were roomy and comfortable as one would expect from a superior business hotel located in a tier one city. But it did feel like something was missing and i cant quite identify what it was.....?

I always stay in the New Otani hotel when I am visiting Tokyo for business. The hotel is close to the Ginza and Marunouchi subway lines in Tokyo and also close to the Akasaka district with many restaurants and shops. The hotel itself has an excellent service and some nices places to have dinner with your business guest. Our company also histed a couple of seminars their which were a big success.

I've stayed here before and will stay again due to the location, friendly staff and large rooms. We had to move rooms as the first room had a smoking smell but within an hour we had a room which was much better and a view of Mount Fuji. All the staff are very welcoming and the grounds are immaculate. Close to 2 metro stations and a number of restaurants. You can grab breakfast and snacks either from the buffet in the garden lounge, the coffee shop or even the convenience store. Will definitely be back soon.

Excellently located hotel, very easy to get around Tokyo from the metro station which is a 2 minute walk away. Staff were all exceptionally helpful too! If I had to pick a fault, I'd say I've found better gym facilities in similarly priced hotels. Just a couple of treadmills and a mat.

The Hotel New Otani had been one of the Top 3 luxury hotels, with Imperial Hotel and Hotel Okura, in Tokyo until 1980's. Then, many luxury hotels of international brands have been built in Tokyo. However, still many National Guests and Royal Families from around the world stay at this hotel, and everytime I stay here, I also enjoy the beauty and the elegance of Otani, from clean spacious rooms, comfy beds, great restaurants, wonderful Japanese garden, to helpful staffs. This is still one of the best Japanese-style hotel that I can highly recommend to my foreign friends!!

Our room in the garden hotel would imperatively need a renovation. The bathroom did not deserve a single star. Room service was lousy. They made up the room just when we returned from our trip at 6 p.m. and we had to wait for 30 minutes before we could enter.The breakfast, restaurant and bar are wickedly expensive.The positive two things to say are that the breakfast on the 40th floor was state of the art and the location of New Otani Hotel is convenient and close to the edo palace.

Great hospitality, wonderful internet and fine location. Don't miss breakfast at the 40th floor - especially on a clear weather , you can see the Fuji mountain and a gorgeous view of the city from the rooftop

We had a great triple room for three of us with a large sitting area and great views of Tokyo! It is a very large hotel and near a subway entrance... staff was courteous and accommodating. If you join the New Otani club I believe they offer free breakfast for the duration of your stay.

The hotel itself is nice, nice gardens, plenty of shops, several restaurants and close to underground as well as lots of restaurants to choose from. The staff in general is nice but reception service is just not on. We have reserved a non smoking room, we check in and got to the room and the smell of cigarettes was unbearable, we come back to reception and there was all sort of excuses not to give us a non smoking room, they took to another room again was a smoking room we did not accepted, then a 3rd room same thing, and eventually 2 hours later we manage to get a non smoking room, but the aggravation on the top of being very tired (after a 10 hrs flight) made the experience very unpleasant. In the end we were given a non smoking room but on the lower level (which again was not what we have booked) we just had to settle. The room was nice and spacious obviously not much of a view but comfy.My advise is state very clearly what you want when reserving and be prepared to fight if what you asked is not was is given to you.

Stay at the hotel a few times a year．usually satisfied with the service but this time the breakfast buffet was not as good as it used to be．food was cold and the selection was very meager We have made reservations again for the end of December . Hope it's better next time .The bar at the top of the tower was a good choice planning on going againFor our next visit.
