I stayed at the New Otani hotel with 10 colleagues for business for three nights. As a result of this experience I have recommended, and my superior and colleagues agree, that we will search for alternative arrangements when we return next year. While rooms and restaurants are all acceptable, management staff in catering/banquets were extremely inflexible, unaccommodating and in some instances rude. They unnecessarily interrupted/halted a birthday celebration and I was treated extremely poorly when trying to resolve a credit card issue (which was successfully resolved before our departure through none of their assistance). In both of these instances their treatment of myself and my colleagues can only be described as terrible and not something that I have ever experienced as a paying guest (and hope to never experience again at any hotel I stay at).

Wonderful ! beautilful hotel, your so kind The service is really correct ,Your location is perfectI hope to come back one day Your are the best hotel that I visited at TokyoThank you for everything And bisous from France

Stayed here for 4 nights at the start of a 11 night stay holiday in Japan - it was excellent. There is a huge choice of bars, restaurants etc. That said they were quite expensive but you can eat more cheaply using one of the mini marts in the same building complex. The gardens are delightful and are also lit in the evenings. The public spaces are very pleasant too. Location excellent, short walk to underground station etc. Wonderful city views from all round the hotel. Quiet and restful stay.

Pleased to have stayed here on my second visit to Tokyo. Good location for meetings in the Marunouchi financial district without the price tag if the hotels there. Was also lucky to have room with a view of the hotel's Garden, the Palace and the city. The room is western standard size and I received complentary water bottles each day and a copy of the Times. Definitely recommend and I expect to return to the New Otani on my next trip to Tokyo.

The hotel provided shuttle from and to the airport that runs every 30 minutes. For non Japanese speaker, this is an easy fix. A big hotel with several tower. The view is amazing. I have stayed 3 times, and always get Tokyo Tower view. At night time, it is a treat to see .The ground floor and up to fifth floor, have plenty stores to do window shopping. All luxurious type. The mini market (on the sub wing) ,a little hard to find, but worth to go. Specially when you are having jet lag and need a quick mealThe hotel settled in a government offices and officials. Palace isn't far from this hotel. Far from the hustle bustle of Shinjuku or Ginza. very quite and peaceful.

The Garden Tower is right next to the Five star, and it felt like being in a five star hotel. The Japanese as always are polite and helpful. There were 5 restaurants that we could choose to have breakfast, from American to good English to Japanese style.We stayed in a triple room (3 single beds) with a small lounge separate from the room. It didn't feel too uncomfortable and we really enjoyed our stay there.The wifi speed was amazing!The hotel was very well situated, with the underground about 200m away, which links up to just about everywhere (on time and frequent). We bought a 3 day ticket, which allowed us unlimited access to the trains for 3 days.It was also very close to a district (just beyond the underground entrance), which had lots of little 7-11s (convenience stores) and eating places and bars. We found a self-service noodle bar just a few steps into the area which was open for 24 hours and was value for money. Because of jetlag, we used that noodle bar at all sorts of odd times and it was great to have.The hotel itself was luxurious and the Japanese garden quaint to visit.

It's our first trip to Japan and we stayed at New Otani for 4 days. It's lovely. A wide range of restaurant in the hotel. It's also within walking distance to the underground/metro and local eateries. It has a lovely Japanese garden. The bedroom is spacious and comfortable.

We arrived as a group from a cruise, but must say that the check in desk did not appear to be ready for our arrival as it seemed unorganised. We had a bit of a blip as they were saying to nearly all of us that the rooms were not ready, and that we would have to wait to check in at 2pm however, it was 1.45pm so did not see that this should have been a problem. This is a very large hotel.We had a room in the Garden Tower and we had a young porter take our luggage to our room and he was very pleasant. we were on the 13th floor overlooking the Japanese Garden which was everything and more that I expected. what a lovely outlook this wasThe room was large and very clean, albeit that we had to have a twin room., There was a sort of water kettle (unusual) tea coffee and a fridge.As the breakfast was around £25 per person, we took cereal, bowls and brought some milk in the super market just down the road and hey presto we had our breakfast, what more do you want.The bathroom had all little extra toiletries, fold up hair brushes, tooth brush and toothpaste, razors, shower caps, cotton buds and shower gel, body lotion etc. If you used these, they were all replaced the following day, there was also slippers in the wardrobe and found the dressing gown in a drawer under the TV.. Very impressed with these itemsThe toilet was something else, nothing like this seen anywhere else. Although these are quite low to the ground and it has all sorts of buttons on it,

Stayed here for four nights as part of a guided tour of Japan. Super hotel. We stayed on the 9th floor of the tower, with views towards the Imperial Palace. Great room, plenty of space. Everything worked well. Our first baptism of the fantastic Japanese toilets. Loads of restaurants at the hotel, but the proximity to the Akasaka area meant that we only had breakfast there, twice on the 40th floor of the tower and twice in the garden restaurant ( preferred the garden because there was a better selection and the 'hot' was hot rather than luke warm). Staff were very helpful. No problems at all. Very handy for the easy to navigate Tokyo metro (Ginza line).

Very nice hotel with helpful and attentive staff. Stayed three days. Convenient location near several stations, tourist attractions and shopping. Close to Asaksa-Mitsue station. Room was clean and comfortable. Large compared to other Japan hotels.

It fabulous, comfortable, with a beatiful gardens and spectacular views from the 40 th floor, in the restaurant. You will love the breakfast if you really like the japanese food but there's not A magnificent western breakfast. In my case, I booked a non smoking room, and although it was, the guest before me smoked and the room was still with the smoke in the air, even after been cleaned.

although this hotel is massive, it is very good. The staff are attentive and helpful, the decor nice, everthing is clean and everything works. Near busy night life - lots of bars, restaurants and clubs. Don't miss the beautiful Japanese gardens adjacent to the hotel - a real haven from chaotic Tokyo

In the hustle bustle of one of the most iconic capital cities in the world is this fabulous oasis. Tokyo is known globally for its cityscapes but the New Otani has acres of gardens with a waterfall and Koi ponds. Service was first class and we found the breakfasts met all our needs and expectations with ample supplies of hot and cold, western and Japanese dishes and fruit.It is ideally located close to transport facilities and a very short walk to local restaurants and shops.Have been fortunate to travel extensively and feel the New Otani is among the best hotels we have experienced.

My husband, adult granddaughter and I recently spent 5 nights in this large hotel located near the Imperial Palace Gardens and a short walk to a useful subway station on the Ginza line. We were not thrilled by the western food for breakfast in the main garden restaurant (under cooked eggs each day, awful bacon, no fresh fruit to speak of) but there were asian offerings and other choices. We tried other restaurants in the hotel and near by and had lots of choice and price points to choose from and several very good meals. Really enjoyed cocktails in the Tower Bar with some bar plates; good food and service while looked across the night lights of Tokyo. The decor is a bit tired but very clean and well serviced. The main service we valued here was the Concierge services in the Garden Tower and main hotel - which were always helpful and very polite, and had strong levels of english speaking staff. The latter we really appreciated when we lost contact with a family member on our second day for some hours and also lost some property on the subway. Help to the rescue and matters resolved positively though both issues were complicated. Thank you to all who assisted us.

This property is just huge. It was a bit of walk from just the check-in counter to the Garden Tower where our room was located. It's a beautiful property with several restaurants if you don't want to leave the hotel to get sustenance. The room is a decent size but has all the amenities you would want. Tons of shampoo, lotions, razors, toothbrushes. There are two different types of robes: the traditional Japanese one and the plush Western one that I'm more familiar with. The staff is friendly and helpful. They were able to secure a dinner reservation for me to an exclusive sushi establishment. It's also located quite close the subway station making travel around the city quite convenient. I would definitely stay here again next time I'm in the city.

Stayed in the hotel for 5 nights. Travel to the hotel was easy from Haneda airport ¥1,300 by limousine bus, pick up at stop 3 and drop off at hotel. On the return I got a taxi which was ¥7,000 (approx £50) and took 30minutes using the expressway.The Garden Tower is part of three tower blocks that make up the Hotel New Otani all interconnected on different levels. The complex is huge and very complex with 3 receptions many many restaurants, shops and offices. In front of the Garden Lounge, one of the locations they serve breakfast, there is the hotel gardens which are beautiful with a waterfall, red bridges, carp, manicured hedges and much more.If only the standard inside was as pristine as outside but the fact is it all looks, feels and smells a bit dated and in need of a good renovation. Don't get me wrong my room was spotless and the staff were very polite and helpful but you expect that for a 4* hotel.Had breakfast in the Garden Lounge which was a mix of western and Japanese buffet. With the exception of the scrambled eggs the rest of the hot western food was all a little bit "different". The bacon was your typical soft and streaky stuff you seem to get everywhere in Asia, the sausages were more like hot dogs, chunky chips were available also. I went for the scrambled eggs and good salmon from the Japanese area. Also available was fresh fruit, yoghurt, jams, marmalade, croissants and more. All in all it was ok.With respect to the restaurants there are many but all prices are very high even allowing for a weaker £ but quality is very good particularly in the teppanyaki restaurant in the hotel gardens.Would I stay here again? Yes, but would hope they smartened the place up a bit inside and also got a decent satellite TV contract so that English speakers had more than CNN and BBC World to watch!!

Stayed here as part of a group, 15th floor. Views excellent both day time and at night. the garden is a delightful oasis in this vibrant city. Had a drink in the bar overlooking the city, don't have the wine - both expensive and for a class hotel very poor (red, French and stale). The rotating restaurant (the sky dining) in the main building was worth it for the food and view. Breakfasts in the Garden lounge and the top of the garden tower had a wide selection, preferred the Garden Lounge. Range included Japanese, continental and Asian, range of fruits, bread and cakes) Room was well supplied (complimentary water) and of a good size for 2 people. Close to Akasaka for a wide selection of eating places, and to Akasaka stations (beware to know your exit it is large and underground) to travel around the city (Ginza, Hanzomon and Marunouchi lines) supermarkets close buy for basic supplies. Exit via the garden court to save a walk around the whole block.

We stayed here at the beginning of September with a group. The room was clean, comfortable but a bit small. The staff and service are second to none. Amazing people and workers. We took a night on the main side before leaving and I must say, this is far better. I'll post that later.The gardens on this property have been maintained for hundreds of years before the hotel was erected and are incredible. To avoid pool fees sign up as a New Otani "preferred" or rewards thing for free access. It costs you nothing. Lots of shopping and restaurants located on both sides of the hotel including down a level on the main.

For the past many years I've traveled -- both for business and pleasure -- and stayed in hotels on all continents that have them (I doubt Antarctica has hotels, but I may be wrong as I've never been there). Depending on the type of travel and destination, I also stay in many kinds and levels of hotels. This was my first time staying in the legendary New Otani (although I had dined and drunk in its restaurants before) and I sincerely hope it was not the last. I might go as far as to say that this was possibly my favorite of any hotel I've stayed in. Let me elaborate.The hotel complex is large, to say the least. My elegant and very comfortable room was on the 33rd floor of the Garden Tower with stunning views over the city all the way to Tokyo Tower. One of the lovely features in New Otani is its gorgeous Japanese garden. It's large and beautiful, replete with carp ponds and waterfalls. A veritable haven in the middle of the bustling megacity.Then there are the restaurants. It's impossible to sample all of them, unless one stays a very long time, for there are more than 40 restaurants, cafes and bars inside the hotel complex. There are many superb restaurants with Japanese, Western and Chinese cuisine. As I had many appointments out on the town, I only had the chance to have lunch in Trader Vic's (an old favorite with a Tiki theme; excellent food and atmosphere overlooking the Japanese garden) and have drinks in the Tower Cafe on the 40th floor of the Garden Tower and in the dark Capri where Japanese businessmen take their dates and a female pianist plays jazz in the background. There is also live music nightly in the Garden Lounge.Needless to say, the service everywhere in the hotel is first class: friendly, helpful and fast. The hotel also serves as a stop for the limousine buses to Narita airport.The location could not be better. All the attractions and pleasures of Tokyo are within just a few minutes' walk from the hotel. Akasaka is a major restaurant and entertainment area in this megacity. It also has a number of subway lines that connect to other parts of the city. I personally enjoy walking and Tokyo is actually a great city for pedestrians, so one day I walked to Roppongi and on another to Aoyama and Shibuya, neither of which is a demanding trek.When it was time to pack up and leave (and have my bags delivered from the room to the airport bus), I felt a desire to stay on.

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here for a short Tokyo trip: excellent central location steps from transportation and with Airport Limousine stop. Service to perfection, in every detail, and very reasonable pricing. Breakfast expensive if not included. Try for Garden view rooms if possible.

This hotel has clean up-scale rooms that are a bit more spacious that most Japanese rooms. The buffet breakfast was yummy with either a fabulous view of the city and beautiful garden below or a feel of eating in the garden. Within walking distance, were hundreds of resturants. There was such a variety that it made the choice of what are where to eat a tuff decision!

We have stayed in the hotel at the beginning of July 2016 and we think that we have chosen very well.Very good location,a lot of stores near the reception,a lot of different restaurants,a commercial centre at -1,a post office where you can use the european cards to get some cash,the stuff very friendly and helpful.And,on top of these,the garden it is really very,very nice.

Only a 5 minute walk from the Yotsuda train station that connects you to virtually every part of the city.The hotel itself has an upmarket feel and the rooms are large by Tokyo standards, and if you get a high level the views are pretty good to. An added bonus, and good introduction to a first timer in Tokyo, is the Japanese gardens outside the hotel. Lovely way to start the day.The hotel is massive so it can feel like a bit of a walk to get from your room to outside, but its a minor issue. There are plenty of food outlets (both shops and restaurants). And a good few shops for souvenirs and the like.Overall this is good place to stay for location, and if you want a bit of luxury without spending fortunes. And, as with most places in Tokyo, the service in first class.
user_name:
Andrew B
East Grinstead, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed at the hotel on a organized tour, which had pre-booked. Excellent sized room for Japan, with air con. Room does have mini bar facilities, along with small fridge. Located close to local restaurants which are reasonably priced if you don't wish to pay the money for the in house restaurants. Staff as you would expect were helpful, polite and only to willing to help you. Four night stay passed to quickly.

The hotel is wonderful: big and very comfortable. Services were fine and fast. Rooms were clean and big enough, they had a wonderful view on the city. It is very well connected, just 5 minutes walk from the nearest underground station that is a centre of connection for various lines.

The complex is huge, and the transit from one lobby to the other is lined with high-end shops with some gorgeous merchandise. But is that why you came to Japan? The rooms are of decent size with fresh, clean linens and all the amenities, including plush terry robes. Service at the front desk and concierge is excellent and highly professional. I had one dinner in one of the hotel's restaurants and it was rather ordinary and very expensive. Also, the included breakfast buffet was extremely disappointing given the size and prestige of the hotel. The following night I walked eight minutes to Akasaka Street and had a fantastic choice of reasonably priced meals. The hotel is close to the Akasaka station.

This hotel was perfect. Posh but gorgeous. The gardens were out of this world, including the waterfall and koi carp in the lakes. Central for a trip to Mount Fuji and the bullet train. Two amazing experiences. Definately recommend this hotel.
user_name:
Barbara L
Romford, England, United Kingdom

review_body: This is a huge hotel complex with shopping, restaurants and a large garden area. Our room in the garden tower was quite nice. The beds were comfortable, the bathroom was small but nice, and the view was awesome. There were all kinds of amenities like slippers, toothbrush, robes, tea kettle, newspaper in the morning, free bottled water, but we were unable to locate an ice bucket. The breakfast was included with our room. We had a choice of 4 restaurants for breakfast. We ate the most amazing breakfast at Satsuki. Although we had to pay an extra charge, it was worth it. They charge you extra to swim in their pool. This hotel is right down the street from a subway station. All the staff are really friendly and helpful. We had a memorable stay at this wonderful hotel.

Located just a five minute walk from Alasaka Mitsuke subway station. It features a 400 year old Japanese garden with ponds, many carp , waterfalls. an absolute delight to walk around even the gardeners will stop and talk to you in English. Approx 400 yards from the hotel is a street that has in excess of 40 restaurants and a couple of pubs, great fun in choosing somewhere to eat. In a great location.

The conference room was well equiped and organized.The transportation for access is convenient and wide choice cuisines for dinner: near Sophia University at Yotsuya.One of my Favorite Hotels in Tokyo metropolitan area.

I checked in on August 2 at 6:00 pm The hotel messed up my check in but showed me to my room anyway. The room was nice and comfortable. The bathroom was stocked with lots of goodies. All in all, a very nice stay. The hotel was located near the metro which made getting around Tokyo easy.

We recently spent 3 nights at this property as a part of a trip to Japan. The hotel is conveniently located to transportation and walking. We especially enjoyed the garden which was beautiful and peaceful. The staff and service was excellent and attentive. We would definitely stay again.

The Garden Tower is separate from the Main part of the New Otani Hotel. We stayed on the 29th, I don't think that the Main hotel is as tall. Consequently the view is amazing, although from our corner room we looked out over Akasaka and a lot of businesses and highways. I bet a garden view would have been amazing from that floor. Anyway, we spent 3 nights here on some hot days in the summer. There were 3 of us in a room that had 3 single beds. This was called a Twin Superior and I booked it from the website stating that 3 adults would be in the room. So this was perfect for the family. Be aware that the beds are very hard here and at most of the hotels we stayed at in Japan, but the linens on the bed were really nice. This corner room had a small sitting room with a couch, coffee table, chairs and desk. The room also had two TVs, but they only get CNN and BBC in English. We didn't try the on-demand services. The Internet worked great throughout the hotel. Our only problem is that the rooms never cooled as much as we would have liked, but it was okay. And the humidity, which was high outside, was also high in the rooms. For example, we washed out some shirts in the sink and it took 3 days for them to dry in the room. The towels in the bath were fabulous! Nice and big. The ceilings were a bit low in the room, so my hubby and son, both several inches over 6ft. had to remember to duck. The location of the hotel is great. It's an easy walk to the Tokyo Metro and there are several parks nearby that you can walk through. If you forgot something, the BIC Camera store 2 blocks away has 7 floors of everything. The restaurants in the hotel are a bit expensive ($20 for dessert and tea), but the service is great. Around the hotel are lots of great restaurants, easy walking distance. The hotel has a pool that looked really nice, but has an additional fee associated with it. Frankly, after long days of touring, I don't think we could have walked to the pool anyway!!
user_name:
Jeanne B
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed on the 34th floor of the Garden Tower in a triple room....what an amazing view! The service was fantastic, and the soba/udon restaurant was delicious. The gardens are a find in the middle of the city. The main hotel lobby area is lovely too. Great location in Akasaka. Would return!

Huge hotel complex in central Tokyo location, good for families as well. Great choice of restaurants inside, excellent breakfast options, free fast WiFi and free parking. Best part of the hotel is the traditional onsite Japanese garden as well as the pool.Garden tower rooms and feel may be a little dated but in good condition, also a lot of options are being charged extra and making the stay more expensive.

We used to live in Tokyo and the New Otani has always been a bit of a favourite. The gardens are excellent with the largest koi! If you join the new otani club then the pool is free - and it is a big pool for Tokyo. The rooms are spacious, clean and well provided albeit dated in decoration (part of the hotel's charm but not to everyone's taste)Service is extraordinary - very attentive and polite- they organised car rental and booked restaurants. Parking is complimentary with s good car park.Breakfasts are served across 4 restaurants each of which are good though not as varied as other countries in Asia - that is true of most Tokyo hotels though - having said that the Satsuki restaurant is great for breakfast with Pierre Herme sourcing the pastries .The hotel is large but this doesn't impact service. It is linked to a shop complex which includes convenience stores (Family Mart) to source snacks and drinks if uou fo not want to source from the hotel.Location wise, the hotel is jn Akasaka (with lots of restaurants) close to metro stations and central between Ginza and the palace on one side and Shibuya and Shinjuku on the other.As a balance of price, room size, utility, location, pool access you fo not have yo pay for, the gardens (which are a destination in themselves) and incredibly high service standards, The New Otani is an excellent choice - compared to some of the other great five star Tokyo hotels

We felt we lived as Japanese people in the past. The hotel is decorated very Japanese to create a cozy and quiet atmosphere. Although it is not really a stay for a big family because the quietness is a must, we all felt relaxed and enjoyable of listening to music and sightseeing around the garden.

everything excellent. Price reasonable.room spacious and well managed.Very friendly and fast check in and check out.easy reach to all transport as location wise shopping and restaurants, walking, garden all GREAT.
user_name:
FANNBH
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: I don't have nothing bad to say about this hotel, the room was adequate, the breakfast wasn't bad, although the view from the 40th story, were the breakfast lounge was located, was amazing. The staff was friendly and understood English better than the majority of the places in Japan. On the whole a pleasing experience.

rooms are not spacious but two can adjust. Amenities like coffee maker, iron are available. Though breakfast spread is good, but quite confusing as three restaurants are for inmates. We in a group checked in , waited for more than one hour to get room keys. There is no provision to sit in lobby while check in is going on. Seniors & ladies suffered after jet log. The rooms are far and in other tower . One has to carry their luggage since no bellboy. Though clean , good location , foreign tourists with laggauge , seniors will have to walk long to reach the room

I've been in this oterl about 10 times for business purposes. Usually when season prices are more affordable. Indeed it's a nice hotel. Very clean, good service. Nice lobby service. Plenty of elevators. Outstanding breakfast area (and variety of food) in front ot the inner Japanese garden. The inside garder is spectacolous. Really worth to walk by and also a nice Japanese restaurant inside. Different restaurants are inside for different choices. Not cheap but good food. Clearly going out right down the street in Akasaka area the choice is almost endless. It's just a pity that such a nice hotel does not have worth fitness area. Just two small rooms with a few machines (and limited acces tima) and that's. I would have expecetd much more for the money you pay for. However, a nice place to be and an insureance to be treated well. i would return and recommend.

Look carefully at the prices before you eat here. Sandwiches and beer in the bar cost us over £70!!! Other than that a beautiful, if large, hotel in lovely gardens. Well appointed rooms with in bathroom entertainment - a Japanese toilet!! Not wash and go, it's go and wash.

We enjoyed our stay here. The staff was nice. We had a triple room that had a separate lounge room so it was nice and spacious. If you are a family you will really enjoy having this space. Just outside the bathroom was an additional sink/vanity. Although not a large space, it was great to have the extra vanity area so I could do my hair/makeup while the bathroom was in use. The furniture was a little beat up. They could stand to spend a few dollars on the interior of the room. The beds were comfortable. The only odd thing was the humidity in the room. I was not really aware of it until I washed a few clothes items by hand. It was 2 full days and they still were not dry. I ended up having to use the blow dryer to finish drying them to pack them up. We were in the Garden Tower building. They have several options of room types and area’s of the hotel. This seemed to be the on the lower price range of the options. The grounds were beautiful. The location was excellent. We were close to the subway stop. I liked it here vs. the main station which is where I initially thought we should stay. It was not as crowded and not as much to go through to get on and off the subway in this area. We were centrally located so it was easy to branch out into any area with out having to cross over the whole city. The only restaurant we ate at was the Garden Café and that was for breakfast. It was expensive at about $35 a person. I almost forgot, the night we arrived after our long flight we did get a burger at Trader Vic’s. It was good. There are a couple of streets just over the bridge that are almost pedestrian only as there are so few cars and there were plenty of restaurants and a grocer and few small shops here. It was nice to have this close by.

It's a stretch to rate this five stars, but I don't know what else a hotel could do to earn that rating. Our room was spacious, impeccably clean, beautifully decorated, well equipped and even had a sweeping view of a section of the city skyline. Located within walking distance of the Imperial Palace in one direction and the Asakasa food district in the other, and a short subway ride from the Ginza, it's just about a perfect location. The hotel grounds are themselves a beautiful garden. Just outside, a section of the old moat wall offers a serene walking path with nice city views. Food was excellent, as was service. So why add a cautionary note to my rating? Because of the crowds. This is a big hotel, and it caters to tour groups and conventions. The corridors can get crowded, as well as the breakfast area. But the included breakfast is among the best, and as a member of a tour group myself I can't complain too much about the crowds. By the way, I see no reason to draw a distinction between the Garden Tower and the main hotel. They were built at different times, but are now connected by a passageway full of upscale shops and share a reception area and dining rooms. The only real difference is that the tower is taller and can therefore offer better views.

Staff were exceptionally helpful. wanted to do anything they could for you without asking. Were on 37th floor with amazing views of city. Spacious rooms. Good location with 5 subway lines accessible within 2 minute walk. Restaurants in hotel are very pricey compared to everywhere we had been. A number of restaurants across the road to pick from which are cheaper. Breakfast on the 40th floor had amazing views, including of Mt Fuji. However, be warned. You may need to queue for sometime to get in between 6-30 to 8-00am. However after the rush you just walk in. The shops in the complex vary from ultra expensive to reasonably priced - depends what you're after. the Hop-on/hop off bus stops 3 times a day here. The airport shuttle service operates from the hotel to both airports. Overall a great experience.

The hotel is fantastically located with shopaholic and eating places within walking distance. The room was spacious with fantastic views towards tokyo tower. We stayed on the 35th floor which helped. The breakfast buffet on the 40th floor was just great. There were some 4 different types of egg preps. The hotel has a mini shopping center which is frightfully expensive but costs nothing to browse by. Enjoyed the hotel and would recommend it.

Our first time in Japan and the first place to encounter the culture of Japan and its wonderful people. The hotel is HUGE. Perhaps not where I would have chosen to stay but fine for an overnight stay. The restaurants were very expensive (to us) but our inclusive breakfast was lovely. The gardens were beautiful and a very pleasant place to walk around. We were on the 27th floor so had a fine view of Tokyo. Did not have much time to explore outside of the hotel and although all the staff were very helpful we were very unadventurous for the few hours we were there.

A huge hotel. We were part of a group booked in here, would not have stayed otherwise, the hotel is difficult to negotiate, and it takes a while to get anywhere! On the plus side the room was spacious and comfortable, with great views over the gardens and city.The gardens are attractive and well laid out. We ate in the Italian restaurant in the evening which was pleasant, though the service was somewhat slow.On the negative side the hotel was very busy, always is I imagine. Lots of groups. And even though there is a number of breakfast venues there seemed to be queues for all of them. The top floor bar was very nice with wonderful views, but unfortunately very smoky.

Stayed here as part of a group trip to Japan.The hotel is lovely, very big (I got lost!) with stunning gardens.The room was a good size, very clean and comfortable, and very quiet.The only downside is that breakfast is a scrum - it gets very busy.

The Garden Tower-40 floors is about 1 third of this amazing hotel complex but despite the size we found it staffed by friendly & efficient staff. Many restaurants of all types , good shops & nice facilities. The adjacent gardens are historically famous & beautiful.Our room was very well appointed & of good size with magnificent views. I think this hotel whilst huge is underrated& could be 5 star.
user_name:
Asternian
Bury St. Edmunds, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed for 3 nights. Very nice hotel on a large property with beautiful gardens. The rooms are on the small size but above standard for Japan. Lots of restaurant choices and various stores. Very convenient to subway station. More of a business or large group hotel. Need to take subway or taxi to downtown. The view from the 40th floor restaurant is quite spectacular. The property is very large with two towers it is a long walk from Garden tower to main entrance and parking at the Hotel.

Exiting the hotel is unusual. If you exit from the Garden Tower exit you take escalators 7 stories down before reaching the outside but if you take the main checkout exit you take an escalator down one story and then you are outside. The Garden Tower exit takes you to banks, other restaurants and other retail. (In the hotel itself there are high end retail. The Post Office including its ATM , another ATM machine, hair styling and other retail you access from the "main checkout" exit.) The room had two single beds and good water pressure for the shower that was easy to direct. CNN and CNBC seemed to be the only English TV channels. The restaurant between the two exits looks out on the waterfall and the maintained garden and is less expensive than the other in hotel restaurants. The closest subway station is a 15 min. walk away. I flew into Narita airport and took the orange bus from the airport right to the hotel in 1 1/2 hrs. For it you purchase a ticket just before you exit Arrivals for outside. It says the time the bus leaves and at which post you stand at. They give you a numbered baggage claim ticket that you turn in to when you get off the bus to get your bag. The display in the bus tells you when your hotel is next.

We stayed here for five nights. The hotel is very clean and well located right next door to the Tokyo metro. With more than 40 restaurants in this hotel, there is bound to be one that fits your food taste and your budget. Concierge service is very helpful. Staff is very professional. A thoroughly enjoyable stay!

Hotel itself very nice, huge. Service was excellent!! Room ok. But could be better. Out dated decor, which really does not bother me that much. Beds were very hard, and really that is my main issue. I have both rheumatoid and osteoarthritis, and when I woke up each morning, the beds were so hard, it made mornings, and first part of my touring very uncomfortable. ( I was there with a tour group ). My only other issue is that there is no store selling bottled water, or other cold drinks. You had to purchase from the mini bar in room, and get expensive water from mini fridge in room. Beautiful hotel overall. While we were there the Japanese Emperor was holding an awards dinner there, and people dressed in their best traditional Japanese clothing were walking around, very elegant. Do not plan on eating lunch or dinner in hotel. Very very expensive to say the least. However, within about ten to fifteen minutes walk, many manny restaurants to choose from, and area is safe to walk in even at night. Lots of high ennd, very high priced shopping in hotel. Many many stores within hotel itself. Take a look at the Japanese Gardens on hotel property. Very beautiful. Go early morning, then again at night for very different views. Would go again, just hope they do something with their beds. My understanding is that hard mattresses are preferred in Japan.

Very large property, lots of restaurants (very expensive.) Hotel room seems large compared to the few others I've stayed in here in Tokyo. Nice standard. Request a room over the garden - views are supposed to be great (I'm on the city side.) Very convenient to subway, but not a lot of interesting bars/restaurants just outside hotel (at least that I've found.) If coming on holiday, I'd suggest staying somewhere with a slightly better vibe. If here on business, this place should meet your needs. Make reservations for dinner - I was turned away from a seemingly empty sushi restaurant due to not having a booking. Staff very friendly and several speak at least limited English, so communication is not hard. If coming from Narita airport, get on the Airport Limousine (bus), it will drop off directly at the hotel - very convenient.

Wonderful to have a room with the view to the beautiful garden!It's a very good hotel, very friendly and competent staff. The rooms are not too small, more agreeable than usual Japanese standard. Good restaurants, but also expensive!Wonderful garden, gives you the chance for a nice walk in the center of the city! Problem: no possibility to open the windows.

What a lovely hotel although it is big, probably one of the biggest I have stayed in, and you can get easily lost when you first arrive. The hotel has 2 accommodation blocks linked by an avenue of shops and restaurants. I wasn’t aware of the lower area of shops until we were about to leave. We stayed in the garden tower which is the newer and taller of the buildings and our room was on the 33rd floor. The room was large, clean and well equipped, including a kettle to make tea, it also had a good view over Tokyo. The hotel had a number of restaurants, western, Japanese, Chinese and Korean, two of them were on the top of the two buildings and the view from the 40th floor was amazing. There is also a superb Japanese garden in the centre of the hotel were you can escape for some peace and quiet.The hotel is not cheap for food and drink, we ate one evening in the western style restaurant in the main lobby and two chicken burgers and two small beers came to £48. A visit to the bar on the 40th floor for a small beer and a small glass of wine was £26. But there are alternatives as it is only a short walk to numerous restaurants and a few bars, there are also a number of small supper markets selling sandwiches, snacks and drinks, there is actually one within the hotel complex.The hotel is in a good position for visiting Tokyo as it is within a short walk of the metro station with links to all parts.

Huge hotel but with the most wonderful unexpected water gardens, better than any parkland Upgraded to a suite because heard the rooms were on the small side. Restuarants expensive, but you have to try the revolving restaurant, very expensive but fun. Excellent choice of wines.Stayed four nights, very convenient for Tokyo, service slow but staff excellent

Loved this hotel and it worked emailing them requesting a room on a high floor, we were on 34th. Wonderful on our 2nd morning to wake up and see Mount Fuji. Also fab views of Tokyo from restaurant on top floor whilst having a leisurely breakfast.

A very large hotel (1,500 bedrooms I believe), this hotel is all about quality with a large number of staff to look after you. There are two towers, we stayed in the Garden Tower on the 19th floor, great views of the Tokyo Tower and the ant like people scurrying to work in a morning. Dining was available on the 7th and 40th floors, however there are a lot more other options you can try in the hotel.Over our three night stay we found it to be very clean and very comfortable, staff were very obliging. A beautiful historic garden within the hotel bounds - ensure you leave enough time to stroll around it, you will not be disappointed.

This hotel was selected for us as part of a tour of Japan. Stayed 4 nights. Room was fine: good size, all facilities ( including easy to access free wi-fi), spotlessly clean, view over city from our window. Convenient for metro and lots of reasonably priced places to eat nearby. We didn't use any of the facilities except breakfast. Lots of restaurants to choose from within the hotel complex. We opted for those on 40th floor. Great views over Tokyo, good choice of Western or Japanese food. Reasonable service. We breakfasted at about 7.00 and didn't experience any queues. Staff were all polite but the hotel is absolutely massive. There are really 2 very large hotels in one as well as lots of shops and restaurants. Be prepared for long walks to get from one end to the other. Rather impersonal.
user_name:
HB2981
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Great location for intro to Tokyo, beautiful gardens, lovely staff, immaculate interior, excellent breakfast restaurants. Rooms average size, good shower, good firm bed, free internet. Ask for view of gardens, too high up and you will miss the view.

We stayed 1 night in this hotel. From check in to our room was a 20 minute walk dragging our luggage as there was not enough staff to deliver it to the room. The room was basic - we had a view of the office building next door. There are lots of shops and restaurants here, but the restaurant we had to go to for breakfast - there was a long wait, and the food was fairly basic, not a lot of choice. This stay was part of a package tour and it certainly felt like it.

The rooms were large and clean and the sushi restaurant was excellent. But that's all that was good about the place. The front desk staff was terribly rude, and the lines to get into breakfast in the morning were atrocious. I had heard this from other colleagues but given the sell out of most local hotels I thought "how bad could it be?"...it was that bad! I couldn't believe how horrible the customer service was. My flight was delayed and I was stranded at the airport at 2am. I called the hotel and asked them to arrange a taxi or car service for me since the train and public buses do not run at that hour. They said they could not help me and could not arrange a car of any type, The guy at the front desk was actually disrespectful - not something I would expect in Japan. I would avoid this place if you want good service and nice people.

Stayed 4 nights in the garden tower and had a wonderful view of the Japanese garden.A large hotel, rooms a good size for Japan and very comfy beds. The staff are all very polite and couldn't do enough for you. We only ate breakfast in the hotel, preferring the Garden Room, however it became busy very quickly on opening due to tour groups leaving the hotel around 8am. A good choice at breakfast. For the evening there are plenty of restaurants nearby offering both Japanese and Western choices.Enjoyed our stay.

High end hotel. Very courteous staff. Very big you could get lost. Has a money exchanger on site, service fee to use it. Close to shopping areas and many restaurants around. Near to subway. Had breakfast on the 40th floor, nice porcelain ware. No wait time in restaurant of you dine.Room gorgeous and aesthetic

Our family fist trip to Japan. The good thing is Airport Bus dropped us at the hotel door step so it is convenient for us. We got a one bedroom suite with the view of Tokyo tower, which is awesome. Japanese garden is really beautiful. The hotel is so big, we lost our way back to our tower many times. Service is excellent. It was raining when we were going for sightseeing, one of the hotel staff run around and get us some umbrellas for us to take with us.Akasaka station is right down the street where you can get good food for reasonable price.

Good sized room with good bathroom. Two downsides - one was the need to queue for breakfast. To avoid this, you need to be there as it opens! Having said that, the choice in breakfast is fantastic! Second irritation - the hotel has two residential parts, joined by a long walkway with garden to one side. Most tourist parties seem to be given rooms in the Tower, which is at the back of the hotel with its own reception desk. When coaches drop people off, it's at the front entrance - so a walk of 4 minutes to get to the lifts in the Tower!! But at least there is a good lift system - anyone who has a room up to the 15th? floor uses one lift, anyone who has a room on the 16th floor and above, has a express lift which makes its first stop on the 16th floor!! A short walk out of the back entrance to a wide choice of eateries.

Very good hotel for conferences, banquets and meetings. Location of the hotel and spaciousness is an added advantage for such events. Hotel is very clean, bedlinen and other amenities are of best quality. Staffs are extremely friendly and humble just like many other Japanese people. Its a very good hotel.

We stayed in this hotel for one night at the end of a tour, staying in the Garden Tower.We found the hotel far too big with everything too far away from everything else made worse by poor service. The room was fine, being large enough and clean with a comfortable bed and a good shower which are the important things. The best feature of the hotel was the garden which was magnificient. I would visit to have afternoon tea in the Garden Lounge and stay somewhere else.

Well like everything else me and my niece had to get our bearings to where we were located. That's why it's important to do your homework first. We liked the hotel especially for getting on the Metro which we used extensively. It's only a short walk out of south end of the hotel and bingo you're on. Also from the same end there's whole slew of restaurants of all types. It will save you a lot of money rather than eating in the hotel itself which if you like spending a lot of money...be my guest. My advice is be adventuresome and leave the comfort of the hotel and try some of these restaurants. The hotel has no problem filling the seats of the restaurants. But most people eat out. Our tour group's breakfast was paid for and the style was buffet and the food was excellent.

Booked a triple room in the Garden tower. There were 2 King singles and 1 single bed. The King single was wide enough for me to share with my 6 year old. The room was big enough to fit all beds, a desk and a sitting area which is quite big on a Tokyo hotel scale. The bathroom was compact but comfy enough to fit all our toiletries; I wish they had more hooks for our clothing. The hairdryer was the folding travel type but powerful enough for my brushing. The room didn't have any ironing board nor iron available but it had a boiler that could be filled with tap water. I liked that it had an extra sink outside the bathroom which allowed the kids to brush their teeth and go to bed while I was having a bath; it was a bit tricky sometimes to share a bathroom between the 4 of us. Our packaged included breakfast and we had 4 restaurants to choose from. The Japanese brekkie at Nadaman was divine. The continental one at the Garden lounge was disappointing and the breakfast buffet at Sabuki (not 100% sure about the name but it was located in the lobby of the main tower) was pretty good. The hotel also has a convenience store and a pharmacy as well as heaps of restaurants. There are also lots of little shops that seem to be frozen in time; some of the merchandise and clothing sold date back from the 80s. Overall, the service was good; I just found check-in a bit slow and I had to complete a form again with all my details whereas that was already done online. Besides that, the location is great and closed to the metro. Akasaka district is just walking distance and offers lots of dinning options. I reckon if this hotel had a facelift, it would be terrific.

Everything about this place is 5 star except for the charges for food and drinks in the restaurants. The garden is magic, the rooms well equipped and comfortable if a little old, the atmosphere sophisticated and the location very good.

The hotel was first class for location and comfort. Hotel New Otani is a city within itself with cafes, shops and a beautiful garden to explore outside. Service was very good with staff going out of their way to be courteous and friendly. We did have a couple of hick-ups however. Coming back from touring one day, we found our room unlocked and ajar. I think the cleaner meant to come back and forgot, or finding we were back, said nothing. Our passports were in the room and that could have been disastrous. As it turned out nothing was taken and all was good and the house manager apologised. The other slight problem was one of communication with breakfast. We wanted the continental breakfast and they kept insisting that we have the buffet. We finally were told that the continental wasn't an option until after 10 a.m.and it was 9.30a.m. It was probably quite evident in Japanese but not reading that language, and trying to make ourselves understood- was difficult. Overall the service was wonderful, and the hotel is close to subway and on most tour pick-up lists.

Our room was a standard twin and the most basic offered by the hotel. It costs rack rate on the web 36,000 JY ( remember 150 JY per £1 ) per night for two people.We were very lucky in that we had a room at the end of a corridor on the curved end of the tower overlooking the Japanese garden with a view of Tokyo beyond. It was a very good sized room and elegantly decorated in black and silver.There were two very large single beds with fresh white sheets, changed daily ( including the duvet inside!) and a nice bolster cushion in turquoise and black and silver on the bed. The curtains were also a mixture of a deep dark silver, black and then a pelmet of the same plus a deep red . It looked really classy. On one wall there was a section of Japanese style black patterned wallpaper in black and pearl in a bamboo pattern.The beds were really comfortable and I did spend rather longer in mine than most as I got food poisoning on my second day and asPictures of New Otani Garden Tower, TokyoNew Otani Garden Tower, Tokyo our roomour roomNew Otani Garden Tower, Tokyo our roomNew Otani Garden Tower, Tokyo New Otani Garden Tower, TokyoNew Otani Garden Tower, Tokyo New Otani Garden Tower, TokyoNew Otani Garden Tower, Tokyo New Otani Garden Tower, Tokyoa result spent a lot of time in the room for 36 hours!!There was a TV which needless to say had mainly Japanese channels but BB world news was available.There was a mini bar offering the usual expensive options but they gave us two bottles of water every day at no extra charge. The tap water is safe to drink though so we drank both.Wifi was free and pretty fast too which was good. We had two comfortable chairs and a small table near the window where we sat at night admiring the view of the sunset over Tokyo. There was a chair and desk unit with the TV, mini bar, fridge , coffee and green tea ( no milk just coffee creamer and sugar) , kettle and two big drawers .Every hotel in Japan that we stayed in let us two Yakutas (light cotton kimonos ) but this hotel also had two white fluffy towel bath robes as well. The Yakutas were changed daily while the bath robes lasted our stay.We had a large wardrobes with about ten hangers, a safe with coded lock was within the wardrobe but the door opened towards us sideways so it was quite a challenge to see the code to set it! A shelf above the hanging area was good for more storage. A folding suitcase stand was also in the wardrobe and there was a carpeted shelf on the desk unit which also could be used to hold a case too.The room was nice and light and airy and di have pretty good lighting too with reading lights for both beds and a central bedside table with a clock integrated facing the room so not easy to see from the bed!You could set the wake up call from the room using the phone and didn’t have to request it in person which was useful.THE BATHROOMThis was not a bad size and has a shower over the bath. The bath was quite a good size and the shower also quite good. A shower curtain and not a screen was used as the Japanese do like their baths too.The sink was set in a unit with a work top area and there were lots of toiletries etc left for us. We had shampoo, conditioner and body wash, two toothbrushes, two folding hair brushes, two razors. A folding hair dryer was on the shelf but no plug outlet in the bathroom not anywhere near any of the mirrors in the room which was annoying for me.The toilet was the most amazing contraption ever and in fact we had these in every hotel and in many public toilets too.Firstly it was huge and you could choose from many options such as heated toilet seat, various bidet options which we didn’t dare try in case we got a nasty surprise. It was ran trickling water as you sat on the seat to perform to cover any embarrassing noises and maybe to encourage you to wee, who knows? I found it rather disconcerting personally.BREAKFASTWe were on a bed and breakfast basis so the only meal we ate in the hotel was breakfast as food in the hotel was very expensive. There were many restaurants to choose from for eating other meals but for breakfast we could choose from three.Every one of the three was busy and if you had to be ready by a specific time then it paid to get there as the restaurant opened as otherwise you had to queue while waiting for others to finish their breakfast. There was a queue as it opened but at least you knew you would be in as it opened and would not have to wait for others to breakfast first.The hotel had a huge number of restaurants from pizza places to cafes and every type of restaurant you might imagine. There are 38 places to eat in total in the complex. And around 3,000 people can be accommodated in restaurants in the complex.There were also exclusive shops in various places around the hotel, some along the passageway between the two towers and many more on floors below. All offering items that only the very wealthy could afford and to be truthful nothing tempted me.

I have stayed here several times and find it to be consistently good. Rooms are spacious, comfortable and clean, breakfasts are generous and offer good choice though morning queues can frustrate, and the staff are always friendly and helpful. Views of Mt Fuji from the upstairs breakfast room are a delightful bonus on a clear day!

The New Otani is an extremely well run hotel. The rooms are of generous propotions especially in Tokio were space is at a premium. Nice bathrooms. Large twin beds with lovely quality white linen, quilts & pillows. Restaurants for breakfast (food very good western tastes catered for) can be hectic at times as the hotel is favoured by touring groups all of whom leave about the same time 8.30am. Adjacent to metro & many restaurants. Overall a lovely stay. Beautiful Japanese garden, older than the Hotel

I have stayed at the New Otani Garden Tower Hotel four times now and it is my "go to" place when I am in Tokyo on business.Positives:- hotel staff are very friendly, incredibly attentive and all speak English well. - rooms are always meticulously clean - the rooms are well sized and comfortable. - the beds are firm and comfortable with quality linen. - the hotel breakfasts are out of this world. There are at least 3 different restraint options to choose for breakfast. The best food (western and Japanese style) is definitely on the bottom floor restaurant in the main building. The restaurant on the 40th floor doesn't have the best food but it certainly has an extraordinary view. - internet access is the best I've seen anywhere in the world. At full gigabit speed it's blisteringly quick and is unlimited and free. What's even better is that there is cable and wifi and there is no silly passwords to remember. Just free unencumbered access. - when possible they will frequently upgrade your room without additional cost which is great. - laundry service and other amenities are first class. Negatives:- the hotel is pricey but in line with other 5 star hotels so not really a negative. - I struggled to find good numbers of reasonably priced restaurants and stores within walking distance of the hotel.All in all, always a great stay.

We stayed at Hotel New Otani Garden Tower for three nights on a tour. We felt that it was very good, although we had some ups and downs.If we were advising friends intending to stay there, our first piece of advice would be - to get to breakfast before the crowd--no matter which breakfast restaurant you choose. Of the three locations, one opened at 6 am and the other two at 7 am. We chose the one on the top floor the first day we were there, and it took 15 minutes in a pre-breakfast queue to be seated. On subsequent days we arrived at opening hour at other restaurants. Many tours book rooms at the New Otani, so there are bound to be peak demand hours depending on when tours leave in the morning.- We would also advise friends to admire the splendid garden outside of the garden cafe right after breakfast when there are only one or two other people out there. The gardens are especially charming when they appear peaceful, quiet and private.The hotel is grand in size and operations with so many first class restaurants and expensive shops that all the time we were navigating its main building and additions. We were aware that at some time in the last it was more grand and more exclusive. The hotel is within walking distance of many restaurants and shops.We appreciated the tiled copies of woodblock prints in the bathroom. The glazed tile surface made the colors more vivid than in the woodblock prints that they copied.Staff seem dedicated. When we reported that there was no water running in our bathroom, a man came personally to apologize, and after the water was again running, he entered our room to confirm it was OK. After we reported that housekeeping neglected to leave coffee and tea, they left a large assortment of both. We feel the price is comparatively low for Tokyo considering the facilities, location, and service

We stayed at this hotel in November 2015 and were very impressed and happy with the facilities and the service provided by all the staff. In particular, the concierge team deserve a special mention. On arrival in Tokyo we lost a wallet at the airport. We reported the loss to the concierge and even though we only stayed two nights, the team made several enquiries on our behalf and finally managed to track it down. It was posted to our home after our holiday in Japan was over.The location is perfect for access to the metro and public transport links.The zen garden is stunning, especially at night when it is floodlit.We had a buffet breakfast both mornings in the garden room which has excellent views of the zen garden and across the city and we never experienced any queues or problems. There was plenty of good food of different styles to choose from. We joined the New Otani club at reception and this gave us discounts in the restaurant.The room was clean and well equipped with all the usual amenities.Two days is not enough to see all the facilities in the hotel, but we would gladly return.

This is a huge hotel built with Europeans in mind. The bathrooms are large with plenty of shelf space but mine had rather tired fittings. The bedrooms are very large with good amenities, storage space and everything you could desire and are delightfully decorated in a Japanese style. My room was on floor 35 and had stunning views across Tokyo, it was quiet as well. Downstairs is a rather daunting rabbit maze so you need time to orientate yourself to the layout of the hotel or you could easily get lost and be late for your tour or meeting. Checking in was a laborious process and like so many other Japanese hotels you are only issued with one key per room rather than one key per person which is irritating. We took breakfast on the top floor (40) which was airy with stunning views. Had to queue for 25 minutes but it was worth the wait. Usual attentive service from all the staff.

A lovely 5 star hotel in a central location, easy access to the Metro allows you tonged anywhere in the city quickly.Good sized bedroom, excellent facilities, including dressing gowns. There a good selection of restaurants to choose from, but prices do reflect the accommodation.Many other eateries nearby.Breakfast can be daunting, you need to queue, the first morning we went to breakfast 10 minutes after it opened, and had to wait 40 minutes for a table. The next morning we went at 6.40 and were eighth in the queue.Service of the staff was exceptional, cannot be faulted, always a friendly smile wherever you go. I would happily stay there longer. Thank you all so much.MOBILE PHONEThis is no reflection on the hotel. If you have a mobile that is older than two years it probably will not work in Japan. I have what Imcall my holiday phone, a cheap travel SIM card in an iPhone 4, that I have used in Africa, South Americac, Iceland and so on, will not work in Japan.A quick solution, most hotels have wifi, open a Skpe account, add some credit, and you can then easily make calls to UK landlines, and mobiles. I paid pence for a ten minute call to a landline in the uk.

We had a corner room with a good view, everything worked, but the decor and furnishings were reminiscent of visiting Japan in the 1970s. The garden was delightful and the best feature of the hotel.Breakfast on the 40th floor was nothing special in terms of food and there was a long line up when we left, although the views were spectacular.It is a long walk from the garden tower to the main front lobby if one is boarding a coach.

We had a room in the garden tower, on booking we asked for a "renovated room", ours was on he 36 floor and was excellent, quite spacious for Japan. We found the location great, 5 minutes walk to Akasaka metro "D" exit. Breakfast was a little pricy, so you can buy items at the Family Mart on the second floor as an option. The garden is beautiful, the lobby of the garden tower felt a little dated, main due to the carpet that appeared to be water stained in parts, needs replacing. Bed was very firm but not a deal breaker. We caught the Limo bus from Haneda, had to go to Shinjuku because it was late, so required a taxi from there as we had too much luggage for the metro (2000 yen).Glenn's star rating 1 - 51 Disaster, never stay again2 Poor, likely will not stay again3 Average, nothing exceptional4 Good, will come back5 Excellent, love this hotelLocation ★★★★Appearance ★★★★Room Size ★★★★Room Cleanliness ★★★★★Bed Comfort ★★★★Linen/pillow ★★★★★Food Quality ★★★★Amenities ★★★★★Value for Money ★★★★★Service ★★★★Average star rating = 4.3

As can been seen, I have stayed at many hotels throughput Japan and Asia. I just mention a few low lights of this dreadful property:ROOMGarden Tower rooms are old and dated yet very expensive.BREAKFASTHad to wait 15+ minutes in a queue just to be seated. I had not planned on this extra time and made me late for my business meeting. Something needs to be done; another breakfast room, a grab & go option, better staff.The breakfast food was the WORST I have ever experienced at an Asian breakfast buffet. Options are limited to truly cold scrambled eggs, some soggy, cold breakfast meats, stale pastries from the day before and canned fruit, cereal.ELEVATORSWaited another 10+ minutes for an available elevator as I was trying to depart my hotel room floor to go to my business meeting. Door would open, elevator packed like some kind of Tokyo rush-hour subway, repeat. Elevator after elevator totally packed.In total I was 30 minutes late for my business meeting due the breakfast & elevator queues.All this for a VERY, VERY expensive room rate.Unless you are a tourist and get a great deal, avoid this miserable property.Attention General Manager: FIX YOUR BREAKFAST SERVICE!!!!!!

Booked on a organized marathon trip and didn't get to choose the room, which was furnished with really old stuff, but in my opinion it wasn't that bad. Stylish after all. The Hotel has 4 restaurants and we tried breakfast in each of them, being breakfast included in our fare. By far our favourite was at the 40th floor. Not only for the view stretching till Mt. Fuji, but mostly because you could select between both western and Japanese styles. However, we didn't try these places for dinner, cause they were far too expensive as compared to the good restaurants just outside.For the rest, wi-fi was working properly, service was polite but not very helpful, the hotel own inner garden well worth a visit.Overall, I would expect more from a hotel of this standard and price.

Came in for a long weekend my my wife and two kids. We booked a Deluxe Room which was recommended for us. When we checked in we discovered that there were only two twin beds for 4 of us!!!! This is what they recommended! When we ask for a bunk bed they wanted us to charge. Then they offered us to go to the Garend room which is so but so old you can not imagine. There to our surprised they gave us three single bed!! My so had to sleep on a small cough. Unbelievable. Note English is very very poor and you just give up in the end talking. Overall I was told this is the best hotel in Tokyo but it is far but far from it and i do come here to japan since 1998!!!

I flew into Tokyo Narita Airport and my transportation was not there to meet me. When I finally arrives to Hotel New Otani Garden Towers. The amazing staff made me feel right at home. The Japanese Hospitality was great as always. This hotel goes the extra mile for the guest. Ready to come back already.

The last time we stayed at this hotel was 25 years ago and we were pleased to see that The New Otani continues to maintain a very high standard. Our standard double room on the 30th floor in the Garden Tower had been recently renovated with a comfortable king-bed and contemporary furniture. Bathroom was up to date. Service as usual in this hotel is first rate. We ate breakfast in the restaurant at the top of the Garden Tower with wonderful city views, and one morning in the Garden Lounge. Nothing can beat a good buffet breakfast at a table overlooking the hotel's renowned 400 year old Japanese garden. However avoid eating in the Garden Lounge at other times as the prices are excessive and there are so many eating options around the hotel. We enjoy the hotel's location within easy stroll of Akasaka's restaurant district. The Akasaka-mitsuke Metro station is virtually beside the hotel, and the Narita Airport bus stops at the hotel (if using the airport bus both ways remember a round-trip ticket can be bought at the airport at a considerable discount). Make sure to take a walk through the Japanese Garden, and the hotel also has an interesting museum free for guests.

I have been here for 5 days in Nov 2015 for a meeting. The room was so comfortable, equipments was good, the servies was perfect. My room view to tokyo tower, so at night when the tower so bright, the view was so impressive. Another thing was the 400 years old japanese garden, overview from the restaurant. It was so lovely and beautiful gardern, especialy for jogging in the morning. The neigborhood around the hotel so convenient which many restaurants, café, stores. High recommands for New Otani Hotel.

Built in the 60s at a time when it was the best hotel in town, the New Otani may not have the flash of an ultra modern Hyatt, but it is a great hotel in a classic style. It is also immense with 3 towers, huge shopping areas and restaurants of both local and Western fare. It is well situated a short walk from a major metro line and has excellent access to all of the core Tokyo tourist sites. The biggest (best) surprise for me was the size of the rooms. One often reads that hotel rooms are quite small, and the New Otani's rooms are on par with any US sized hotel room...well appointed, and clean. The staff at the hotel were quite pleasant and cordial. I sampled the roof top dinner buffet and the garden breakfast buffet. The former was satisfactory, and the garden view buffet was excellent with great views of the garden. I highly recommend.

Have been at this hotel for about a week to prepare for and recover from the Tokyo Marathon. The service is perfect, each morning you get a newspaper (Japan Times incorporating New York Times International) at the sidebar of your room door. Free wifi, also option to plug in a cable. Enough space, great bed, your room gets cleaned each day. Options for having either a bath or a shower. And an extended room service assortiment, varied eating menu and even in-room massage (but didn't take this one). This hotel is perfect for staying when you run the Tokyo Marathon. It is situated in the middle of the start and finish line and there is even a bus transfer service that takes you both to the start at the Government Building as well as from the Big Tokyo Sight Congress Center after the finish line to this hotel. There are many good restaurants in the neighbourhood, though you actually wouldn't need those since there are 22(!) restaurants and many shops within the hotel building itself. The atmosphere is very relaxing. In the morning you can take a breakfast with the voucher you got when checking in your room. And on the top floor (40), the overview of the city and surroundings are beautiful! You can even see Mt. Fuji with good weather from one side. On the Garden Floor restaurant you have a great overview of a Japanse Garden, in which you can also take a walk. And in this restaurant they also have beautiful live jazz occasionally in the evening, played by a piano. And are you OK and want a burger, they have TOP hamburgers in the Vic restaurant that you can find on the ground floor restaurant. This is definitely a place that I can recommend and would re-visit.
