review_body: Spent four nights in this five-star business hotel. Good view from my 8th floor room but should have asked to go even higher for better view. Favoured by government and diplomats, it has splendid restaurants, a superb breakfast array in four restaurants, a beautiful garden and a sense of quiet competence. Peculiar lack of drawers for clothes but adequate cupboard space. Splendid triple king size bed and a big bathtub makes it my favourite in Tokyo.

Spent 3 nights at the Garden Tower. There was a small hiccup to begin with as there are actually TWO hotels that make up Otani with separate receptions/concierge etc. I went to wrong reception & so check in took much longer. The hotels are joined by an arcade of shops so walking between is a non issue.My room was on 35th floor offering views over the city. I could see snow capped mountains to the north, the Tokyo Skytree & the trees of the imperial palace gardens.There is a restaurant on the 40th floor that offers different views of the city & on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji in the distance.The rooms were faultless - large, lots of amenities, complimentary water bottles, free wifi, good lighting.All the staff I encountered spoke English so there were no communication issues. They were all very polite & eager to help.The hotel is close to a subway station so you can catch a train to the famous Shibiyu (sp?) crossing area or Ginza shopping district within 10-15minutes. The hotel itself has plenty of dining options but it's also a short walk to a local area that has all kinds of various restaurants in different styles & price ranges.

Hotel is actually a huge complex consisting of number of buildings, restaurants and shops and beautiful gardens. It is conveniently located close to both Subway and JR train stations. Plenty of shops and restaurants within the complex and nearby.

We booked a 7 night stay here and don't think we managed to see all of the buildings. It's bigger than hotels I have seen in Vegas! Our room was located in the garden tower. It took a few days to get our bearings but can't complain at all.we enjoyed the family mart for cheap sundries, we had a cocktail in trader vics, a beer in the bar on the 40th floor with excellent views and had breakfast at the garden view buffet. We went down the street mostly for our meals to save money. There is a hooters restaurant nearby and lots of Japanese restaurants and tea rooms. We liked that they don't accept tips in Japan. The nearest train station will take you most places on a Jr rail pass or cheap subway ticket and if you are feeling lazy you can get to roppongi for around £10 and Tokyo tower and zojo ji temple can be reached by foot from there. Also we enjoyed the room facilities such as kimonos, robes, fridge, bottled water, tea and coffee and excellent toiletries. The pool was closed as it's winter but the gardens are beautiful. The staff are so nice, respectful quiet and honourable people. You will have a great time here I would love to return to Japan some day but we both have tattoos so activities are limited.

Driving up you can't quiet help but hum the James Bond Theme tune. This hotel is a bit of an icon and a landmark in Tokyo. I only had one brief night, but fell for the place. At night go to the skyline bar and then return to the same level for breakfast. You won't be disappointed. Before you rush off to whatever awaits you take the time to see the gardens. They are wonderful. Put this hotel on your bucket list.

Gigantic building with multiple towers that seem to be all a different hotel (formula). Overall very good. Good room, all facilities. The queing at breakfast can be somewhat cumbersome, but excellent value for money.

Stay for 2 nights for conference at the main wing.New Otani hotel is very huge complex in Akasaka area. I think the history of this landmark was back at least 50 years ago.The room in garden wing is typical Japanese business hotel. The size is ok, and it is clean and comfortable like it should be. Breakfast is nice.Cannot say about price vs value as it was included in conference package.The location is great, easy 5 mins walk to few metro lines. There is Yodobachi above the station, and the alley at the back of station has plenty of food and entertainment options. Limousine bus for both airports stop here. Also, you can find family mart on 2nds floor of adjacent building.

Great location and excellent food and service. Try the japanese breakfast. Prices are high, but the experience is worthwhile. Very close to the business district and several other locations midtown Tokyo.

My first impression about this hotel is old. I checked later, and it is said it was built on 1960s. However, the hotel has undergone renovations. Interior is luxurious. Service is good. Although the hotel is huge, I've never got lost by asking any hotel staff I met. They explain in good English and showed the way, if necessary. The hotel has many restaurants and bars. For breakfast I may suggest 2 options: Garden restaurant, which has good view and a lot of seats, and Shitake restaurant near the lobby, just in case you're in a hurry then the lobby is only a few steps away. The one on 40th floor has good view, but limited seats although you have spare time to queue.I'd also like to suggest the bar in top floor, a good place to chill out with colleagues and friends in the evening. Hotel bed has good quality. I have no complaint for its cleanliness. It is also quite spacious.Happening places is 5-10 minutes away on foot, just in case you want to kill time at night. My suggestion is to choose a room that faces Tokyo Tower. The building has 3 wings. At least 2 sides of 2 wing are facing Tokyo Tower.

I love the cleanliness of this hotel, especially the towel. I've stayed 2 nights on the garden tower, and the room was good.2 special things from me from the breakfast were the food was great and the view from the breakfast place were stunning. You can choose several different places to have the breakfast and i tried the 40th floor, where you can see the whole city in the morning; and from near the lobby, you can have the window seat to see the garden with the small waterfall.Just a beautiful hotel, although from the main lobby to the garden tower where the room located, you need approximately 5-8 minutes walk.Nearby with the train station which made the visit on tokyo is very comfortable.

This hotel was very beautiful. We had a high floor facing the city. The gardens were beautiful. There was a buffet breakfast everyday.All staff that we met were very nice. I cant wait to stay with them in the future.

Nice classic quality hotel, with lots of amenities, nicely located near the subway, and a few good places for a meal and drinks. You can have dinner in the revolving rooftop restaurant for pretty good views at night. If you book a room on a high floor, and the weather is clear, you can also see my Fuji, which is a nice view to wake up to. The garden is very pretty .

The hotel is located 4 mins away from the nearest subway. The hotel lies in the midst of 3 subway stations, so it gives you option, depending on where you are heading out in Tokyo. Two streets away, there are numerous restaurants for your selection. If you are unsure where to go, ask the friendly English speaking concierge, they have a simplified map for all the good food around the hotel. It gives you numerous choices, so take your pick. The room key is not the card type but the typical metallic key, so you need to ensure you don't lose it. The room was very clean. The room comes fully equipped to serve our needs. The children liked the room very much as it was spacious. The TV programs, like in most Japanese hotels, were mainly in Japanese language, however if you figure out the controller carefully, it allows you to switch to English language. This switch only works if the program comes in English (e.g. news, Hollywood movies). Hence the children were able to understand the cartoons. This hotel has a unique feature within its vicinity. It has a historical garden which offers tranquility, while a water fall and peaceful swimming Koi gives it a beautiful and lush greenery setting. Whilst there, we saw numerous couples taking their wedding pictures in their wedding gowns and kimono. I would recommend that this garden is a must visit, if you stay here. But if you do not stay here, it is still worth a visit. Visiting is free for all.One tip though, if your room package does not comes with breakfast included. You may want to consider joining their hotel membership (ask at the front desk). This allows you free wifi access, breakfast comes in a special rate (almost halved the listed price) and late check out. I would recommend this hotel especially if you have children.

I've stayed a few times here. It's a big hotel with 2 area's. i staed in the garden tower.Service is good, rooms are a bit old fashioned and fit for Japanese people.Many restaurants in the hotel but also in the surroundings. Nice garden and swimming pool

i visited tokyo for my Asian holiday adventure and i decided to get a room in this hotel for the last minute and surprisingly i got a room. the room is nice and spacious and the service is great. just sad that i have to stay just 3 nights in tokyo.

We made a reservation for the basic room with a garden room and were upgraded to a junior suite (at twice the cost but not as much as the general rate, which is 4 times the cost). This hotel is amazing. The Japanese garden is beautiful and the service is impeccable. The closest train station is a 5 minute walk away and gets you on the Ginza line (which I find most convenient).Overall, a great stay at a good location in Tokyo

The hotel is quite dated. We were given a smoking room (even though we did not ask for one) and asked to change since we are not smokers. It took over 45mins to arrange a new room which is absolutely not acceptable after traveling so far. The main is a much better option. We were also not informed about any of the hotel facilities or breakfast options. Very unsatisfactory.

The hotel staff are very friendly and helpful the hotel is bigger then some cities, the gardens are amazing and our room was very comfortable. The hotel Restaurants are okay. The shops also around The hotel are interesting, so take time to look, l did not realise the airport is over an 1 hour away from the city. Tokyo is a beautiful city, with lots of gardens.

Went for business and stayed here for 6 nights. The most astonishing thing from this hotel are the japanese gardens. Itś very hard to find the middle of a hotel in Tokyo city. Room is one of the biggest I've stayed of all times I' ve been in Tokyo. Staff is superkind and helpful. Wifi works really well in all hotel. Our view was directly to Tokyo Tower: brathtaking.Breakfast is a 10. We could choose on 4 different places and my recommendation is the following: The Top, you should go for the views at least once but the buffet is shorter than in the others; The Garden, for me, quite recommendable, the continental breakfast was served directly on table and the views were directly to the garden so...amazing experience, and, for quality and more assorted breakfast, definitely go to Satsuki at the lobby in The Main building. Business Center is also very helpful and good. Hotel is quite classic but will not hesitate to stay again.

Tokyo is magical, and staying at New Otani was equally so. Apart from great service, room and food, there's this beautiful garden providing quietness one would not expect to find in the middle of such a big and noisy city. Tokyo is too big to walk around, but there's good places to be seen and have a drink even in the walking distance of the New Otani hotel.

We stayed in the garden tower for 3 nights. Check in was not available until 3 pm which was totally unreasonable for a hotel of this calibre. Rooms are OK, beds are wonderfully comfortable, but bathrooms very small. Long queue for breakfast on 40th floor next morning and it was likewise at the ground floor alternative restaurant. However, staff were always there to help and advise when asked, the shops on all levels are beautiful, but there is a lot of walking involved between the hotel facilities and restaurants. Don't miss the fabulous 400 year old garden, especially at night.

there are two buildings. if possible, choose the front building. it is closer to all facilities including the main entrance. you also have a better view of mt. fuji at the horizon on a fine day. there are 4 restaurants to choose for your inclusive breakfast. i like the old japanese restaurant on the first floor near the elevator of the back building. the food is great, the view of the japanese garden is awesome.

The allocation of tables at breakfast in the Satsuki coffee shop was very, very slow. This is the only place for breakfast open before 7am, and there was always a long line of people waiting. After waiting for 25minutes for a table, it was annoying to see that there empty tables, set up with a place setting, not being used. The manager was wearing an ear piece! was anyone telling him that tables were available for the long queue waiting outside?

Rooms rather small.Bathrooms old and oldfashioned.with only tub,no shower.Nothing to hold on to when you want to go into the bathtub.Staff hardly speaks more than a few words of english.A smell of food in the corridors.We changed hotel after 1 night to the younger sisterhotel New Otani.

this hotel is ideally located in center of Tokyo city. Service is quick and prompt, staff understand good English, very very polite and courteous. it's a large hotel, two separate breakfast restaurants, the garden one has a great view. the view of tokyo city from top floor restaurants is simply amazing. i stayed for 3 nights last week at garden tower, only down side was the Gym, they need to equip it better,

This hotel of over 1000 rooms has two entrances on two different streets. Bus will pull up at entrance to original 1960s hotel. From there it is up one floor to the checkin for that part of the hotel.The newer tower hotel is a 150 metre walk down a corridor to the check in. That check in is on floor 6 of a different street entrance. That entrance is to an office block and the hotel checkin being 6 floors up is not at all obvious.Once you have mastered these orientation difficulties you find that the coffee in the hotel cafe is very expensive but there is a small but useful mini mart on floor 2 of the tower block behind Tullys coffee shop. There is also a gourmet food store on ground floor of office / hotel tower building.There are two outstanding rooftop restaurants on top floors of both buildings. The revolving restaurant on top of main building has many different areas for many different foods, sushi, grill, sweets etc. The roof top of the tower building is great for breakfast but get there at opening time as a queue forms quickly.Hotel is a quality property close to the night restaurant strip and associated train station.Hotel has an amazing garden available for wandering in or gazing at from the window.

The Hotel New Otani is a great hotel, and has many restaurants on the property, along with many shops for buying gifts. The shops are not "touristy" shops, but yet range from local artworks, to high end boutiques. The rooftop restaurants and bars are a must see, and great for pictures of Tokyo City.The service is impeccable and they are always eager to help. The rooms can be a little old fashion when compared to five star hotels in the US, but they are still clean, and comfortable.

We stayed here in the garden towers for 4 nights when first arriving in Tokyo and it is simple massive. It has several entrances all which can be slightly confusing at first, especially the one leading down the escalators as the signage is not too clear. But the standard of the hotel and teh restaurants is very good we had no problems with the rooms or the service offered. It is located well and has many shops and bars within easy walking distance. We had breakfast each morning in the garden restaurant which offers great views of the Japanese garden within teh hotel grounds - well worth a visit by day or night when it is lit spectacularly well. Our room on the 32nd floor offered great views of Tokyo but if you want even better views go to the 40th floor bar or restaurant for stunning views - prices are quite expensive but then you are paying for the views. All round a really good quality hotel nice stay

This place is amazing, and huge. The accommodations are what one might expect in such a beautiful place. Our room came with one of those built in stereos that just get Japanese talk radio, probably news since my Japanese is not that good. The rooms were nice, and clean but somehow we suspect that it was once a smoking floor ( rooms/hallway). There is a slight stench of cigarette in the hallways, it is not that strong but you can smell it. The hotel also has a swimming pool but be aware that there is a time when it is closed for a month or two due to weather.Our stay came with breakfast vouchers and they do have 4 interesting places to eat breakfast. All of them are good and,one of the dining areas overlooks the 600 year old Huge garden, complete with a waterfalls and Koi pond. You can actually go and walk the gardens, when we went down and took a walk it started sprinkling, Good thing there is a bunch of umbrellas that you can use just sitting by the doorways. You just borrow and return. ( Awesome).The hotel is located in a very good area, it is attached to a small mall that has a coffee shop and a supermarket where you can buy food and drinks to take up your room, Sake and very delicious sandwiches. Go straight out the backdooor of the garden tower and you will easily see the stop for the train and across that is a wonderful streets filled with restaurants, shops(Bic Camera, where you can buy anything that you can think of) bars and etc. The streets are full and even at times you might think that an alleyway is dark and dangerous. It is not, it is one of the safest and cleanest place I have been.The hotel's facilities and location makes this one of my favorite places to stay while in Tokyo. You can stay in garden and reflect or step out and party with the crowd. A must Stay.

we had a lovely 3 night stay here, the hotel is beautiful, good breakfasts European and Japanese food, very tasty and plentiful. very clean rooms and all areas. Bed was hard and we will invest in travel pillows! The staff are wonderful, so helpful and polite.

The poor rate is not to be meant for the room (which are large and clean), neither for the location, but for the quality of service provided by people working at the front office.They are not able to provide even the simplest information!This morning my wife and me had to attend to a Tokyo city tour be booked several mounths ago. Our pick-up was planned at 7.50 a.m. at the hotel. At 7.30 we went at the reception with our reservation form and asked where the pick-up place was (the hotel is really large and has several receptions and entrance on different streets). None of the people working at the reception could give the information. A first receptionist asked a second one end both of them asked a third one. Then they asked a porter girl and suggested me to go asking to another reception which was located on the opposite side of the hotel.We went to this second reception and the receptionist didn't know where the pick-up place was, but a porter girl showed me the bus parking and told me that all the tour coaches stop there.Unfortunately it was 8.10 and our coach had already gone away.We lost our tour and the money we payed for it.That's a very bad way to deal with our honeymoon and THAT'S NOT THE SERVICE LEVEL A CUSTOMER MAY EXECT FROM A 5 STAR HOTEL!

Hotel New Otani consists 3 blocks, the main building, garden tower and garden court. Has its own shopping arcade and many restaurants. The garden is amazing with a fall. The rate is reasonable. Location is good, go to all shopping areas are not far. 5 subway stations are just a few hundred meters away. Airport limousines from Narita and Haneda stop in front of the hotel. Room is clean but not as big as i thought. I really like the bath towels, very thick, soft and good water absorbent.

A group of us were booked in here for a business trip. Some of us had moved across from the Marunochi which was far more modern. the New Otani is anything but new. It is also a very confusing hotel in terms of entries and exits and cabs often left us at the wrong side making for a walk to get across to reception. The service is at typical Japanese standards and very good but the atmosphere is so so dated. It's like something out of the early 1980s from top to bottom. Breakfast is served in a number of restaurants and the food was excellent in terms of quality. Would recommend you check out other newer hotels than this one of it's your first trip to Tokyo. Location is OK but not are great as others near stations that can get you straight onto the Yamomoto Line. Rooms are large but the bathrooms are tiny and have a very bad step that you don't see until you trip over it! Business Centre is good and there is WIFI access in there even though they tell you there isn't.

Although this large hotel is about 50 years old, it is well maintained, clean, and offers consistently good service – which was one of the highlights for me. In line with the enormity of the hotel, there is a wide variety of restaurants available of which three offer breakfast. I have had breakfast on the 40th floor in the Garden Tower and in the annex overlooking the lovely Japanese Garden and preferred the top floor due to the wide selection of food and the lovely view.My room in the Garden Tower was comfortable and spacious offering all the expected mod-cons. The interior was slightly dated but completely acceptable and did not detract from the overall experience. I understand that the rooms in the Main building has had a facelift in recent years. Free, fast and unlimited wifi is available throughout the hotel.Unfortunately the outdoor pool is closed during winter (including the more pleasant autumn days as was the case during my stay). An indoor alternative is available. It is part of the gym/ spa though and you will have to pay in the region of Y4000 (with a NOC membership card) to use this facility. There is a small and basic exercise room available in the Garden Tower at no cost. It is easy to get from Narita airport to the hotel with the airport limousine bus dropping and collecting from the hotel’s main entrance. This is also the cheapest option. The ride takes about an hour since Narita is situated quite far from the city centre.Although I generally prefer more contemporary hotels, I have enjoyed my three day stay at the New Otani and will certainly consider it again it during future visits to Tokyo.

The room we had was a bit dated and could do with a makover, however it was big and spacious. Something you won't find often in Tokyo. The view from our room was amazing, especially at night. All the staff were helpful and friendly, they had more then enough staff for all hotel guests to ask any questions too as there was never a big queue at reception. We tried the garden lounge breakfast as well as top of the tower breakfast. I preferred top of the tower breakfast, they had French toast and pancakes and the view was amazing from up there. The Japanese garden was beautiful and very serene. I highly recommend this hotel.

This is one massive hotel but as soon as you arrive you get a feeling that it needs to be brought up to date. That continues to the rooms certainly in the Garden Tower. They are in serious need of an overhaul. The staff are very friendly and helpful though so that makes up for it a bit. The pool area looks good but to get to it is a bit of a trek. We ended up not using it because the weather turned on us as we arrived. Like most hotels in Japan you have to pay extra to use the pool, but if you join their New Otani Club before you go and get your card through then it's free. If you don't bother joining at least the cost is a bit more reasonable than some of the other hotels (e.g. Intercontinental). The location is great with Shinjuku a nice walk away and Akasaka just across the road. Would happily return to the area but wouldn't go back to the New Otani.

A nice, big hotel, nothing special though. Quite a big selection of restaurants to choose from on the the ground floor. Great views from the nice rooms they have. Staff are VERY friendly. It's a strictly business hotel offering a lot of options to single travellers.

Very nice hotel. Nicely located in Tokyo. Most attractions are a short metro ride away and there's plenty in the local area to see. We had rooms on levels 36 and 23 over a six day period. Both rooms were excellent. Well appointed and with everything one needs. Two key observations. First, don't be silly like us and leave it until the last day to explore the beautiful Japanese garden which is on site here. It is a magnificent world class garden. See it early on as it really is a rare treat. Second, the restaurants here are rather old fashioned for breakfast and haven't kept up with dietary trends. There's barely a whole grain option available and all the cereals available are highly processed high sugar rubbish, basically. I felt like I was back in the 1980s. They need to modernize. Quickly. Beyond that though, the hotel was great.

Super service. Clean. Organized and efficient. The New Otani Hotel is very large and comfortable and well-located next to the Akasaka district. Our hotel room was spotless and very comfortable; it was here that we first experienced the heated and multi-featured toilet seat - amazing. The bathroom and hotel room were comfortably large. The room included two beds (a usual set-up in Japan), the obligatory desk, and a sofa.We ate in 2 of their 3 breakfast buffet restaurants during our 4 night stay and found each to be exceptional. We used concierge service for recommendations about where to eat in the nearby Akasaka district and enjoyed each eatery very much. The experience of strolling the nearby district which is loaded with restaurants and bars in complete safety - even late into the night - is wonderful. I loved seeing the black-suited, briefcase-toting 'salary men' first hand.Also, I experienced a need for medical help while in Tokyo and the concierge at The New Otani Hotel was super helpful in securing an appointment for me with an English speaking doctor (Johns Hopkins trained). I highly recommend The New Otani Hotel!

M y wife and I recently spent some time in Tokyo and on the advice of our travel agent stayed at the New Otani Hotel in the Garden Tower section. Well what can I say about this hotel, the room was superb, breakfast food in the ground floor buffet restaurant was very good as was room service and, frankly I just can't help praising this establishment.In every respect. All staff were attentive to an extent that almost made us feel embarrassed, and which I have not experienced elsewhere in recent times. They insisted in carrying bags, opening doors, summonsing lifts and providing assistance and directions when asked whilst politely informed us that they do not accept tips. A highlight is the view of the beautiful gardens from the down stairs dining room - well worth spending some time exploring.

My wife and I recently vacationed in Tokyo and stayed at this very nice and very large hotel. We were put in the Garden Towers on the 33rd floor and had a very nice few looking west towards Mt. Fuji which we had a clear view of our first two days. The room was also very clean and modern looking, however the beds were extremely small (doubles) and we were not able to put them together.Our reservation included breakfast each morning at 3 different restaurants (the hotel has over 20 restaurants), which we enjoyed each morning. We also dined at their Tempura restaurant our first evening which was very nice. The hotel staff we encountered were all extremely friendly and helpful, especially the concierge desk which we used and took advantage of many times throughout our stay.The hotel also has a beautiful garden, which we walked around on our final day there in Tokyo. Centrally located and a quick 5 minute walk to the nearest subway station, we enjoyed our stay here and would recommend to anyone planning a trip to this beautiful city of Tokyo.

Our family (2 adults + 2 pre-teen kids) recently had a very enjoyable stay at Hotel New Otani. We stayed in a very large garden suite in the Garden Tower which had excellent facilities, including 2 toilets, and a massive master bedroom which is separated from the rest of the suite by sliding doors. The view from the room was over the impressive hotel gardens and out over Akasaka Palace and western Tokyo. The hotel is located in a very convenient location with easy walking access to the Tokyo subway and metro train stations and the many restaurants in the Akasaka disrict. The numerous hotel staff are very friendly and helpful and our lack of Japanese language skill wasn't a problem. The hotel facilities are excellent with five restaurants available for breakfast, we stuck to Top (aptly named as it is on the top floor of the Garden Tower) and the Garden Lounge both were good but Top offered a better variety of food with a nice view over Tokyo. The Garden Lounge had a great view over the Japanese garden and felt a bit more relaxed than Top but the food was of a slightly lesser standard and variety. We would highly recommend this hotel and would stay here again if we were fortunate enough return to this amazing city!

Fabulous hotel, beautiful gardens, breakfast was fabulous and included in our trip. Staff always polite and helpful. My only criticism is that other then breakfast the hotel restaurants didn't really cater for vegetarians

Jan H
Norwich, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed at this hotel on a recent holiday in Japan. The staff, reception and concierge were very helpful and keen to help. We arrived at the hotel after a early flight from London and our room was ready. If you have the JR pass you can take the Narita Express to Tokyo station and then take the JR Choe line and come out at the Yotsuya Station. It is very straight forward and then a 10 mins walt to the hotel. The rooms are big for Japanese standards

Our last hotel after touring several cities in Japan, we were disappointed not to receive the excellent service we had come to expect. For example, both the concierge and reception desk refused our request to print out an e-mail Boarding Pass (at a time to suit their convenience), instead referring us to a Business Centre (for which we would have to pay) in a different part of this very large complex. I have requested this simple task at many hotels around the world and have never been refused before. The hotel boasts 30 restaurants; but what it doesn't mention is that the vast majority are closed / last orders by 9pm. So little opportunity for a pre-dinner drink in the bar. Our room was very traditional with a lovely view over the Tokyo skyline, we were offered a room upgrade in the more modern part of the hotel but as our stay was short we declined. The garden is beautiful and the outdoor pool is lovely. We used the Limousine bus service to Narita airport which was excellent. However overall we were very disappointed with the level of service in such a large hotel.

I stayed with my family in a Triple Room in the Garden Tower, on a high floor. The room was actually a suite, with separate rooms for sleeping and relaxing. The bedroom had three comfortable single beds, good closet and general space, well appointed bathroom with a second sink & mirror outside, which was convenient. The separate living area has a couch with separate easy chairs, working desk, and flatscreen TV. This room had a city view (see attached photo), looking down toward the nearby and very convenient Akasaka-mitsuke Tokyo Metro Station (Ginza and Maronouchi Lines). We did not have a breakfast package, but utilized the Family Mart and small supermarket within the same complex to source our morning fare. There is also a good coffee shop near the Family Mart. So many reviews note the historic on-site gardens, and rightfully so. The 400 hundred year old traditional garden is genuinely impressive (great for family photos!), and are a truly unique feature of this hotel. Within the gardens is a rather pricey restaurant in a very beautiful setting, as well as a chapel where a Christian fellowship meets on Sundays.Best way to get here from the airport is by airport bus, which drops off and picks up from the main entrance. Location is really very good, only a quick walk from Akasaka-mitsuke station, as mentioned, which gives easy access to the entire city. There is a major restaurant area on the street just behind the station (parallel to the main road), lots of interesting options. There is also a massive BIC Camera location right above the station, all you need for any electronics shopping.The area around the hotel apparently has lots of cherry blossoms in season - would love to stay again and experience that. I would definitely recommend this hotel, and would not hesitate to stay again.One last tip: before your visit, sign up for the New Otani Club. It is free, and a member card will be sent to you, entitling you to separate check-in area, discounts on breakfasts and restaurants, daily newspaper, etc. We used the discount to try out the otherwise quite expensive breakfast on the top floor of the garden tower with its panoramic views of Tokyo (and Mt. Fuji on a clear day). Breakfast is pretty good, although I would not pay full price for it. Eating area is a bit too utilitarian and cafeteria style for the price you pay. But maybe worth it at least once (with NOC discount), just for the views.

Actually the Otani was one of the first hotels I ever stayed in Japan as a tourist, over 12 years ago. Now I live here, and came back for a special occasion.The hotel is near Akasaka-Mitsuke station on the Marunouchi Line and Ginza line of Tokyo metro. Take Exit D at the end of a corridor, but this exit may close about 10pm. From Exit D, go towards the junction and left. The tower of the New Otani is a distinctive shape and if you see it on the web before going you'll find it easily. Lobby is on Floor 6.We had a room on floor 26 and had wonderful views towards Shinjuku. If you are facing in this direction the large wooded area and palace belong to the Geihinkan, where foreign dignitaries are received, and to the Crown Prince's palace.The room itself was a good size for Tokyo and had a large bed (that will vary of course with the rate), electronic safe (would take a modest sized laptop), fridge, desk, TV with international TV channels etc.The bed was very comfortable and the curtains blacked out the light very well. Any quibbles? Well, as a slightly older hotel, while it was well furnished, they could do with power points near the bed, for keeping up with our technology-obsessed times. That's all though. They had free WiFi, which many similar-priced hotels charge for.Good location for exploring Tokyo, wonderful Japanese garden (although the entrance can be tricky to find), and several (not cheap!) restaurants in the garden. Plus a convenience store ... somewhere in the hotel. Maybe on 2F, I forget.We had a nice stay and depending on price would come back for special occasions.

The service from the staff was extremely good (the best we had in Japan and we had good service everywhere) from the moment we walked in until we left for the airport. My husband and I decided to spend a bit more and stay here. The New Otani has 3 areas for stay: The Zen Executive, The Main and the Garden Tower. The Garden Tower has beautiful views of Tokyo and it's garden and we were given the 28th floor. The room was very clean and spacious (atypical of other standard Hotel rooms in Japan) with good quality toiletries. The view facing the garden was spectacular and that was what made the room. The breakfast on the 40th floor provides a very tasty breakfast buffet of both Western and Japanese fare and it was popular for breakfast because of the view. The Garden Restaurant on the main level(in this case, it's the 6th floor) has the best Garden view as it is slightly elevated from the Garden and provides a great view of the waterfall(this is one of the selling features of staying there). We had dessert there 2 nights and the desserts were delicious. We also had the Kobe steak dinner set at the Rib Steakhouse our last night at dinner and it was very good but it is on the Basement level so there is no view, no windows and dark. It was a special set for people who were staying at the hotel and a bit discounted so a glass of decent champagne and onion soup was included in the meal. We also found that the location was ideal for us as it was only 2-4 stops to any of the major districts and one stop to Rappongi and Ginza taking the Marubouchi Line(Akasaka Mistubashi is the stop for the hotel on the line). If you walked it was a 20 minute walk to Rappongi or Ginza and a 45 minute walk to Tokyo Station. The airport limo bus also picks people up to go to Narita or Haneda(less time availability for Haneda) and the Hotel Bell Captain can arrange for seats that you can charge to your room. The per person cost is 3100Yen to go to Narita and well worth not having to take the subway and train/bus and lugging large pieces of luggage during rush hour in Tokyo. It takes about 90-120 minutes depending on the time of day and they stop at 6 hotels before going to the airport but the ride is very comfortable so give yourself 2 hours for commute. The Bell captain also asks which airline so he can give you the right terminal to get off at and it is written on the baggage tag so that the airport limo driver knows which bags get off at which terminal. It is quite organized like everything in Japan. The reason why I only gave it a 4 star is because the rooms need to be updated in the Garden Tower. While clean and spacious, it looks outdated and a little tired. Also, the stores in Basement level need to be refreshed as the styles in all the stores are old fashioned and matronly and it seemed that no one ever went in any of the stores.The service was a 5+ and everybody spoke English and tried to make our stay effortless. Book longer in advance and take advantage of the hotel deals. If you sign up to be a New Otani member(free membership), there are some discounts you can receive. I believe the New Otani is in 10 other cities in Japan, One in Beijing and one in Honolulu so may be worth signing up. We signed up to get a discount at the breakfast buffet(the membership was immediate once we completed the form) as that was not included in our room price.P.S. Also family friendly as all the hotels we stayed.

We stayed here as part of a tour group, in the Garden Tower. Service was excellent, from start to finish. The staff are extremely polite and helpful.The room was on a high floor, with a beautiful view of the Tokyo skyline. It was clean, but could use some updating. (There was an actual room key.) There was an abundance of amenities, that were replenished daily. The bathroom had low light.The hotel is in a very good location. There are a variety of stores and eateries within walking distance. There are several restaurants, and family Mart within the hotel. A Metro stop is a very short walk away, from the Garden Tower entrance. (Hotel staff provide umbrellas if it is raining.)Breakfast at Satsuki, in the main lobby was excellent, consisting of both Japanese and western options.We had a pleasant stay.

We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights and it was an excellent choice.The service was gentle and very polite. The room (34th floor) had a stunning view, perfect daily service and always clean.Breakfast was nice (top roof at 40th floor) with a good variety of western choices.Akasaka mitsuke station is just close to the hotelVery good experience

Very good hotel with some excellent restaurants and a fantastic ornamental garden which provides a great view for breakfast. Absolutely huge however so always depart 10mins early for any meetings just to get out of hotel! Good views over the city.

The one thing that sets this hotel apart from many is the gorgeous garden with waterfalls that will truly mesmerize you. This sprawling hotel is like a city in itself with restaurants and shopping, a chapel, and even a pool during the summer. The rooms are clean, well-maintained and comfortable, and the bar is well-stocked. However, it's quite a stroll from the nearest stations, but it's worth the walk.

I've stayed at this hotel three times now - twice on business and once on while holiday. The service is always exceptional. The rooms, while not fancy, are always clean and quiet, many times with an excellent view. The staff will always go out of their way to assist, and the Garden Cafe buffet breakfast is an incredibly peaceful way to start the day. The onsite restaurants should be appreciated mainly for their convenience rather than the level of their product, especially given the great selection of offsite restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. The close proximity to the metro is a huge bonus as it's very easy to get anywhere in Tokyo from the New Otani. I look forward to my next visit!
