review_body: We spent four nights at New Otani on the 30th floor of the Garden Tower and had a very pleasant stay.Excellent, courteous and well spoken staff at every point of our stay (managers please note!).Fantastic view from room 5007 over the lovely hotel gardens and on over some amazing Tokyo skyscrapers.Breakfast on the 40th floor was an excellent buffet, helped by our New Otani Club membership card which got us a window seat each morning, nearly spent more time gazing out the window than eating! Good selection of fruits, pastries, western and Japanese breakfast goodies. Constant top ups of coffee and tea from the friendly staff.The New Otani, Tokyo, is approx 8 mins walk from the Yotsuya JR station or only 5 mins to the Akasaka Mitsuke metro station so very easy to get about.Lots of restaurants and coffee shops of all costs just past the metro station so you will not go hungry. Several convenience stores also for those little necessities.Down point: the pool was FULL of children all day, every day, so we gave that a miss, great shame that.An adults only pool would go down well as there were extensive other sports facilities, tennis, gym, etc.The garden was lovely to walk around in the heat of the August day.Would stay again.

We stayed here for four nights as part of a cruise. The place is enormous with two separate accommodation towers on a 10 acre site, with beautiful ornamental gardens. It's slightly impersonal with a reception that is constantly busy. There are a number of different types of bars with happy hour in Trader Joes our favourite as is the view from the revolving restaurant. There are some interesting areas close by with a number of local bars and restraints. The metro stations are an easy walk and like the rest of Tokyo are a joy to explore in what is one of the safest feeling cities we have visited.

This is really three hotels linked by a 100m walkway.The rooms are very spacious. Try to get one as high as possible facing the gardens of the hotel and Imperial Palace.The back entrance nearby is less than 200m from a street full of restaurants.

We stayed in this hotel for family vacation. It has many restaurants, and close by to 3 train station. If you are staying at Garden tower, closest station is Akasaka-mitsuke exit D. Many eateries nearby, close to station, and away from crowds. This hotel has beautiful Japanese garden, usually busy on weekends with weddings.

The check in was efficient and quick. The rooms were clean and tidy but dated. The hotel was the best in the city a few years ago but they have not moved with the times. The hotel is huge with lots of rooms. The garden is well maintained and is a must to visit before you leave. Breakfast was included and there were many options and restaurants which would accept the breakfast coupon. There are many restaurants in the hotel which leaves one with good choice. The use of the pool would incur an extra charge of US$25 per person which I found annoying. The gym was small with limited choice. Of course Japanese hospitality was evident all thought our stay in this hotel. Staff were extremely courteous and always seemed to go out of the way to help.

The room was very clean and tidy, and the gardens were a highlight by themselves. Breakfast was very nice with many options and good variety as well as stunning views from the 35 floor.Overall was a great experience. Would stay again definately.

This hotel is centrally located and near to the great garden. You can reach out to the center of the city Akasaka, where you can get into train/bus. Also, there are lot of shopping area and restaurants like "Ninja" (Do not miss this). This place is near the round-about and near the exit of Akasaka rail station. You will enjoy the way they take you to the table. You have Starbucks, Bic Camera for electronic shopping.Enjoy the stay with good food in the restaurants - try the Sky bar. The rooms are good with all necessary amenities.

Our room was spacious and had a king bed! The shopping in the hotel, as well as its restaurants are quite good. There are fine local restaurants nearby, as is a Metro station. The breakfast buffets all across this property were top notch, and there was even a "western style" breakfast buffet available. A great stay.

- Very central location but takes 15 mins on foot to get the bus or train station- Nice view and reasonable size of room. Ceiling and Bathroom is old style. There is no standing bathroom- Love the breakfast here because guest can choose between international style or japanese style (in 2 different restaurant). Japanese breakfast taste so well.- Staff was very useful and kind. They help me to receive and send personal package to my friend.- Bar was close so early which makes me have nothing to do at night

My family of three was only staying in Tokyo for one night, so we decided to splurge, at least a little. It turned out that little splurge was a lot, because this is decidedly more upscale and grander than we had expected. That's not to say it was an unpleasant experience, quite the contrary. The staff were impeccable: beyond polite and consistently helpful. The room, on the 29th floor, turned out to be an amazing three-bed suite with a lovely peekaboo view of Tokyo Tower and Rainbow Bridge. The entire complex contains high-end restaurants and retail galore, but also meets the needs of more frugal travelers, with some reasonably priced food options as well as the added bonus of a post office on site, should you -- like we did -- require cash when you're only carrying a U.S. credit card. And the grounds? Wow! We spent the morning wandering through the palatial garden, in the rain no less, and it was completely breathtaking. Other bonuses: - The hotel is pretty well-situated. It's about a 10-minute walk from the Yotsuya rail station, and there is signage directly outside the station leading the way. There's a pretty bustling commercial area in the vicinity of the station as well, so if you want something less high end to nosh, you can easily stop there.- It's hard to find hotels that accommodate families with older children, but they did have three-bed suites. The beds are about American full size, so they sleep one adult comfortably. Well, kind of comfortably. The mattresses were as firm as they come. There were also French doors between the bedroom and the living room, so the late sleepers/early risers could cordon themselves off without disturbing each other.The downside:If you're a laid-back, shorts-and-T-shirt traveler, you may feel out of place. We never received anything but utmost courtesy while we were there, but there was an air of business-formal to most of the complex.

While the staff is incredible the hotel does not reflect the best of what Tokyo offers. Too big and impersonal. More suited to Las Vegas. One good recommendation is the French style brasserie to the left of the Garden Court tower. Bit of Paris in Tokyo.

We stayed here for the last three nights of a long trip around Japan. We were not disappointed. We would normally try to stay in small intimate style hotels but this had been decided for us in advance as we were on a travel package.This is the largest hotel in Tokyo. Its centrally situated and to give you some ideaa of size. There are 3 individual high rise blocks within the hotel grounds. It has a very large garden area with waterfalls etc. There are approximately 120 boutique style shops within the complex ( very expensive). We think around 17 restaurants of which 4 or 5 serve European style food. One of the restaurants is revolving and on top of one of the accomodation blocks.We found the staff to be very courteous as had been are experience in Japan wherever we went.We stayed on a B&B basis but we ate in the hotel in a different restaurant each night. The food was superb and we loved each of our different dining experiences.The gardens are very special and we spent quite sometime soaking up the experience.As you would expect from a top 5 star hotel it had all the amenities and could cater for large scale operations most efficiently. On one of the days whilst we were there they had 9 weddings running on the same day!We felt that this large complex was very well managed and we were quite comfortable staying here inspite of our normal "small is beautiful preference"We had a bedroom on the 22nd floor which had fine views and all the comforts one would expect from a hotel of this class.We would highly reommend it to anybody visiting Tokyo

The sheer size of this hotel can be both spectacular and daunting, with 3 towers linked by long walkways and the biggest hotel shopping mall I have ever seen. Rooms very comfortable and quiet. Views of the hotel's large garden and the city at large were spectacular from our 27th floor room in the garden tower, and even more so from the 40th floor restaurant. Said to be earthquake-proof too. Less mobile guests might struggle with long walks to their rooms.

We stayed at garden court room for 3nights.Since they offered special plan we stayed very reasonable price at 45m2 spacious room.From the room we enjoyed the nice view of the City and also enjoyed beautiful Japanese garden of the hotel.My son loved koi fish pond and the water fall.Well stay here when we have a chance for the next time.

Great hotel ... well located for everything and with amazing views of the city and Mt Fuji.We stayed in a Junior Suite on the 36th floor which was very spacious by Western standards (so enormous for Japan) and it was truly a fantastic room. The hotel was slightly let down by the breakfasts ... large queues for entry and very medicore western food, although the Japanese breakfast was very good. All staff were amazingly helpful and friendly.

We picked this hotel because it was across the street from the university my daughter wanted to visit. We had been warned to expect small rooms in Japan, but our room was very spacious and comfortable. It is close to multiple metro stops and tons of little restaurants, which is good because the hotel restaurants are very expensive. The hotel employees were so helpful. The gardens are beautiful. We had a great experience and will definitely stay there again on any visits to Tokyo.

Great hotel with good location. We were a family of 6 adults, who stayed for 4 nights in the Garden Tower. Had two triple rooms, big ones compared to the standard of Tokyo. Clean rooms, nice and helpful staff, who spoke good English. Very close to metrostation and to smaller streets with plenty of restaurants. Nice Japanese garden. Only drawback was that the pool wasn´t open.

This is a hotel founded by a sumo wrestler and if one wants a room bit less expensive than many of the 5 Star international hotels, this is it. Very centrally located, close to major metro station with easy access to Ginza, Shibuya, Shinjuku vicinity. One can eat different types of food without leaving the hotel at all and great food at that. However, if you want quick or decent restaurants outside of the hotel, there are many at Akasaka, a walking distance from the hotel near metro station. Love their morning buffet both western style overlooking the beautiful Japanese garden and Japanese, Chinese, Western style buffet breakfast at the main hotel. Also, very good. If you want a hotel near by and less expensive, try Excel Hotel Tokyu in front of,Akasaka Mitsuke Metro station, but I like Otani.

This is a very large hotel with over one thousand rooms. We stayed in the Garden Tower for three nights as part of a tour group and had a great room on the 35th floor. Room was quite large with very modern bathroom. Staff were very helpful at all times. Japanese garden which is part of the complex was beautiful. While the hotel has numerous restaurants only three or four are open for breakfast and don't open until 7 am so with numerous tour groups staying at the hotel, the breakfast queues are ridiculous. Apart from this issue which could be fixed by simply opening them earlier, it is a great hotel to stay at.

Great hotel, all staff were extremely friendly and helpful and spoke good English. The gardens were beautiful to walk around. Stayed in the Garden Tower and had a wonderful view of Tokyo Tower, the room was very clean. Had dinner at the Jazz buffet one night and would certainly recommend it, the food was great. The location was great for getting around Tokyo. Would definitely stay here again.

I stayed here on business, and the location was fine for those purposes but not very convenient for any exploring at leisure. The gardens were beautiful and there was a huge choice in restaurants, although I found most quite expensive. At breakfast although it was included you had to pay extra to upgrade to any hot items, which I think could have been clearer on booking and made it overly expensive for what you got.The room was fine, but a bit of a trek at times!

I was in Tokyo with friends and stay at this hotelThe room is so nice. The garden is so beautifull and it located beside Garden lounge inside the hotelBut the main lobby and the tower which room located are a bit so far. i love the hospitality of the hotels teamarigatto see the pic at my instagram jimmy.teddy.7

We had a room in Garden Tower, floor 34, and after staying in Kyoto and other Asian hotels this felt very basic and dated. It was clean, and well maintained, but window very low and the room felt claustrophobic and airless. We were told air conditioning was 40 years old and it did get going after a while and some assitance.It's location is okay, but not great, it isn't really near anything, except a Starbucks and the Ninja restaurant!I was told if we wanted to use the pool we would have to pay AUD10.00+ as we were guests, this was a discount price - i have never had to pay to use a pool in a hotel where I was a guest before. There is a nice garden, and many restaurants, all of which are quite expensive for the quality, even in Tokyo.What really let the stay down was the quality and standard of food in the restaurants - we used Top and Satsuki - more choice in Satsuki, but very basic. Breads and danish were dry, pancakes like cardboard, coffee below average. Large range of Japanese meat and fish based items (we are vegetarian and had little choice). It was very business hotel breakfast, not luxury holiday.The staff were very polite throughout the hotel and concierge was very helpful and efficient assisting and making bookings.Complimentary WIFI worked well and speeds quite good.

A very large hotel with superb gardens. We enjoyed our stay here and having a room overlooking Tokyo and the garden was a bonus. I had a problem with my laptop and the wifi connection and within 5 mins I had someone at the door to solve the problem. The only downside was that sometimes you had to queue at breakfast in the main restaurant due to large size of the hotel . There are many restaurants within a short walking distance, serving many different types of food, at very reasonable prices

We started our Japan adventure at this hotel. After an overnight flight we arrived to be told that our room wouldn't ready until 3pm, so we weren't overly happy. Having said that there were things to do to pass the time. The Japanese gardens on the hotel grounds were beautiful and it was relaxing just wandering around, looking at the fish etc. There were shops within the hotel and we were able to use one of the restaurants to top up on coffee. Although we didn't venture too far from the hotel we were told the train station was a short walk away.When we did get to our room we were impressed by the space and comfort. The bed was huge, the décor modern and very comfortable and the bathroom, with heated toilet, was clean and light. We had breakfast in the top floor restaurant with beautiful views and a great selection of dishes to suit any traveller. The staff were very apologetic at the delay with our room so I didn't see it as being a fault with the hotel itself. We would definitely stay there again.

3 massive buildings with everything you can imagine. A Japanese garden, a pool and fitness, mid to high end fashion shops, a supermarket, arts and souvenirs, all different types of restaurants with stunning sky views on 17th (in the Main) and / or 40th floor in the Garden Tower. The service is excellent and friendly and the breakfast serves every taste of all the continents. The location is quite central, has a metro station nearby and the nice places to visit are not too far, like the Akasaka Palace and the beautiful Eastern Gardens by the Emporor's Palace.

Stayed here for four nights as part of a tour of Japan - it is an international hotel so not exactly full of Japanese character. It has a beautiful garden that is worth spending time in. There are plenty of eating and shopping opportunities close by and a couple of good little supermarkets in the hotel itself. It is really conveniently located for public transport as well. All in all a good place to enjoy Tokyo from.

Hotel New Otani would have to be the largest hotel I have ever stayed in. With 1,479 rooms, this place is massive! The rooms are very comfortable and a nice size with all the amenities you would expect. The gardens are beautiful, nice gym and pool and even a shopping mall with a mini supermarket. There are plenty of restaurants and a great bar/restaurant that slowly rotates so you get a 360 Degree view of Tokyo. Although not in the heart of town the train stop is a 5 minute walk from the hotel. In fact it is quicker to walk to the train stop than to walk from one end of the hotel to the other. As this is a large hotel it is always crowded in the main areas, a bit like a Boxing day sale. But most importantly the service was excellent.

Spent 4 nights here, had breakfast but ate out in the local area that has lots of restaurants at reasonable prices. The breakfast was good but the eggs and bacon were normally cold. You have to ask the chefs to make the fried eggs, but the bacon will still be cold. It has a very pretty garden for a nice morning or evening walk. There are long queues at breakfast but they go down reasonably quickly.

Western style with Japanese flare. Lovely gardens and good area for restaurants. So many shops in hotel it is a bit like a cruise ship on land. Service was very good but cost was high. Clean and nice view of the Tokyo Tower from our room.

This hotel is huge plus it has a surprisingly large and impressive garden with a waterfall right in the centre of Tokyo. The public areas are very busy and there is always a queue for breakfast at the top of the Tower and at the main ground floor restaurant from 7am. Breakfast selections were varied but a bit uninspiring and the cooked food barely hot. There was very little fresh fruit and too much tinned fruit, both of which were a surprise to us. Similar quality hotels do not seem to have the same problem.

Lovely hotel, very clean and all staff welcoming. Had room on 34th floor with wonderful views over the City. Breakfast taken on the 40th floor had stunning views over Mount Fiji. Plenty of choice for breakfast, and for evening meal we found a couple of small very reasonably priced restaurants in the basement area behind the shops. All in all a very delightful stay. Free wifi in bedrooms and Hop on/Hop off bus stops in the hotel car park. Lovely Japanese Garden in the grounds with huge Koi Carp!

We spent 4 night in the Garden Tower on 22nd floor, so noise was not an issue. The hotel is big with 4 restaurants and loads of rooms. Our room was a good size with a double bed and all the bits,the dressing gown was nearly the right size for a large man! The hotel is close to the metro station ( the metro system is very easy to navigate).The staff were all very friendly and helpful, our cleaning lady was very cheery. Breakfasts were good, with the one on the top floor getting crowded very early. Lots of choices for eating but with 4 star capital city prices. A good range of restaurants were only 5 minutes away. The lovely garden was a bit chilly.

We stayed here for four nights in April 2015. Room on the 34 th floor after changing from a smoking tomon smoking room. Very big hotel. Easy to get lost! Breakfast is the best so much choice. Room a little tired. Staff really nice. Would come back any time!

Well situated near central Tokyo with adjacent extensive Japanese gardens (they were there before the hotel). Well appointed rooms.Splendid views from breakfast restaurant on top floor of one of three multi-storey blocks.Staff very good, almost too obsequious at times.

There are great things about this hotel - its comfortable, clean, breakfast is excellent, location is really central....However, it feels a bit tired (old fashioned, in a not so good time warp kind of way), staff are stand offish, I would go out of my way to stay here again.

Stayed for 4 nights for the Tokyo Marathon. Staff are exceptional! Incredibly polite and helpful and most had a good command of the English language.A very large but well managed hotel with a variety of Restaurants offering Western Food and a super Sky Bar.Rooms are spacious and clean with a good bathroom. The hotel has a beautiful Japanese Garden, a most welcome retreat from the busy city. Within walking distance of the Metro.Definitely recommended and would return.

A NYC type hotel in Tokyo with spacious rooms that are well appointed. Close to all and provides all so you have your choice. This hotel offers multiple restaurants. Suggest a high floor away from the elevator.

The New Otani was built for the 1964 Tokyo Olympics and feels that way - from the ridiculously expensive restaurants, bars and shops to the 'modern' amenities in the rooms (including a 'vintage' modern built in radio alarm clock) this place feels very dated now. If you want to feel like in a 60s-70s-80s Bond movie this place is for you. The traditional garden with waterfall and restaurants is charming and the view on the garden from the downstairs restaurant is spectacular. the top floor restaurant has glimpses of Mount Fuji on clear days.The gym/pool access is NOT included in your room price and is again very expensive. Crazy!zBar Capri is a time capsule in itself (and smokers can smoke inside).This is a great place for a few days if you need to be in that part of Tokyo for business and if somebody else pays the bills. Avoid as a holiday hotel or with a family.

The hotel is extensive with a large range of pricy shops and numerous restaurants. As other posters have stated the price of meals in the hotel is a little eye watering. Our room has a wonderful view of the city of Tokyo and the imperial guest house. The hotel seems to be a business hotel rather than tourist and perhaps thus explains their attitude to tourists. The room is spacious, clean with a great range of toiletries in the bathroom. The decor is very conservative. The windows are single glazed so even though we are on a high floor traffic noise is considerable. The BUT... we flew in to Tokyo with a twelve hour flight arriving in Tokyo early morning and arriving at the hotel at 09.00 completely exhausted. Been up nearly 24 hours by this time. The check in time is 15.00 so had to sit around until then before getting our room. So if you are arriving early in the day book the room for the night before also so you can access the room immediately.The staff seem friendly but I get the impression that it's their job to be so rather than genuinely wanting to serve.

This is a high quality hotel very near to a metro station making transfers easy and getting about town straightforward. It is a vast complex with many rooms and plenty of choices to eat. Rooms are modern, large and well furnished. Maid service is of the standard you would expect. Beds are somewhat lie and hard for my lines but I slept well nevertheless. Staff are friendly and helpful. Hotel has lovely gardens and a stunning waterfall that looks amazing at night.Only drawback with this hotel is that eating in is very expensive. £30-40 for an evening buffet and £20 for a beer and burger. The upside is there are a number of great restaurants within walking distance including a couple of great sushi places. Anyone there on a Saturday afternoon can watch the Japanese equivalent of ladies who lunch taking tea.

Stayed on my recent visit to Japan. Got a great deal so decided to stay here. I always felt that a hotel like this was too expensive, and didn't even look, boy I was missing out.Yes maybe a little more$$, but definitely worth it. Service is great.....you actually feel you are someone important, even if you are a "nobody" like me. The facility itself is huge with many restaurants and shopping to choose from. For those of us who prefer English, most staff I was in contact with seemed fluent. My favorite part was the garden. Beautiful set up with lots of greenery....you would forget that you are in the middle of Tokyo.Would definitely recommend at least considering. You won't be disappointed.

great service, choice of restaurants, convenient location to Metro - wide choice of bars,restaurants,shops & Karaoke within 200 yards. Great city views from 30th floor. Wonderful traditional garden to look out on from the restaurant. Kettle & Fridge :)Huge beds.

10 days on floor 35 of the new Otani Garden Tower just finished. Booked two rooms, both facing in different directions both with amazing views. Check in was quick and efficient. Staff always friendly and welcoming. Hotel is perfectly positioned for nearby metro stations which are very easy to travel through using a Suica card (instructions for buying and topping up in English). This is a large hotel so take some time to look at the shop and restaurant guides in the hotel room. There is a Familymart which stocks everything you could possibly need, or have forgotten. Tullys Coffee house is also very handy and serves a very good value morning set and were particularly accommodating to the vegetarians in our party. The New Otani gardens are stunning and a very pleasant way to start the day with a wander around them. The Travel agent in the hotel called Linda is very helpful at arranging trips and advising on what to see and do. Beds were very comfortable. Water is provided in the good sized room each day. Shampoos etc are of a high quality (Kanebo). Gowns and slippers are provided. There is an in room safe. Tea and coffee making facilities are also in the room.The surrounding area has a variety of restaurants, cafes and shops including the always popular Bic Camera. The hotel is easily reached form the airports by using the Limousine bus which takes you right to the door. We were two couples, 20's and 50's and all enjoyed our stay. We loved the novelty of having a doorbell at each room instead of having to bang on the door!. Another plus was how efficient the lifts were (always important when on a high floor) we never had to wait long for one. All agreed we would definitely return. We have stayed in other Tokyo hotels but this will now be our choice. It was my birthday during the visit and on returning to the room in the evening there was a cake box with tasty cake and lovely message. Thanks to the staff all of who were superb.

We stayed at the New Otani for 4 nights in a twin room. Firstly, the room was really spacious which is a huge plus in Tokyo. The beds were really comfy and overall the room was clean. The bathroom was also spacious and clean. We also had a great view of Tokyo, and Mt Fuji which was a great surprise to wake up to! The staff were very friendly and accommodating. Other positives were fast, free wifi and a free bottle of water for each guest per day. The hotel is well located, with a number of subway stations in short walking distance. There are also a number of convenience stores and plenty of restaurants located close by in Akasaka. We would recommend this hotel for those who are after a comfortable stay in Tokyo.

Travelled to Tokyo for business and couldn't get in my preferred hotel due to it being over booked to stayed in the Otani for several nights. Hotel is as all good Tokyo hotels are, clean, well appointed with impeccable staff. Room was small but nice and in what I would call old style Japanese as was the hotel. Its certainly not "on-trend" like some international brands but more how I imagine many hotels were a few years back in Tokyo which I think is probably part of its charm. Definitely less international visitors here than in some other hotels but again I enjoyed that.Only giving it 3 stars mainly because the location is a little out of the way for central business districts and because I would have preferred the décor to be more up-to-date for the price paid.

Stayed in Hotel New Otani Tokyo early December '14 for 3 nights. Arrived late evening, opened curtains early next morning. Beautiful view over Tokyo with Mt. Fuji in the back. Excellent breakfast in garden tower. Rooms are clean and tidy, stuff is super friendly. Location is good. Would return anytime.

This hotel is massive and as a result had several dining options ( 4 different places to go for the buffet breakfast). The breakfast in the tower has a breathtaking panoramic view of tokyo and we were lucky enough to see Mt. Fuji on a clear morning. The staff were very helpful and friendly and were able to get us started with a map and guide to Tokyo and the metro. It is a short walk ( less than one minute) to a metro which goes directly to Shibuya crossing. Like all the hotels in Japan they come with handy toiletries like a comb, toothbrush and razor. Large comfortable and clean rooms.Would stay again!

I am staying in The New Otani Hotel at Tower Garden from Dec 25, 2014 to Jan 1st, 2015.Only left 2 days more to have nice experience staying in the heart of Tokyo.This hotel offer you the Garden View experience, if you stay at odd number room you will see the beautiful Garden View and Koi Fish (I guess it's gonna be more beautiful in April when Sakura blossom)If you stay at the other side you will see the Tokyo Tower and Sky Tree.So when you arrive at the hotel, you will find the Shopping center and take lift to go to lobby to 6 floor and take another lift to your room. the room as worth as your spending and I dont have any complain except the key room not using card.and also hmm I guest I cant find the Lotion at the bathroom (since it's winter I need lotion)Easy to o anywhere from here, if you bored with Family Mart at 2nd floor you can walk to daily yamazaki to buy dinner (also there's Bic Camera)

For this busy city, we found for the 10th floor the room was amazingly quiet - never heard a neighbor or a car. The staff were all over to help out to any needs from restaurant reservations to where to get a manicure. Staff communicated with us in perfect English. It is a very large hotel, but it did not feel overwhelming. It was nice to have the choice of restaurants, but we were particularly enjoyed the Garden restaurant overlooking the gardens. The ambiance of the restaurant lowered my blood pressure of the hectic week. The gardens were terrific and even though it was very cold, it was very enjoyable to relax while the rushing of Tokyo was just outside the area. Very easy to get a cab here. The Tokyou hop on/off bus stops here too. Pretty close to the Akasaka district, but we ate out once in the area and were not so impressed. There is even shopping in a mall area in the adjoining tower, but I was very disappointed with the manicure I had in the small shop. We had free wi-fi, but do not know if that was true for every room.

I have stayed in the New Otani on at least four occasions for business travel, each time in the Garden Tower.On a practical level, it's a perfectly satisfactory business hotel. The rooms are comfortable and generally quite spacious (by Tokyo standards), although decor has been dated in the rooms I've had. It is a huge hotel with a wide choice of restaurants and bars. It's conveniently located close (c.3 or 4 minutes' walk) to two metro stations. Internet works. You have to ask for an ironing board and iron, but it does arrive.I don't often notice such things but the Garden Lounge, the main breakfast restaurant, has a genuinely relaxing and pleasant ambience. The hotel's gardens are beautiful.One downside is that there is a significant additional charge to use the health club. There is a free-to-use gym, but it is tiny (4 or 5 machines). This factor is the main reason why I have knocked off a star.There's something else about the New Otani that works on a more subjective level. It has a 1960s faded glamour about it - half-close your eyes, and you can almost see David Niven chatting to Twiggy in the lobby. This adds absolutely nothing tangible to my work trip. And I still know I'd be disappointed if the office asked me to stay anywhere else in Tokyo. (Except maybe the Park Hyatt.)

The hotel has been around since the 1968 Olympics but that doesn't mean it is outdated. The rooms are fine even if not up to the standards of today's hip and super luxury hotels. The service is also quite good, as can be expected from the Japanese. The biggest plus are the gardens and the bewildering number of restaurants in and around the hotel. To top it all, the rates for both the rooms and the food were quite reasonable, thanks partly to the weakness of the yen.

Stayed her for 3 nights on business in October 2014 , was looking forward to my visit as some Japanese colleagues had said that this was one of the best hotels in Tokyo , unfortunately this was not my experience .Hotel is very big and has an almost Vegas style layout . This hotel opened sometime around 1964 and was used in the filming of the James Bond film " You Only Live Twice " with Sean Connery , I am sure that in the Sixties this hotel was state of the art , unfortunately the same cannot be said now . The rooms are ridiculously small with very basic bathroom facilities ( except for the very futuristic toilet with heated seats and remote controls , yes really ) and are just not suited to todays travellers expectations Breakfasts were ok but nothing special , location was also good , overall as title says , a little disappointed . Tokyo however is just absolutely Incredible and somewhere everyone should visit;

The New Otani Garden Tower is a 40 storey building as part of the hotel complex built for the 1960s Olympics.The hotel complex is big with over 1500 rooms,38 bars and restaurants as well as shops and a convenience shop for many things. All very good.We stayed 4 nights and had excellent sized room on the 28th floor. Great bathroom and a great start. Fast lifts mean you don't notice the height. There are 3 breakfast rooms serving both Western and Japanese food and one special to Japanese food. Staff are excellent at service and general assistance and made us very welcome in this new city. English is not a problem at all as it is for the most part in Tokyo.Obviously eating can be done in the hotel but most cheaper restaurant facilities are a few minutes walk in the Akasaka district where most have English menus if needed.The hotel is an excellent base in a superb location to get around locally as well as the city. Explore the hotel itself and enjoy many options that can only be had in a quality hotel.Several tips go with the hotel:-Tip..catch the subway at the Akasaka-,mitsuke station (g5) near hotel and remember it is a good line for Shibuya crossing,Ueno park and Ginza.Tip..as the hotel is large remember the best way in and out eg remember a shop or florist in the hotel as a key exit area.Tip..explore the beautiful gardens which include water features, waterfall, flowers, quiet places to sit . Try and have breakfast in the garden room for great garden views.Tip..if it is a lovely day have breakfast on the 40th floor and take some aerial photos of the Emperors Palace probably the best view you will get of this palace .Tip..if you arrive tired eat at the cheap French restaurant Aux Bacchanales at the front of the hotel. Good value for all.

Stayed at this hotel for two nights and found it satisfactory. The room was spacious and comfortable, if a little dated and I found the staff to be very courteous and helpful, particularly when I requested recommendations for local restaurants, of which there are many within a 10 minute walk. The location is good; you can walk to the Marunouchi area and the Imperial Palace in about 25 minutes and it is a little less than 10 minutes walk to the subway, from where it is easy to explore Asakusa, Roppongi and indeed, the rest of Tokyo. Overall, I would say that the hotel seemed a little mored geared towards business travellers, but it was more than sufficient for a short stay.

Ok, so there were a few downsides to this hotel. The first is that the mattresses are too hard (this is common in Japanese Hotels, but it was worse for this one) and second the hotel is ... oddly located. To get to it you have to go to a shopping plaza, take an elevator to the 6th floor, walk a little ways, check in, and then take a different elevator to your room. It gets a little annoying. Also despite the places price, there wasn't the option of an included breakfast plan.That said over all it was a nice place. The rooms were nice, but not overly impressive. The gardens, shops, and restaurants below were what really impressed me. The shopping area I mentioned earlier is a small mall in its own right and the restaurants are amazing (if expensive). Most of them look onto the gardens at least partially. The gardens were amazing as well and we literally spend two hours wondering them. They were a tourist attraction in their own right :-)

My wife and I based ourselves here for a vacation in Tokyo, the extensive and superbly maintained gardens are a joy to behold. Although the hotel is 'old' the upside are large rooms. The choice of hotels is stunning, however the local area provides restaurants across all price ranges. The metro system is accessed by underground walkways just 5 minutes from the hotel

Great location 5 mins walk from metro, loads of restaurants, 7/11 and citi bank with ATM for UK debit cards. Stayed in garden tower in spacious room. Enjoyed breakfast in garden restaurant overlooking formal garden - over weekend American hot dishes added to cold buffet. Very attentive service - coffee continually topped up. Stayed as part of tour, so can't comment on value but very comfortable room. Comfortably a superior 4* type hotel

Great hotel in Tokyo's Akasaka concession. Although the hotel is not the most modern anymore, the service is superb from start to end. Metro station around the corner and some bars and restaurants with great views. Hotel is however pretty expensive.
