Den Bosch, The Netherlands

review_body: The 40 storey Garden Tower is a later addition to the original 1964 main hotel and linked directly to it with use of all of the facilities of the complex, including pool and splendid Japanese Garden. Although a very large hotel, the charming and friendly staff help to avoid it feeling impersonal. Service is unfailingly polite and efficient. The bedroom was one of the largest that we encountered on our visit to the country and was comfortable and well equipped in all respects. There is plenty of choice of dining with six restaurants offering various cuisines from Japanese to the classic French Michelin-starred La Tour d'Argent. If the hotel prices are too expensive then there are many local restaurants in nearby Akasaka (just near the Akasaka-mitsuke subway station) which is less than 10 minutes walk from the front door of the Garden Tower. Or you can buy prepared food and drinks (soft, beer and wine) from the Family Mart convenience store on the first floor of the Garden Tower, including a variety of hot dishes which the staff will microwave while you wait. A combined Japanese and Western buffet breakfast is served on the top floor of the tower but there are other options including a continental buffet in the Garden Restaurant and a really excellent Japanese and western buffet in the Satsuki restaurant in the main building. If you arrive at peak times there will be a queue but a wait of no more than 10 minutes is normal. Happy hour in the Top Bar in the Garden Tower is good value and there are panoramic views of the city. The adjacent district of Akasaka features shopping, restaurants and bars as well as the nearest 7-11 convenience store with its all important ATM.

Spent 4 nights in the New Otani Garden Tower hotel in Tokyo in October as part of a three weektour of the Asian coastline starting in Japan. We had read quite a lot of reviews of hotels in the area and were pleased that this one was chosen on our behalf. The hotel complex was originally built for the 1964 Olympics and although of an age where it may have been needing some tlc there was no sign of that on our visit. Surprisingly modern and yet containing enough old fashioned Japanese charisma to add to it's charm this is a cracking hotel. It has a traditional Japanese garden dutifully tended and kept with it's history dating back 400 plus years, a delight of a place and home to many big koi carp in the waters dotted with little red painted bridges .The rooms are typicaly large and well thought out, ours with a bath and shower and the toiletwhich was a source of amusement with the built in heated seat and bidet sprays etc.The large tv and teamaker are standard equipment and a table and two chairs handy whenplanning out your next days adventure. All this and a huge comfortable bed and good a/c made our stay exceptional as the weather was a little less kind to us.The continental breakfast was the best selection that we have come across, plus some western hot food and Japanese food all available.Now for the bad news, this hotel to eat dinner at is extremely expensive bearing in mind thateating out in Japan is very costly also, so be prepared in the hotel to pay well over 120 b/ poundsfor two burgers and fries and a couple of soft drinks.If they could sort out the eating costs then this hotel could be back up there with the best of them.

We stayed in the New Otani in the Garden Tower at the start of our guided tour of Japan in September run by Riviera Travel.The room was perfectly adequate with everything you would require. The staff were very polite and helpful greeting us whenever we walked through. The restaurants were good with a lovely breakfast at the Satsuki Restaurant. The Sky bar has spectacular views over Tokyo and a good Happy Hour!The hotel garden is worth a visit with a spectacular waterfall in the grounds and huge Koi carp in the many ponds.The hotel is within walking distance of many restaurants and the metro is close by.

This classic Hotel has some great restaurants but leaves a bit to be desired... The hotel is a bit tired and in need of updating... The hallways and rooms ( even the non smoking) Smell of smoke and the pillows and bed leave a bit to be desired... If your staying in Tokyo Consider other options...

I have been to this area of Tokyo many times for business and always opted to stay in the more budget hotels. I have to say that the difference in the quality of this hotel by comparison is much larger than the relatively small increase in room rate. The staff were great and extremely helpful, nothing seemed too much trouble. The room was perfectly reasonable and should be judged by Japanese standards where function often comes before frivolity. Everything you would want from a hotel is avaliable and i will be staying here again. There are so many great places to eat within a 15 minute walk and the underground system is 5 minutes walk. Taxis are available anytime and there is a shuttle to either Narita (1hr 30mins best case) or Haneda (45mins best case). Overall, very impressed.

The room that I stayed in was not having a very good view. But the room is nice enough to stay for a few nights and comfortable enough for a business travel. Location is very good as it is near the metro line of Ginza. There are few shops nearby as well for food, etc

Our four night stay in Tokyo was enhance by the location and facilities of the New Otani. Our room was in the Tower and had a great aspect across Tokyo and the Imperial Palace. Breakfast was available in numerous resturants, but our favourite was the American with a view of the waterfall and gardens. A great way to start any day.The location was good for transport links and other resturants in the city.

We stayed at the New Otani as an add-on to a cruise. We arrived for our first visit to Japan to the most polite reception from all the staff. The room was a twin room on the 29th floor with a fabulous view. It was spotlessly clean with every facility needed apart from an iron and ironing board. Other reviews have stated that this hotel is dated - its not newly decorated, so does that make it dated?The first morning, we had breakfast in the hotel overlooking the garden which was breathtaking and we were lucky enough to see a couple of weddings being photographed in the gardens. The gardens are lovely to walk around.Apart from the first morning, we did not eat in the hotel, so can not comment on the restaurants.Very close to the hotel is a busy, buzzing street with lots of restaurants and nightlife along with a couple of small supermarkets, useful for soft drinks and snacks.There is a metro station within 50 yards of the hotel, giving access to the whole of Tokyo. This is a great hotel, ideal for getting around the city but nice and quiet. When you go into the city, take your passport with you as you can use it to get tax back on certain goods. A special receipt is stapled into your passport and when you leave the country, you take your passport to a desk at the airport and they remove the receipt. Also, you need your passport to get a two day ticket for the underground at a reduced rate - the location of the desks where the tickets can be bought, is on the back of the Underground map.Tokyo is a fabulous city and the New Otani is a great place to stay to explore it.

Was a nice hotel. Got a group conference rate of 17800 yen a night. Ask & you may get this too. We stayed in the Garden Tower. There are 3 sections to it and it was a bit confusing trying to move around. The rooms were of a 4 star standard. TV Channels limited to about 4 new channels Bloomberg, BBC, CNN & Discovery Ch - which all got repetetive every 15 minutes. Breakfast buffet was good and fattened me up. Although location was out of the city - the underground train station was close and got you into the city fast & cheap. Taxi was about AU$15 to the Ginza. Hotel room had awesome views of tokyo city from the distance and an awesome japanese garden.

What a lovely surprise. Our stay in Tokyo was made all the more enjoyable by the embiance and facilities at this wonderful hotel. Garden Tower has lovely views of the large grounds with waterfalls and pleasant walks. Rooms are very spacious with all you could wish for. Meals and bars on location and wonderful service. NO tipping either. This is a must.

We stayed here for four nights in October 2014 as part of a pre cruise package. It was an offered upgrade that we payed slightly more for.We felt the room itself was of an average standard, neither small nor big with a great view of the city but there are many different views depending on your room. We both found the twin beds quite hard and we are used to a firm bed at home. We used our two iPhones and iPad extensively using the hotels wifi for no charge. It was a reasonable speed and was not constantly dropping out.All the staff were incredibly helpful, efficient and polite.All the dining options were expensive although we did treat ourselves to a breakfast on the morning of the Super Typhoon that struck while we were there. The view from this dining room looks out onto the fantastic Japanese garden where we also spent half an hour walking around it.The thing we enjoyed the most for this hotel was it's fantastic location situated only a five minute walk from the underground station and a great shopping and restaurant area. Personally I would not call this a business hotel, it had everything I needed as a tourist and if we went back to Tokyo we would definitely stay at The New Otani again.

Taxi costs 18 US dollars from the Tokyo railway station.Staff are all very very kind and helpful.Room: The furniture and carpet may be 30-40 years old. Room telephone was house-type and fixed near the bed. Ceiling is a bit low. You have to take shower in the bathtub. The toilet was automatic and it was a great fun. The safe is big enough.Garden is very nice.Food: There are many restaurants but 1 cheeseburger, 1 beer and 1 water costs fifty US dollars. Enjoy!

The hotel has two towers and a few restaurants and shopping botiques and even convenience stores inside the whole complex, which is indeed very convenient if you want to buy something to eat or some water.The restaurant has great food and a good view over the beautiful garden that is attached to the hotel, the garden itself is also very interesting to walk through and take some pictures.There is another rotating restaurant which is quite an attraction for itself.We also used a conference room, which was well equipped and they had good service.There rooms where also nice and well equipped.

This was my first visit in Tokyo,Japan. Staffs are well trained. Effective ,polite and Courteous . Concierge service was amazing. Fast , reliable , and they didn't take any tips but they were very active and helpful. Breakfast was served in 4 different restaurant but I had in the cafe in the main lobby. Food was good . There were so many to choose but every morning (I stayed there 4nights) was the same not changed even in a small thing. Anyway , this hotel made me to fall in love with Japan. I will definitely go there again for lemur with my family again.

Stayed here twice in 2009. The rooms are decent, great view to the garden below and the kois in the pond. Though we have not ventured out on the way to the hotel it seems walk away from the one palace in tokyo. Great experience :)

I was looking for accomodation in Tokyo, needed 3 beds in the room. Found this hotel suit to my needs that close to Shibuya for shopping/ dining and Roppongi for National Art Museum. Closest station is Akasaka- mituke for both Metro Ginza Line and Metro Maruno-uti Line, about 4 minutes by foot. The room at 47th floor had a small separated living room, small bath tub, but the night view was great with Tokyo Tower lighted up. The Japanese Garden in this property had a pond with large colourful carps, swimming pool only for summer time. The shopping complex in this building connecting to main tower is like a small town has from convenience shop to fine dinning, can get anything you need. The staff of this hotel speak fluent English. Worth to stay.

The best part of the hotel is the garden outside the hotel. Very well appointed hotel rooms. Definitely go for the small cost of the deluxe room, as it makes a huge difference in size and appointments.

I absolutely loved the garden of this hotel with the spectacular waterfall! I visited Tokyo during cherry blossom season and the hotel's garden was just beautiful. The hotel was also near a few streets with a lot of cherry blossom trees.

Very nice hotel with excellent staff. 'The Main' seems to be in excellent condition but the 'Garden Tower' rooms are rather jaded for what purports to be a 5-star hotel. The beautiful Japanese garden setting is glorious within the hustle and bustle of Tokyo city but hardly makes up for the outlandish pricing of food and drink within the hotel......see a price then add 10% service charge.....THEN add 8% 'consumption tax' (V.A.T. to us in the UK) so add 18.8% to everything that you might drink or eat. Sadly we purchased just two drinks on our first night until we had 'orientated' ourselves and never drank or eat in the hotel after that. Fortunately it is just a 4-5 minute walk to many outside eateries. Access to Tokyo Metro is just 3-4 minutes away but if you walk to Asakusa make certain that you use the Garden Tower entrance.....walking from/to 'The Main' entrance takes 4-5 times as long and is uphill all the way back (it's a shame they don't tell you this at reception but perhaps you are expected to use taxis to get 500 yards 'as the crow flies' to get to the Metro entrance?).

The New Otani Hotel (not to be confused with the New Otani Inn) is excellent and the modern blend of modern with a Japanese flavour. The hotel, like many, blends into an up market shopping mall and is near a local shops and transportation network. The hotel's Japanese garden is worth a stroll although the restaurants there are a bit expensive.Their Garden room serves a wonderful 'Joyful Set' afternoon tea, and very nice breakfast spread.

I’m coming to this his hotel already since many years. I really do like it a lot, especially now all the rooms are renovated. They did a fabulous Job. Very tastefully decorated, very spacious rooms, especially for Tokyo standards and absolute comfortable beds.Personally I am not really a huge fan of such big Hotels which almost feel like bed factories but here somehow they seem to recognise one and it is a nice to be back now and then. Location is excellent next to the Akasaka area and close to Ropongi. Metro is located around to corner and brings you everywhere else in Tokyo. There are many F&B outlets all over the hotel but in my opinion quite expensive.

I picked this hotel because my father stayed here when he visited Japan. The hotel definitely needs updating. The rooms are small, the radio, clock, etc. in the room is still analog. For example, the clock is facing the same direction as you are sleeping and is on the dresser next to the bed. In order to see it -- you can't unless you sit up! It's little things like that. The bathroom is very small and the shower looks and feels old. The staff is VERY friendly and helpful though. There are plenty of help in the hotel and they always have a smile. The dining options are incredible. With so many options of places to dine, it is overwhelming. As are the shops. Most of course are overpriced for tourists. Japan is VERY expensive so be prepared to pay for everything. For example, $28USD for eggs Benedict. $33USD for a bowl of beef curry.The ONLY thing I would suggest you visit is the Japanese Garden. It is beautiful and shouldn't be missed. They have a waterfall feature, along with some koi and most of the small restaurants are through the garden. With so many choices, I will skip this hotel and look for others when I return to Japan.

We just returned from a 7-night stay at a Garden Tower Triple Room .Room was large; has a separate sitting area with desk and chair, sofa, coffee table and TV. It also has a mini-frig, a hot water pot, free instant coffee, green tea, plum tea, back tea. Free Wi-Fi. Plenty of towels, bath robes, kimonos, soft slippers. The usual soap, shampoo, conditioner, body soap, hand soap; a bit unusual: foldable brush, razor, bubble bath, cotton swabs. The shampoo, conditioner and body soap are from a nice Japanese brand; they smell nice and leave skin clean and soft.The hotel is very traditional Japanese. After check-in, a hotel staff brings your luggages and show you to your room. My preschooler was also gave a small toy as welcome gift. Ice is brought to your room upon calling housekeeping; so are iron and ironing board. Free daily newspaper (English or Japanese).Now the best part is the location of this hotel, we have a preschooler and sometimes, we just want to have a snack or a light dinner at hotel room. No problem. There are 2 on-site convenience stores. One store is called Family Mart which opens 7am to 11pm. It is located on the 2nd floor of the Garden Court building. It is like 7-11. It has drinks and food. Food includes breakfast pastries, Japanese chips and snacks AND prepared meals like fresh ramen noodles, udon, curry rice, BBQ chicken stews, salads and more. They will microwave the hot food for you. Must try is the frozen ice cream cone; it is made from Hokkaido milk. The other store is on the 1st floor of the same building. It is more of a traditional Japanese small grocery store with prepared meals, high-end fruits; for example, $15 watermelon that is rated on sweetness level; $50 for a small basket of grapes that are from a special part of Japan. We tried the $1 tiny Mandarin orange which was so sweet and smelled so fresh. They also have high-end souvenir Japanese crackers/cakes which you cannot buy at the Narita airport. We saw a lot of office workers go there to grab lunch. Note that the Garden Court building that it is in is actually an office building.Outside of the hotel, you are 5 mins walk away from 3 streets full of Japanese restaurants. Lotsa choices but lacking in "Take Out". I would say 99% Dine-in; except McD and First Kitchen.Now, let's talk about the distance of this hotel from different tourist locations like Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku, Akihabara, Ginza. I would rate that it is a fair location. It is about a $20-$25 each way Taxi fare from each of the above locations except for Akihabara which was about $30-$35. Note that a train ride is only approx. $3 per person each way; children under 6 is free. Taxi can seat 4 and stroller is free to store in trunk.Now, let's talk about the cleanliness of the room. We were shocked to find that the carpet is super clean. We spilled a glass of water and clean it up with white towels and the towels remained white; not a speck of dirt? How is that possible? May be because they provide slippers for guest?Also, we watched the house cleaning lady cleaned the sinks and she was very detailed; the spouts are spotless and shiny front and back and top and under. All the glasses that they provided are spotless and look brand new; also individually wrapped in clear plastic. The only thing that does not look 'new' is the sofa; it had a lint issue. Other than that, I would say this hotel room was 9.5 out of 10 in cleanliness.Overall, I would recommend this place for family with small children who needs a clean and central location to stay with easy access to quality food source.

Big international hotel with rooms in a tower with view on Tokyo skyscrappers and on the river downside. The hotel has shops, many restaurants (different types of Japanese cuisine, also French style); some of the restaurants are in the garden and look nice. Unfortunately menus are really expensive compared to the restaurants you can find around in the area of the hotel. I really appreciated sushi restaurant in the Bizz Tower which is at a distance of 15 minutes walking. I just had a Japanese and international buffet breakfast one morning to be able to appreciate the view on Tokyo, and another day a breakast on the ground floor with the view on the Japanese garden; but did not take a chance to try the restaurants for lunch or dinner because they were too expensive. Furthermore, you have to have to add 8% of taxes to the bill so be careful!There is a small bar on 40th floor to appreciate the night view on Tokyo, but I did not like my cocktail.Staff is really nice and helpful at front desk.Rooms are clean and comfortable. I had a beautiful suite on 27 th floor wih the view on Tokyo; the bathroom was Japanese style, that is to say with a shower to wash yourself with a small bank apart from the tub, and also a bath tub. Toilets were apart from the bathroom.Small water bottles, green and oolong tea bags, instant coffee, are available for free, with also a water boiler.Nice kimonos and bath robes are also available for free; the good thing with Japanese hotels is that they offer toothbrush, and other useful things like hairbrush, cotton ear tips, etc...The hotel offers massages in your room for around 50 euros (50 minutes at least); did not have time to try it!Laundry service is excellent.I had a really funny and surprising experience when I decided to go to the swimming pool around 18:00-19:00 during August : the swimming pool was open to non-customers, and was invaded with a crowd of young Tokyo beautiful and young people showing off around the pool! You can see mostly girls wearing last tendance swimming suits, chatting, and of course not swimming! It was impossible to swim and was like more or less a fashion défilé. Furthermore, I was eaten by mosquitos which are really tremendous in Tokyo during summer time!The spa is really expensive beacuse you have to pay an entrance fee.My recommendation is that is that you ask for your New Otani membership card on the hotel website before your arrival, so you can benefit from more attention, like newspaper in the room and access to the swimming pool for free.

This is a difficult hotel to review, because there are so many different components that go into it. Basically, the New Otani Tokyo is a vast complex consisting of the hotel, several restaurants and bars, a garden and a large underground shopping arcade. Considered purely as a hotel, I was slightly disappointed. The rooms were large by Japanese standards, everything was clean and the service was good, but it did all feel slightly dated. Also, the size of the hotel can be annoying in itself, because you often have to do a lot of walking just to get out of the complex. On the other hand, the garden is amazing, access to the pool is free with New Otani Club membership, there are some nice opportunities for shopping and "The Bar" on the 40th floor of the tower was just spectacular. Great view of the Tokyo Tower, especially at night, wide selection of drinks and snacks and amazing service. Many (most, in fact) of the other bars and restaurants were overpriced in my opinion, though.To sum up, I would say that if you get a good deal on the room (as we did), the New Otani is a nice hotel, especially if you like the idea of having everything in one place. It does have some significant flaws, though. Finally, as a tourist you may feel that the location is not ideal for sightseeing.

A good hotel in its category. It is immense, but this means that you can get (at a price) a bewildering variety of food in the several restaurants, some with great views, within the complex. Our room was large (36 square meters), the bed was comfortable, with well-working wi-fi, sofas, complimentary bathrobes, 'kimono-robes', slippers, good TV and free tea/coffee making facilities. Outside, there is a pretty Japanese garden. On the negative side, the room was not as glitzy and modern as one would expect a Tokyo hotel of this category to be: antiquated shower, not enough room for storing clothes, and a lack of mirrors. The personnel is amazingly kind and well-trained. Prices are very reasonable. And this is a historical hotel, which adds some charm.

This sprawling hotel complex is Vegas-size with well over 1000 rooms, at least half a dozen restaurants and several bars. First, the pros: largish rooms at reasonable prices, nothing missing. Some nicely decorated bars (e.g. Traders Vic's in Polynesian style), spectacular views across the skyline, especially at night, efficient, faultless service by uniformed personnel, a truly outstanding Japanese garden, speedy and reasonably priced limo buses to Haneda and Narita, showy boutiques if you fancy spending 2.7mY on an antique armor. I really found only one negative and that was the feeling I was being charged well over the odds for any sort of food or drinks. 27 USD for a burger or 28 for pasta at the bottom end seems like a rip off unless you are the Ritz. Some restaurants offer top-end Japanese food at 200 - 300 USD per meal. Drinks in bars are pricey (19 USD for a Mai Tai) and for a hotel that large many venues were strangely empty. And, 30 USD to use the pool really is usury, though probably just crowd control. A bewildering array of discounts and happy hours adds to the confusion.Overall, the hotel is simply too big to be enjoyable.

In spite of being a huge hotel, probably more than a thousand rooms, we felt like welcome guests. In comparison to the enormous and luxurious hall, shopping arcades, etc..., the rooms are a bit small and should provide more space to keep clothes, but the spectacular views on the city's buildings and parks make good for that. Enormous is the choice of top level restaurants in the hotel, you should try at least one of the Japanese. Food is of the best quality here, as you can expect also expensive. For not so expensive options you can go for an enjoyable walk in the Akasaka district, where you will find lots of restaurants only a few steps from the hotel. Breakfast is served on the top floors, where the view alone makes worth the high price. To pay a bit less it is useful to ask in advance for the free New Otani Club membership, which also gives you free access to the outdoor swimming pool. A special thanks goes to the entire staff of the hotel, who exceeded in helpfulness and were very professional all the time.

This is an old hotel but still well maintained The lobby is spacious, But one has to walk a mile to get tonthr roomthe japanese garden overlooking the restaurant awesome , the view from my room got had a boring next bundling. IWW where people worked late, so had to keep curtains. Loses till late in the night.I was not (luckly to get the tokyo tower view The room big and nice , the staff friendlyBut my god have never seen any hotel with such a huge choice of food.There are more taphan ten restaurants. Serving every cuisine.It's expensive though, but then Tokyo s one of the mos expensive cities in the world.For the breakfast i tried the 40th floor I got the 5 star quality n service if you looking for more range of food go to the roof top restaurant it worth the wait for 15 minutes i spent- but its vale for the money. The food is good and the view great. Omelette cheese and french toast definetl thumbs upPositives 5 min walk to subway station10 min walk to streat food and resto 10 min walk to convinient store10 min walk to yoshinoya 24 hrs

Our room was large and had amazing views across Tokyo. We were a bit jet-lagged when we arrived but this comfortable hotel with outstanding service allowed to relax. The beautiful gardens were a peaceful retreat from the city. Excellent value for money, though I must add we didn't eat at the hotel, preferring to eat in city restaurants.

I have pained less and stayed in better. Rude staff, dated rooms and the blinds didn't work.They also wouldn't accept my visa debit card. Which was embarrassing so I couldn't charge anything to my room. So make sure you have a credit card so you can get into more debt.

This is old classic hotel but still well maintain. The lobby was spacious, the garden was awesome , the view from your room amazing (luckly i got tokyo tower view ) .The room quite big and nice , the staff so friendly. For the breakfast i hve tried the 40th floor and the garden style. Both offer you 5 star quality n service. But if you looking for more range of food go to the roof top restaurant it worth the queue for 20 minute and worth the money. The food is terrific and the view even better. Omelette cheese and french toast definetly tumbs up ... Cant wait to be back .Good point :5 min walk to subway station10 min walk to streat food and resto 10 min walk to convinient store10 min walk to yoshinoya 24 hour

Excelent hotel. Very good service, well equiped rooms, clean, quiet,... Subway is near so you can go everywhere in tokyo in very reasonable times.It also has a very nice garden that we couldn't enjoy until the last moment.Very good value for the money

We arrived late, about 9 pm, in transit on our last night in Japan. The lobby is very nice and check in efficient. The desk man offered an upgrade for a minimal price as we were told the rooms reserved for us In the garden tower were smaller and older. For one short night we demurred. Our room was ok. Did not smell fresh, but the beds were comfortable. The bed linens were old but seemed clean. The bathroom, however, was more modern, clean,with nice appliances and towels. Breakfast in the Japanese style was excellent. As good as any we had dusting our stay. The view of the garden was spectacular, and we had to walk through it. Fantastic. The view of the waterfall from the Japanese tower restaurant was even better close up. Easy trip to Narita airport via the limo bus service. Very satisfactory for an overnight. Apparently the new tower has bigger, better rooms. We would try that, the rooms in the garden tower are ok, but could use some freshening.For a hotel with such a garden, and containing several upscale stores and a Tour d'Argent outpost we would have expected consistent luxury. But the front desk warned us!

It is a good business hotel ! It huge. It is close a one Bic Camera Store, and a many restaurants. The rooms are confortable, but smells a cigarrete. There is a wonderful garden, The breakfast is wonderful and with a view of the garden.Very central.

Fabulous hotel that has the feel of 1960's Palm Springs classic hotel.The service and courtesay of the staff is excellent as it is everywhere in Tokyo.We had a room on the 36th floor of the garden tower. The views are indescribable, simply wonderful.The restaurants are all high end and the food is good. Even the room service had a better than European standard.I recommend the bar at the top of the 40th floor on weekdays. The best Manhattans ever.

Stayed in this hotel to join the Trafalgar group with whom I travelled through Japan.I understand that this is a reputable Hotel Chain, with a very beautiful site, with the a Japanese garden etc. ... but it was far away of what I received from other hotels along my journey through Asia. I knew when choosing a Trafalgar Tour that would have to settle for 3 star hotels, but the New Otani website seemed to offer more. But it didn't. Check in was ok, nice people , extremely helpful.You have to walk 200m from one building to another, so breakfast is a kind of "operation ", if you want to come back to your room.Internet just inside the room.The room is small, old and cramped. The breakfast in the Main building is better than the Garden.

I stayed her recently for 5 nights. The location of the hotel is great being right beside the subway line.The actual hotel is so vast we often got lost inside. The lobby and shopping/restaurant areas were very impressive. As for the bedroom, there was nothing about ours to suggest it was in a 5 star hotel. I think the room left a lot to be desired and was actually quite dated. It was very clean throughout our stay. I would suggest going into Shibuya or even down the street from the hotel for bars and restaurants as the ones in the hotel are very expensive. The swimming pool was not open (mid July and 30+). This was very disappointing as was learning if it had been open it would have been 3000yen each per swim!

We were lucky enough to be treated to a couple of nights in a well equipped suite with a great view in this massive hotel by our very kind Japanese family and friends.The hotel has a very grand formal atmosphere with some original retro features from the 1960's which I rather liked.The buffet breakfast choices were vast and all the items that I tried were delicious. The view from the top floor was amazing. The only downside for me was that the outdoor pool was not open (despite it being mid July and 33 degrees outside) and the alternative indoor pool was small and you had to pay extra to use it (and the gym) which seemed a bit harsh considering the room rate.

Very small old rooms. 30% premium charged for check in before 7 PM or check out after 10am . Rooms ok for 1 adult not 2. Bathroom barely big enough to sit on toilet . Would avoid this hotel and look for American brands and check room size and check on and check out policies

Lovely hotel with nice big rooms and really nice bathroom . Beautiful gardens a pool which is seasonal and you have to pay to swim in ! . Staff really nice and all seem to Speke English . We only ate in the cafe over looking the waterfall and a little expensive and to be honest not very nice at all but there are plenty of places close by that are nice . Well worth a stay .

relaxing experience especially during new year when every one goes to see their family . large and comfortable rooms and great staff . lots of shops and restaurants and good view . also great location close to nagatacho metro station.

Stayed here on a business trip to Tokyo. The main thing that struck me was the courtesy of staff and the level of service. Public areas were good and the rooms were very comfortable. A wide choice of restaurants and bars in the restaurant, along with some nice shops. The Sky Bar is worth a visit, especially and night to see Tokyo by neon.

We stayed in a triple room which had all the comforts you would expect from a luxury hotel. We felt thoroughly pampered throughout our stay here. The room was spacious and comfortable. The bathroom was well-stocked with a generous supply of Shiseido bath products, which were replenished daily. The breakfast buffet at both Satsuki Restaurant and Top of the Tower featured a delightful spread, with Japanese and Western options. Top of the Tower offers magnificent views of Mount Fuji, if you opt to sit by the windows. We enjoyed dinner at a quaint Japanese restaurant called Nakajima, which offers sushi or Japanese noodles. My kids enjoyed dining with traditional Japanese-style seating. Alternatively, there is the option of dining tables and chairs. Needless to say, this is where we had dinner every night. The service was excellent, with attentive staff. The location of the hotel was convenient as it was only a short walk away from the Akasaka-Mitsuke train station. We were able to commute to different attraction spots with ease. An additional feature of this hotel is its beautiful gardens, which unfortunately, we did not visit as it was still very cold during our stay.We would definitely recommend this hotel and hope to be back in the future!

My wife and I stayed at this hotel for four nights while on a group holiday in Japan. We had a spacious room on the 35th floor of the garden tower with great view over the Imperial Gardens. Our deal was a bed and breakfast basis; we sampled a couple of the restaurants for breakfast, and food was both Japanese and Western. Varied and plentiful. Service excellent.This is a huge hotel, but there always seem to be staff available to help in any way possible.

The hotel might look old and simple on the outside but wait til you get inside. All floors are carpeted, light fixtures are relaxing and oh, I so love their Japanese garden. We took a lot of photos there. Bed is comfy, bathroom is nice. Though area for buffet breakfast is quite small. When there is a lot of guests, you have to wait for a vacant table. But over-all, this hotel is wow!

This was my first time in Tokyo and I and my husband were very pleased with the New Otani. The breakfast was excelent with many diferent options either western or japanese, but on the first day we had an enourmous quew and had to wake up earlier the next day. The room was spacious and clean, and the hotel staf was very nice and helpfull but there were many staff not speaking adequate english, making it difficult to understand us. The hotel is very well located being near several restaurants and shops with a very close metro station.We had one meal at the only restaurant open after 10 pm on our arrival day and this was a disapointment, quite expensive and not very goos foood.I would certainly recomend this hotel.

My 4th trip to Tokyo, this time a business trip staying at the New Otani (not a first choice honestly). Coming from Haneda airport, took the train to Shimbashi station, then changed to Akasaka station, heading out to exit D. 2 minute walk to the hotel. Unless you have a lot of luggages, I do believe this is one of the most convenient and economic way to get to the hotel.Overall, I'd say that the hotel is not as modern as how it looks on photo. Room size is good for a Tokyo hotel (executive suite with 2 single bed and a good view of the garden on the roof) but generally the amenities does looked it could use some refurbishing in the next 2 years.TV stations seemed like a lot, but for a foreigner, can only stick to CNN or CNBC, no HBO or movie channels to kill time.Was out of the most time was not able to engage with the staff much, but generally are friendly can carry on a good English conversation with guests.Probably only go back for the convenience, but there are definitely better hotels in Tokyo.

There is nothing to dislike about this hotel. Location is great - close to the Akasaka station - with about 5 different lines passing through. There are also 2 rows of restaurants within walking distance - we ate there almost every night. We had a suite (bedroom & living room) but only 1 bathroom. The room is spacious. The service is good and prompt. The room is clean. Bottles of water, hot water pot and coffee replenished daily. Most importantly, there is in-room wifi and it is fast. One thing I did not find favourable is that there is limited TV channels - mainly news channels. No HBO or star TV or the likes. I did not try any of the hotel restaurants although there are many to choose from. We did take a walk in the garden - that is part of the hotel, and went to the chapel in the garden.

We stayed here 3 nights in early June 2014. We booked a non-smoking king room; when we checked in the room we got smelled like it had been smoked in a lot (it also looked a little outdated). So we called the front desk and within 20 minutes they switched us to an equal-sized but updated and clean-smelling room ten floors lower.The room was decent sized, similar to any big-city hotel room I've stayed in. Very quiet, no sound from outside or next door rooms. The bed was a bit hard and bouncy, but it seemed like a marshmallow compared to the futons we had been sleeping on in the previous week. Some of the furniture was new, some was older but in decent condition.The hotel property is huge and includes a bunch of fancy stores and restaurants, it all has a somewhat dated 60s/70s Vegas-y luxury vibe (but it's all in very good condition). We only ate at one of the restaurants once, the garden cafe - we had burgers and they were big and good, but they were nearly $30 each. We never tried the breakfast or any other of their restaurants; instead when we wanted a cheaper light breakfast or lunch/snack nearby, we went to the Sunroser building next door (it's connected via a short walkway from the garden tower lobby) where there's a Tully's coffee on the 2nd floor, and a small deli/market on the 1st floor. Other notes:- You can sign up for a free Otani club membership on the spot when checking in to save 20% on breakfast.- On-room wifi is free (seems like a recent change) and it worked fine.- There are many bars and restaurants only a few blocks away in the Akasaka neighborhood. We had a nice shabu-shabu meal at "Shabugen" which is on the 5th floor above the McDonalds.- The Akasaka-Mitsuke metro stop is a block away.- The app "Tokyo Subway Navigation for Tourists" was extremely helpful for using the subway. Aside from a map, it will show you the closest station, and if you plug in the start and end stations, it will show you where to change if needed, how long the trip will take, and how much to pay.- If you're going to be using the metro more than a few times, it's worthwhile to buy a Suica or Pasmo card which you can tap to ride the metro (and use to buy drinks at many vending machines). The cards are sold from machines in many metro stops and train stations.

I stayed in the Garden Tower, large double room (for 1) very comfortable, clean and all amenities you'd expect. Breakfast in the top of the tower restaurant for Mount Fuji views, but expect to wait to be seated. Well worth the effort. Good choice of in-house restaurants for lunch & dinner but plenty of alternatives in the local area within walking distance (loved the Ninja restaurant at Akasaka Tokyu Plaza). Staff very helpful and smiley.

An extremely large hotel split into 3 buildings. We stayed in the Garden Tower and were very pleased. Hotel is near a subway station which makes it very handy for getting around. In addition within a few hundred yards there is a restaurant area with dozens of restaurants of every kind. Breakfast was very good with a large buffet catering to all tastes. A delightful Japanese garden is contained within the hotel grounds. The charge for the use of the pools was the only complaint. A hotel of this standard should offer free pool access to residents.

Booked by the travel agent for a 1 night pre-cruise stop over and overall we were quite satisfied.Arriving at 09-45 we could not check in until 14-00hrs which meant hanging around the hotel for 4hrs after a 10hr flight, not very good. After a couple of hours and needing food we seated ourselves in the restaurant overlooking the Japanese garden and ordered 2 rounds of sandwiches with fries and tea for 2. The food was most enjoyable and we had no complaints with it. However, after converting the JPY to English pounds it left a bitter taste £48 or $80, hence the title. We found the room clean, roomy and well equipped with everything you needed including toothbrushes, slippers and hairbrushes which amused my wife with me being bald. In the evening and being tired we decided to risk the high prices and eat in the hotel. We enjoyed a lovely 4 course meal, really excellent, for only £69 or $116 and the waiter was very friendly and attentive. If I found myself booked into this hotel again by the travel agent I would not mind at all.

First of all, the location is pretty good - a three minute walk from the pivotal Akasaka subway station. The sprawling hotel comprises a 17 storey so-called Main hotel and a 40 storey Garden Tower separated by nearly 100 metres of corridor. I haven't stayed in the tower for a couple of years, but back then it had large rooms, sparsely furnished, with the hardest beds I've ever experienced. The Main hotel block rooms are far smaller, more recently refurbished, and with beds which help overcome jet lag rather than reduce your chances of sleep. Whichever block you choose, the bathrooms are small - and of course come equipped with the ubiquitous electric lavatory. Press the wrong button and you'll self induce colonic irrigation, and it's worth learning how to turn off the seat warmer.The complex - for that is what it is - is built on the side of a hill. This makes it quite confusing. The lobby floor of the Main hotel is on the equivalent floor to the 6th floor of the Tower (so the Tower lobby is on the 6th floor). There are restaurants and shops all over the place. The hotel is a hive of activity during the day - navigating the wide, shop-lined corridor between the two parts of the hotel is rather like walking down a busy street - yet turns into a wasteland at about 8.30 at night.There are several places to take breakfast. On a sunny day, opting for continental breakfast allows you to eat in the Garden restaurant - half way along the 100 metre corridor separating the Main from the Garden Tower. The huge picture windows overlook a 10 acre Japanese garden, complete with red bridge, rock garden and fairly sizeable waterfall. It looks less polished when you walk round it, but from the breakfast room it is a spectacular oasis of peace over which to gaze while eating your beakfast.We also had breakfast in the more popular, larger, and rather dismal breakfast room in the Main hotel. While the choice is good, the atmosphere is oppressive and the seating arrangements so convoluted that they contrive to create a 10 minute queue for a half empty restaurant at 06.00.Over the last couple of visits I have eaten in a couple of the hotel's Japanese restaurants, including the really excellent Kyubey sushi restaurant. The Sky Bar is a different matter. Service is pitifully slow, the ambience is uninviting (which is why the lights are virtually on "off"), and the view is completely spoiled by the distraction of the revolving restaurant which circles the bar.For the record, over the years I have found the service in the hotel to be solid if somewhat slow. This time they struggled to cope with the fact that I arrived with my wife rather than just alone as my booking indicated. What should have been a two minute rate adjustment took 15 minutes to resolve. This time round the bed had hairs in it: it happens in hotels; they were very apologetic; but it took two people an inordinate amount of time to remake the bed at 11.00 at night.It's absolutely not a five star experience, but it is reliable and - for Tokyo - reasonably priced for what you get (25,000 Yen per day including breakfast).

We stayed here two nights at the end of our Japan trip. The Garden Tower is an older building in the Hotel New Otani. We had a good sized room with two twin beds - unfortunately the beds were very hard and I did not sleep well. The furniture was older, a little outdated, but well kept. This is what you get for around $300. The "Main" building has much nicer rooms if you are willing to pay a few hundred dollars more. The hotel is well situated with easy access to the subway for a quick trip to Ginza or Harajuku. The breakfast buffet was good with a nice view of the lovely garden, and the airport bus starts it's journey from this hotel, which makes it very convenient (around $30 to get to Narita, don't ask the cost of a taxi!). The staff was very helpful, many of them spoke English, as is the norm in large hotels.

My finance and I had high hopes about dining at "The Sky" since we had read an article saying it had a great view of Tokyo. We made the reservation for a Friday night, and I was told (in writing) that the base price for dinner would be JPY9,505 per person. On Friday afternoon I had a work meeting and needed to change my reservation to the following night (Saturday). We showed up on Saturday; view was ok but nothing great. Food was decent. Then the bill came. We were charged JPY 15,444 per person. When I pointed out that this was not what we had been quoted, I was told that this was the holiday price (effective Saturday but not Friday). I thought it was a bit unprofessional that no one had pointed this out when I changed my reservation but we decided not to let it ruin our night.I gave the waiter my credit card, which was a Citibank American Express from Singapore. (we are expats living in Singapore). After awhile, the waiter came over and asked me to come and enter my pin. I told him, there is no pin because it's a credit card, not debit. He then said my card didn't work and we needed to provide another. My finance gave him her Citibank American Express card, also from Singapore (from her own account). She was also told her card didn't work. This was extremely strange to us since we had been using both cards the whole trip, all over Japan. We then each provided our Citibank Singapore Visa cards. They "did not work" either. When we said that we thought there must be a problem with the credit card machine at New Otani, and asked if they could manually key in the numbers or run it at another machine, our waiter became increasingly agitated and told us we needed to provide another card. He was repeating "Your card not working!" aggressively which to both me and my fiance felt like he was implying we had done something wrong or we did not really have money behind our cards, which could not be further from the truth. At this point we had provided 4 cards. We had also stopped enjoying our dessert and coffee to come deal with the situation. It was embarrassing to us and many guests saw what was happening. Another manager came back to our table and took a manual imprint of the card. We then left. However, the following day, I got an email from my WORK COLLEAGUE based in Singapore. The New Otani had actually emailed my WORK saying that our cards still didn't work and the balance from dinner was outstanding. They asked my work colleague to ask if I could come back to the hotel and pay cash. Now we were really infuriated. They got my colleague's work email from my away email address which said "for urgent / emergency matters please contact ____", and they had my email address because this is how I originally made my reservation. CLEARLY the dinner was a non-business matter and also a non-emergency matter; furthermore my cell phone was working just fine and that number was also listed on every correspondence I had with New Otani. Now my office has received emails which imply that my fiance and I don't have working credit cards. I was incredibly shocked that they would abuse my work "away" email auto message, particularly when they had my cell phone number and my cell phone worked fine. We called Citibank immediately who assured us all of our cards had ample credit and they saw no problem on their side.The entire situation just ruined the end of our Tokyo trip and I will never be eating here again. For a 5 star restaurant and hotel, it's just unacceptable to me. The service was that of a 2- or 3-star. Employees not knowing how to use their own credit card machines or trouble-shoot situations professionally is not ok for how much you're paying. On other notes the view is completely sub-par.

Here for business. Service is excellent. Lots of stores in the complex. Airport bus stops here making it easy to get to and from airport. Expensive, but Tokyo is. For food, lots in the area or for the price difference, take a taxi.

This is a huge hotel complex, with numerous places to eat, drink and shop (although, in keeping with other hotel restaurants/bars, they are more expensive than going out). And because of the hotel’s excellent location it is very easy to go out for a drink or meal, as it is a stone’s throw from the Akasaka district (and metro station should you want to go further afield) where there are ample different restaurants to suit all tastes and pockets. To walk to the Akasaka area it is quicker to leave the hotel by the Garden Tower entrance rather than the main entrance as it saves a walk round the block.Our room in the hotel (in the Garden Tower Block) was more spacious than I had expected in a Tokyo hotel, with enough room for storage and suitcases. It was clean, comfortable and well serviced with towels changed every day. The bathroom was also the best we had during a tour in Japan, with a showerhead that could change the direction of jet, bars of soap, small bottles of shampoo and conditioner plus face clothes – all of which were lacking in other hotels we stayed in.Breakfast in the hotel is also good, with a reasonable selection of hot western style dishes, Japanese dishes and fresh fruit. (Although I found this never-varied selection was much the same in other hotels we subsequently visited and consequently became a little boring, but it was probably better here than other hotels we stayed at). Breakfast can be taken at one of several restaurants, but the main two for western breakfasts are the rooftop restaurant in the Garden Tower, and the central ground floor Garden restaurant (there is another Japanese restaurant if you want a Japanese breakfast). These open at 7pm and there is invariably a queue, particularly at the rooftop restaurant where great views over Tokyo can be had from window tables. If you want a window table here for an early breakfast you would need to get there by about 6.45, otherwise just before 7.30 when, although still usually a (shorter) queue, you will get the first arrivals starting to leave. The Garden restaurant is more airy and has a greater capacity, but again you should be there just before 7 for an early breakfast to get a table overlooking the superb gardens. For us, this was the more comfortable and relaxing of the two. (Incidentally, the attractive gardens and pools full of Koi carp are well worth walking round).Drinks are expensive (1000 yen plus for a small beer). The lobby floor Capri bar (near the main lobby) is a bit soulless with more serving staff than customers when we went (I noted 6 attentive serving staff for us and another couple), while Trader Vic’s bar (the only other we tried) was equally pricey but had a better atmosphere being decorated out in a Disney-like South Sea Island style. It also serves snacks in the bar.Overall we thought the hotel very good, reasonably priced for the size and style of hotel it is, and met our needs in all respects, although we did eat and drink out after the first night.

We stayed here for four nights as part of a tour of Japan. Our room was well equipped, had a view of the beautiful garden and it was hard to believe we were in the middle of a bustling city.Breakfast was served overlooking the garden and was of a high quality as was the service. This hotel has a range of shops and restaurants and I would recommend it to anyone.

I really loved this hotel.The view is perfect, the staff super helpful and the breakfast buffet delicious.The hotel is near the Akasaka-Mitsuke station, a 3 minute walk to get there. If you're hungry but don't want to spend a lot of money I recommend the restaurants near the hotel.I also recommend the 40th floor when having breakfast so you can have a beautiful view of Tokyo.Oh and when making a reservation for a room, ask for the garden view. It's beautiful.

Huuuuuge hotel. This hotel is a very old hotel. It's been around since the early 1900s. Nice and with good service for the price that we paid. I noticed quite a number of complains in the reviews about the hotel being expensive but I beg to differ. The hotel is quite reasonable for the quality (And its cheaper than the hotels we paid for in Hakone!) It's also quite accessible, next to Akasaka-Mitsuke train station and 5 mins walk from Yotsuya station (one of the major train stations which gives you access to multiple lines).We stayed on the 37th floor which afforded us an excellent view of Tokyo.

We stayed for 3 nights in the New Otani. This is a very big hotel, avoid it if you have walking difficulties. The room was well appointed and very clean. Towels changed every day. There are a lot of restaurants in the hotel, but all very expensive. It is much cheaper to go to the Akasaka area, where there is a good variety of cafes and eating places. We had continental breakfasts in the Garden room. Very good and there are lovely views of the Japanese Gardens. A nice way to start the day. This hotel is in the business district and not really near many tourist attractions. The Akasaka tube line is just out of the 'back' door and you can get anywhere in the city easily. A day pass costs roughly 4GBP.

This hotel is simply put..huge!!Multiple entrances to 2 wings.The older wing is the Main and the slightly newer wing is the Garden Tower.I arrived at the Garden Tower and the entrance was more like a department store entrance.A maze of shops selling practically everything from designer clothes to a high end supermarket.Lobby is situated on the 6th floor and considering the size of the hotel is very small.There are so many restaurants and corridors its just to confusing and guests really need directions from staffs.Checkin was quick and typically Japanese style.Very businesslike.My room was on the 24th floor but the room number started with 44....which can be confusing guests might think they are on the 44th floor.Rooms start from the 11th floor to the 39th floor.Room was very very old fashioned and really needs a renovation.They still use a room key which I have not seen in many many hotels.Size was average with plenty of space.I had a lovely view of their private garden and swimming pool.Bathroom was on the small size with very limited amenities unlike other Japanese hotels.The bed was very odd.It felt so springy whenever I laid down on it or just turned.It felt like I was sleeping on a trampoline.The bedsheet just barely covered the end of the mattress and so it was a bit uncomfortable for my feet because it came out as it was not tucked in.Besides all these...internet was free.The aircon worked well.And it was clean.Location wise its situated across from Akasaka..so theres an alley way full of restaurants and convenience stores but that's about it.The subway station is just before the crossing.The hotel grounds are truly magnificent.they have a very traditional restaurant called Nadaman that's serves kaiseki...traditional Japanese food served course by course.They even have a traditional outhouse in their garden which caters to special VIPs and dignitaries.The swimming pool is very big.Be warned though..the restaurants in the hotel are all very very expensive as this hotel is considered one of the high end hotels in Tokyo along with The Imperial Hotel.Personally this hotel is not to my liking as it is just too old for me.And the location is not to convenient for shopping.

Out of mistake, we booked into this hotel, but would rather not go back there. There are many nicer hotels in Tokyo. Although the front of the hotel looks fairly smart, the building at the back is very outdated, with old carpets throughout and rooms in need of updating. The new and old parts are linked by a long, impersonal and rather off-putting corridor devoid of charm or cosiness. The whole atmosphere is that of a railway station. We stayed there for 8 nights to attend a congress in Tokyo, then for another night after a business trip on our way back to London. The air conditioning in our room was not working properly, so we had to call reception for them to send up an engineer to fix it temporarily so we could sleep for 1 night. There are also long queues for breakfast at certain times of the day. Overall, a very disappointing experience.

The New Otani is special. The garden is really worth taking a contemplative stroll: if not that, at least have breakfast in the beautiful restaurant that overlooks the garden (it will reduce your blood pressure... Unless you're paying!)My favorite aspect is the little wedding chapel: it draws guests in traditional kimonos, which makes people-watching much more fun.The service is attentive and unerring. The rooms often have spectacular views. I've stayed in several hotels in Tokyo: this is my favorite.

I stayed for one night with friends.The staff's service was nice.They flexibly respond and to our request pleasantly. The room was clean and comfortable. The hotel prepared connected room for us, 4 person.They covered the little bump between the rooms with a white luxury mat. I was impressed by all staff's professional and attentiveness.The guest can choose break first style from several choice.We chose the one our porter recommended and it was nice with many kind of dishes. If I say one thing, access from public traffic.We took taxi. It is a bit far from the station near around. (In the season of cherry blossom, we will walk from Yotsuya station.)If any chance to have a special stay again, I will visit this hotel again.I will recommend the hotel to oversea friends!
nice stay at a highrise and the room is perfect and the massage was perect its the best excellent

This is a hotel in the style of enormous Las Vegas ones. It's vast. The Garden Tower is fine but there is a definite change in feel when walking through from the Main. Although the hotel flows from Main to Garden there is a distinct difference. The garden tower needs some refurbishment, however, it is clean, comfortable and value for money. Breakfast is very expensive if you pay full price. join the Otani Club at check in to get a discount on all spending within the hotel.

Huge, impersonal hotel.The room was ok, price not bad, but no real gym, no sauna (unless you enter the beauty spa and pay 3500 yen), poor and quite shabby breakfast.Top floor bar closes at 11, restaurants at 21.30..., what a sad place.Only beauty is the garden with Koi

In searching for a hotel with benefits, I came across this wonderful space on earth and spent a fabulous week there. I knew that there were gardens on the grounds, but nothing suggested that I would be treated to such an experience. The hotel management gave me a breathtaking view of the gardens from my suite. First thing I saw was the waterfall, surrounded by the well manicured shrubs, trees and well appointed walking paths then across the red bridge, various lakes, multiple terrain and historical pieces of stone appointments. One very elegant sculpture was purportedly executed by the Founder of Benihana Restaurants and strategically placed. I proceeded to photograph the entire experience because I wanted to develop a garden of my own. Lo and behold, it started to rain and just when I thought everything was spoiled, I bought a book from the hotel bookshop and found out that the best time to view the gardens was when it was wet, a traditional way the Japanese celebrate their gardens before visitors arrive. I love it and the whole world will most likely agree with me.

Very accommodating, clean and centrally located hotel for business travel. Service is exceptional. Rooms are comfortable and appointed. Many choices in restaurants that appeal to both eastern and western palettes. My hotel of choice when traveling in Tokyo. Recommend.

We stayed here for 2 nights during an exchange program with the Japanese govt. It was totally a great hotel. Very near Akasaka district where there are lots of restos and places to eat. There's a subway very near.Rooms:The rooms are big and you never feel crammed inside. The windows are huge which creates a good atmosphere. The bathroom also is big enough. Breakfast:The breakfast was ok though we preferred there would be more meat products. It was satisfactory.Really enjoyed my stay. It has a very nice garden!

Sheldon S
Davao City, Davao City, Philippines

review_body: Rooms were spacious, gardens wonderful and location convenient. Limited selection on hotel restaurants if arriving late. Beds were comfortable. First good night sleep in 7 days. Attached gardens were wonderful- tranquil and relaxing.

This was my first visit to Tokyo and this hotel was just right. The room was spacious and elegant. The hotel is huge with two towers but is very nice designed so as not to be overwhelmed. The garden and waterfall were beautiful. We enjoyed having lunch or an afternoon snack looking out to the garden. The rooftop restaurant was perfect to have breakfast with the all round city view and seeing Mt. Fuji on a clear day. The service was always very professional and polite. It was a great stay. It was very nice having the metro just a few steps away from the hotel saving us money on taxis.
