De N
New York City, New York

review_body: I have been here at least ten times in the last two years for work. It's an OK place to stay in Akasaka. It's fairly priced, and in addition to the facilities of a normal business hotel, it has a unique zen garden.On the negative side, the rooms are pretty old and tired, with wooden furniture from the 90s; they need to be renewed. The gym has some equipment that belongs into a museum. They are little by little improving; finally, from the middle of 2013 they offer wifi in all rooms (incredible, but they did not before!)On the positive side, if you get a high floor facing in the right direction, you can get some amazing views of the city and even of Mt. Fuji.

After booking this hotel, a lot of Japanese people told me that it's a very nice hotel.However, I am disappointed with Hotel New Otani.It's a very big hotel, we stayed at the garden towel. It's similar to the scale of any Vegas hotels but 30 years older. The room is still using key not key card which mean no energy saving power control. It took us a while to find the power points which are behind a chair. The lights switches are next to the door therefore no control when you are in bed.The location is not the best as around 10 minutes walking to the closet subway station.I was surprised to see there are lines to check in and check out at all times. It took me lined up for 30 minutes to check out. I can tell it's a very usual thing as they giving out sweets to manage the queues.The room is very spacious which is a plus.

I've stayed here a few times in the past while on business. This trip was longer, a total of 7 days for both business and a few days of vacation. While I researched other hotels in Tokyo, my good past stays, a reasonable rate by Tokyo standards and IMO a great location in Akasaka led me back here again.This trip included my two young adult sons, and conveniently the Garden Tower has at least a few "deluxe" triple rooms. There are three single beds in the bedroom, plus a sitting area with sofa, desk and a couple of chairs. Plenty of room for a stay like this, and well laid out for three. Good elbow room and storage space without having to pay for a full suite or two separate rooms. A nice bathroom. Not large, but efficiently designed and fairly new or at least looking so. In contrast, the furniture was showing some age and soon should be recovered, replaced, etc. Not a complaint though, as everything was clean and functional. As in the past, the whole staff was professional and friendly. You can't beat the location and attractive and extensive facilities. Be advised that the bars, restaurants and most shops in the hotel are quite expensive. We used sparingly, and took advantage of the Food Mart and other convenience stores on-site (it takes a bit of searching to find them though.) Also had fun venturing out and taking advantage of the many good restaurants and night life within walking distance.

Very nice hotel, with excellent service, clean room, a lot of facilities (spa, restaurants etc.) and on a good/central location in Tokyo. I can recommend this hotel to everybody for business and for holiday/Leisure.

This hotel has a long history. The rooms are reasonable, if dated. The main attraction is the garden, which was the one used in a James Bond movie. The staff is very polite in a robotic way and get things done quickly when asked. The location is convenient for business or sightseeing. You can definitely find less expensive, more modern hotels in Tokyo but this one is quite dependable.

It was our first stay in Tokyo. we liked this hotel very much, grand, beatiful, many options to have breakfast or dinner, different kitchen, different solutions, wonderful revolving restaurant, very tasty food, calm atmosphere. But old Japanese garden (400 years old) in inner yard was the best one. You are in the centre of Tokyo, but the impression is that you are at a lonely picturesque nature. Only if you come for shopping, shopping area is not so close.

Stayed here for the best part of a week in late September, early October. The room was clean, spacious but missing an iron and ironing board but who comes on a business trip to do ironing....I do, at least to look smart. The hotel is large and has several restaurants. Breakfast had a large choice of Japanese and American with a play on European; all nice so try to be a bit adventurous. I was on the 34th floor of about 40 which did provide some great views both during the day and at night. As for evening meals, I eat out in a few of the many restaurants around Akasakamitsuke Metro Station. Choose one with pictures of the food...unless you are feeling very adventurous!Overall, a good hotel, nothing (other than the want of an iron) worth mentioning.

Everything about this hotel was as best as one would expect from a top class hotel. And there's much more than one would expect as well. For instance, the sprawling Japanese Garden in the heart of Tokyo, the revolving Sky restaurant giving a 360 degree bird's eye view of the city and the very well managed and very well appointed board rooms for business meetings...I was on business but it would be great for family including kids as well.

The hotel is a traditional type hotel with lots of bell boys (and ladies) and other help always looking to help make your stay pleasant and enjoyable. There is a beautiful Japanese garden behind the hotel that is a must if this is your first stay. Lovely ponds and classic Japanese style. The breakfast buffet has something for every taste. Be sure to get a late night drink at the top of the Garden Towers bar. You will have a wonderful view of Tokyo.

Nice hotel, clean excellent staff. You are not far from the Imperial Palace and it's possible to walk all the way around it (although its a long walk.) The traditional Japanese garden in the hotel was lovely. The Hotel complex has everything you need there's even a Family Mart shop and loads of restaurants. Apparently this hotel features on the Bond film " You Only Live Twice." Only grumble was that the decor was a little dated and the Restaurants inside the hotel are quite expensive compared to those outside of the hotel complex.

Was billeted in a 38th floor standard room of the Garden Tower with a great view of Shinjuku in the distance, the Imperial Palace (and Gardens) and the hotel's new wing. (The hotel is so large that there's a separate page for reviews of the hotel's "new" "Zen" wing.)My room was meticulously maintained (everything worked) and quite clean. However, the decor was outdated. How outdated? Well, the knobs and switches on the bedside control stand are definite throwbacks to an earlier era. I likewise dislike the green upholstery on the room chairs. Plus the bed's mattress was firm and took some getting used to. I had an LCD TV (from the early 2000s it looked like) with an adequate (but not great) selection of English language channels, including CNN and BBC. All the usual suspects (except for complimentary bottled water) were present (i.e. safe, closet and hangers, mini-bar, luggage rack, etc.) as well. Finally, at 27 sqm. or so, the room was of a sufficient size for one person.The bath was okay. Sure, not as nicely laid-out, designed or large as some hotel bath's I've had the pleasure to use but still okay. Shower and tub combination rather than a stand-alone shower in the bath. In addition, the bath had a low ceiling and I'm only of average height. However, it did have a hand-held shower with different spray settings and I did like the Japanese "scene" done in tile on the wall of the bath. Toiletries were more or less complete. However, you get body wash rather than bath soap and I think they were a "house" brand rather than a well known Japanese, European or American one. I should mention breakfast. You can take it at 4 different restaurants. There's a Japanese restaurant serving a traditional Japanese breakfast, two restaurants offering full western buffets (the first in the 40th floor Italian restaurant of the Garden Wing and the second in the all-day dining restaurant located on the ground floor of the new wing) and one restaurant offering a continental buffet located along the passage between the new and garden wings. As expected, the 40th floor restaurant was busier, since it offers great views of the city. However, the restaurant in the new wing offered much, much better variety and, dare I say it, much better quality as well. I tried the Japanese breakfast during my first day and I can say that it's definitely worth having at least once. I did not try the continental buffet.Service wise, I didn't really have any cause to complain. The bellman even insisted on giving us a tour or briefing of our rooms, pointing out all the controls and what not. The staff spoke English with different levels of proficiency, with the aforementioned bellman sounding almost like a native speaker. I also very much like that Japan doesn't have a tipping culture. Finally, the grounds and facilities are expansive and the hotel's Japanese Garden is definitely worth a visit.

The hotel was originally built to house guests for the Tokyo Olympics, so it is a ginormous, overbuilt complex with restaurants, office buildings, shops and the like, which was the preferred style of tourism in Japan 40 yrs ago.  The Garden Tower is an annex and the prices should be much lower than that of the Main building, and you would not get that sort of price in this area. That being said, the Japanese garden is beautiful, bringing back the beauty of what once was, as the site belonged to the three Tokugawa families during the Edo period and then to become home to the Fushiminomiya family ( branch of royal family). Yes, eating in the hotel is very pricey for what it is; go out to Akasaka where you will have plenty of options in both types of cuisine and price range. But, having afternoon tea in the lounge enjoying the view of the beautiful garden is very nice.

This is one of the best hotels for the price in Tokyo. It was a set of convoluted circumstances that led us to choose this place as I usually do not opt to stay in Akasaka. However, I was glad we selected this hotel as it turned out to be a fabulous stay. The location was reasonably convenient in the sense that it was about 8 - 10 minutes walk from the Yotsuya Train and Metro Station. The hotel with its two towers was quite large and it was quite a walk just to get from the front door back to the Garden Tower. There were at least three restaurants and several shops in the lower lobby level. There were also several other restaurants on site such that one would never have to leave the hotel for variety if they did not want to do so. The check-in went very smoothly and efficiently. I was quite happy with my room as it was very spacious, even by Western standards, and also very clean. The amenities worked well. The internet was plug-in but functioned quite sufficiently for my needs. The morning breakfast was quite good in the Garden Room with a full buffet on weekends and a continental buffet (salad, bread, fruit, yogurt, juices, etc.) on weekdays. The rate for the hotel was very reasonable for what I paid and a better value than any other hotel at which I have stayed in Tokyo in a similar price range. I would highly recommend staying here if it works into your plans.

It's one of the most traditional, classic hotel in Tokyo. It's located 5 minutes from metro station, Akasaka downtown where you can find many restaurants and bars, but few places for shopping. The room was comfortable, and the night view was amazing. But the Internet connection was not good. When I had breakfast in the garden tower at 8:00, I should wait for 15 minutes in a cue. It was so crowded. I think the is too small compare to other international hotel. But the food was really good and could enjoy traditional Japanese breakfast. Room amenities ( Shiseido ) and free bottle of water were plus.

I travel alot for business, but this must be one of the best hotels sofar ever visited,.. If you have the money,.. As it is pretty expensive,.. 10 restaurants,tons of shops.,bars.. No need to leave the hotel,... Even a pool

This is a very big place and one often finds service impersonal in such places. However, we cannot praise the staff highly enough. On arrival we asked to change rooms. No problem. Room with better view room provided seamlessly. Cases moved to new room. We left some clothing in the room when we went to an airport hotel before our flight and they sent in on to us via the limousine for us to collect at the airport. No charge. We travel a lot and have only once received service close to this and that was at the Savoy. Friendly,helpful efficient,organised. All this for a great price compared to other Tokyo hotels. A win-win situation.

This was a superb hotel quite easy to find two stops on the Maranouchi Line up to section d in the walk way and over the bridge outside and the hotel is there. It is such a large hotel and the decor is very modern inside many shops and about 15 restaurants catering for all tastes little bit on the expensive side though. Very clean and various sizes of room, we were in a twin room in the Garden tower which was a fair size but had a breath taking view of the Garden and of Shinjuku on the horizon. The garden is 400 years old and was superb lovely red bridges and a waterfall of its own. There are a couple of restaurants in the grounds and a christian chapel that was lovely . Very warm and pleasant staff most speak perfect English good concierge service overall an excellent hotel

We stayed here in order to attend a wedding. The hotel was very large and fairly grand. There are lots of expensive boutiques in the lobby and many restaurants. Our room was well appointed and very clean. The hotel was well situated and it was easy to get to nearby train stations and from which to explore Tokyo. The staff were very friendly and knowledgeable, giving very useful tips and information about our wish to climb Fuji overnight ( which was in itself an incredible experience but its certainly true that if you have climbed it once - twice would be madness!!). The wedding at the hotel was a truly memorable experience and it was not until we attended at the wedding did we realise just how big the hotel actually is. All in all we had a great time at the hotel. The only downside is that it is incredibly expensive to eat and drink at the hotel - in our view prohibitively so. The pool was also expensive to use ( although it seems that if you join the Otani business club you might be able to use the pool at a reduced rate according to other guests) and very crowded as it is open to the public - not quite what we had expected really. All in all a lovely hotel in scenic grounds - whilst it is somewhat impersonal because of its size - it is a great place to stay and proved to be a good place to stay to begin our trip around Japan.

The hotel staff are friendly and extremely helpful, with widely varying English skills including one native speaker. I found it kind of odd that the bell staff were all female.You'll get a pretty big room, with nice views from the corners such as the #xx10 tier. However it will smell of smoke and be kind of musty. The bathroom will be clean but kind of outdated.Stores and eateries in this giant hotel are numerous. But with Akasaka right nearby, I highly recommend going out to one of Akasaka's hundreds (thousands?) of restaurants within an easy walk from the Garden Tower.Ethernet connections in the rooms are free, so bring a router to get wifi (I just set my MacBook to share the connection to a local wifi). Generally speaking in Japan, free wifi is rare compared to Korea. Maybe about the same as America. Make sure you have an offline maps app.Taxi drivers all know the New Otani well, though be sure to ask for the "Gaadan Towaa" and pronounce it slowly. The Akasaka-Mitsuke subway stop nearby is convenient also. For Narita access, use the "Airport Limousine" for 3000 yen.Concierge staff is quite good, though they don't keep great maps of Akasaka available.

It is a while since I stayed last at the New Otani. And I remember now why. Maybe the Main building is better, but the Garden Tower is a zoo. The room was OK - although the ceilings are very low and the bathroom cramped. The bed was large and comfortable. But look, in 2013, you have to have wifi in the rooms. I know Japanese hotels are proud of their cabled connections. But they don't work with macs or with smart phones. The lobby is full of refugees from the rooms trying to find a signal. And if you are paying for a room, you shouldn't have to go to the lobby to connect! One lift was being repaired, and the other two elevators were slow and crowded. Breakfast on the top floor is very crowded - long lines. And not very good. Standard Japanese breakfast - lower class. Although two types of scrambled eggs for some reason - or maybe it was scrambled omelet. Hard to tell. Bad coffee. Cold milk. Staff doing their best, but simply too many people.

very big hotel with a nice garden.On top of the tower a nice view of Tokyo skyline with Imperial Palace.When the air is clear you can see Fujyyama in the background.Good service, big rooms, very near to the metro station of Asakasa Mitsuke.Suggested

We stayed in the main tower for three nights with our three year old and one year old daughters.The room and bed were large by Japanese standards and exactly what you'd expect from a 5 star hotel. The bathroom was immaculate (of course, its Japan) but a bit 80's. The staff were great, check in friendly and efficient, handy information desks to the right of reception and concierge to the left. Highlights: the Japanese Gardens make for a lovely walk and (it appears) atmospheric if pricey evening meals. Our kids loved the waterfall, the fish and the little paths. The location is great, loads of dining options just moments away from the Garden Tower entrance including the awesome Ninja Restaurant (under Tokyu Plaza, next to Stockholm Restaurant) behind a single door it's a great, fun place to eat and, as you walk towards Asaksa station you'll see a noodle place on the right (almost opposite the metro entrance) with "24 Hour" written on it. Go here for cheap, amazing udon, tempura, ramen etc. They have an englsh point and choose menu plus some of the staff speak English. Transport via the underground was great, just a few stops to Shibuya, Ginza, harajuku etc. Message me for info on walks to take in plenty of the sights. Brilliantly, the Garden tower has a cool store with all sorts of food, wine and beer options. Great for picking up snacks. Finally, EVERY Japanese Taxi driver and local in the area knows the New Otani so directions are never an issue.

mark c
West Yorkshire, United Kingdom

review_body: 3 day stay at new otani- a large hotel but staff very attentive. Rooms are very large by japan standards and had a great view of the city. This hotel has every immaginable retail and restaurant choice, including those from the connected office building. An easy walk to night life and 100's of restaurants and a metro stop nearby. The gardens are spectacular.

My wife and I stayed in a room on the 31st floor of the New Otani Garden Tower in April 2013 for the final four days of a two week travelling trip around Japan.The room was large - very large, in fact, by Japanese standards based on our previous stays during the trip. It was clean. The bed was comfortable (apart from a very unusual bedding setup, a duvet folded into a very oversized bedsheet). There were two pillows provided (a rarity from our other experiences), one firm and one soft. The bathroom had a bath with stand-up shower. Overall, very happy with the room, except one thing...We had a no smoking room. However, it was not a no smoking floor, which seems a ludicrous decision by the hotel to do this. The room still smelled of smoke as, surprise surprise, the smell seeped through the door frame and whenever the door was opening (e.g. during housekeeping / room cleaning). While more faint than had we been in a smoking room, it was still unpleasant to have that smell lingering in the room.On check-in, the front desk had the wrong dates for our stay, having us down for three nights rather than four. They were quick to rectify the situation by checking with their booking agent (we had booked and paid via our Avios airmiles so hadn't booked directly). A minor inconvenience but nothing too bad.The location is good in that it's very close to a metro station (Akasaka Mitsuke). There are lots of restaurants and bars nearby, ranging from the cheap (250 yen noodles) to expensive, so there really is no shortage of options for dinner or drinks. However, if you're in Tokyo sightseeing you will need to travel - there is very little of cultural interest within a short walking distance, e.g. no large temples or shrines, no large gardens or parks. However, this is not a problem as the metro is very convenient and runs well. The only time the location would be a problem is if you were wanting to be out late (after the metro stops) each night, this could get expensive in taxi fares depending on where you will spend your nights/mornings.The gardens attached to the hotel are pretty and worth a little walk around, but you won't need more than 30-minutes here - they're not large.A big failure is that there is no free wifi, anywhere in the hotel. In your room there is wifi available, but for a mildly extortionate fee. In this day and age this is inexcusable. I expect wifi to be provided, and for free, in all but the most basic and cheap accomodation. For example, we stayed in two "Monterey" hotel chain venues (Tokyo Akasaka and Kyoto) and both had free wifi throughout the entire hotel.Overall, I'd rate the hotel 3 out of 5 for a few reasons.-While the room was large, clean and comfortable, the smell of smoke in a supposedly no smoking room was unpleasant.-For what you get, the price is (I believe) too high. You get absolutely nothing but the room. No bottled water, no biscuits with your tea, no wifi, nothing. As such, it feels like it's geared towards business visitors rather than holidaymakers.-While there are lots of bars and restaurants attached to the hotel, they are all vastly overpriced. Again, this makes the place feel geared towards business travellers. Not a big problem as there are lots of restaurants and bars near the hotel.-A mistake on check-in, telling us we had booked (and paid for) one night less than we had, is not something I expect from an expensive or well run hotel, even though it was resolved quickly.

This is an imposing hotel. Enormous. You must walk and walk and walk to get to any place in it. But it is nice and well situated, very close to a strategic Metro station. Staff is friendly, a little too much reverences and salutes, only, they seem automatic. They are efficient and kind. Unfortunately, they speak very little English, and nothing of other Occidental languages. But that is normal in Japan. Rooms are comfortable, nice, clean, and very well supplied. But be careful: we received a smoking room, and could not change it, and it was really smelly. And other fellow travelers had it even worst. By the way, windows are fixed, and permanently misted. Breakfast at the restaurant at the top of the building might be an odyssey. We stood once 30' on line to get a table. Other people waited still more. Once you are there, view is magnificent, and the breakfast itself is one of the best I ever had. The elevators in the Garden Tower are another nightmare: they normally run crowded, and often people gets in "Metro stile", occupying every inch. Terrible. Internet in the rooms is expensive. They offer free WiFi at the lobby (lot of people using it there), but as I said, it's miles away... The best thing of the Hotel is the Japanese Garden. One of the nicest in Tokio, believe me. A place to walk, to read, to meditate. Wonderful.

Garden Tower where we are staying is only one part of the larger complex. There is the main hotel as well as garden court complex. There are lots of great hotels near by but we are enjoying our stay here as it is close to Akasaka Mitsuke Subway station and this area is one of the major restaurants and play town of Tokyo. From this subway station you can go anywhere in Tokyo very easily. In you room you have to pay around $15 a day to access wifi but at the main hotel lounge, it is free. Here at the hotel, there are many restaurants to choose from and from the 40th floor bar of Garden Tower, you can observe Tokyo Tower illuminated for the night. Price of drinks not cheap though. Here at this hotel there seem to be more locals rather than from overseas. This hotel was built by an ex-sumo wrestler whose name is the hotel namesake. The hotel was also used not as a hotel but as a corporation for one of Bond's film. Believe 007 was Sean Connery.

I stayed at the New Otani many years ago and at the time found it to be a HUGE hotel that was sorely in need of renovation. I'm happy to report that I stayed there in March 13 and to my pleasant surprise I found that the hotel has had a massive face lift (much needed). It is still HUGE (of course) but now I can honestly say it looks like a modern, nice place to stay. The rooms (or at least the ones I have stayed in) are SMALL so be prepared. They are well-appointed but if you are expecting a spacious room, you probably need to book a larger room or look elsewhere. Staff are very professional and helpful.

Stayed there on business. Very nice. Rooms plenty big and have all the amenities. Bed very comfortable. Great cleanliness. Lots of restaurants to choose from. Very helpful and friendly staff. Location is superb. Would definitely go back.

I stayed here for business recently, so was put in this hotel by my host - the pluses are: very central and close to Metro/easy to get around, pretty good size room, very clean, staff friendly, check in and out easy, there was always someone who could speak English to help me, concierge helpful, easy to get to and from on the Airport Limousine from Narita, lots of food options (the heartiest breakfast was in the resto closest to the main tower's check in - tonnes of options there, whereas the Garden Restaurant overlooking the garden had a great view but breakfast options were sparse), a couple of gyms to use, lovely views of Mount Fuji from my room as well as the huge hotel garden. The negatives: this wing is a little dated compared to the newer wing, the hotel reeks of smoke - as soon as you walk in you can smell it, this tower has NO WIFI but you can go to the main lobby for wifi, you have to pay for internet access.

Hotel central location is perfect for sightseeing and easy commute as it is right next to the Asakusa-Mitsuke metro station. View from the room on the city is gorgeous at day and night, and it faces the garden. Rooms are well equipped with everything you might need or have forgotten to pack. Staff is very friendly and available 24/7, however sometimes their English seems somewhat limited so be patient and repeat the question using simple wording.Breakfast buffet at the Garden tower is delicious with lost of choices: real french croissants, eggs prepared in all kinds, meat, salmon, lots of fruits and vegetables and plenty of traditional Japanese food.Hotel offers plenty of restaurant choices from Japanese & Italian to 2 Michelin star French cuisine at Le Tour d'Argent. However, expect to pay between 25-45$ for breakfast, 50-80$ for lunch and dinners starting at 90-100$ + (250-300$ excluding wine at Tour d'Argent)Some cheaper options exist in the basement of adjacent building (Court Garden) or just walk into the street passed metro station - multitude of choices and 30-50$ for dinner.The only downside of Garden tower - you don't have Wi-Fi in the rooms only cable internet - so be prepared if you have a tablet. Internet is free in the lobby of the Main building.I stayed at the hotel for 6 nights and would definitely come back!

Trip back to Japan after many years, the hotel is serviced to the door by the limousine bus from the airport which is very convenient, efficient and relatively inexpensive. Arrived to a mass of concierge staff all very friendly and helpful, unfortunately room was not available until 2PM so had to find somewhere to wait for 3 hours, I understand that the 2PM deadline is typical and non negotiable. Eventually checked in, which as mentioned previously was faultless, given great advice to join the New Otani Club free of charge which gave discount on breakfast. Quality double room in the main building which was very nice, spacious, clean and well serviced and free wifi (good in room, sadly lacking elsewhere in building). There are a number of bars and restaurants within the hotel complex although the position of the hotel gives you a huge choice within a 5 minutes walk outside. Breakfast in the hotel was extra and quite expensive but a good variety of choice. During my stay the service from the staff was exceptional and I would not hesitate to return.

Stayed in the Garden Tower which was very handy for the bars and restaurants just across the river bridge. Check in / Check out was very slick despite being very busy.Rooms are a bit tired but very clean. The only complaint was that we could not get any cash on our credit cards from reception which is not good for such an International HotelA bit expensive but suppose you pay for what you get

Everything was good. Fanstastic view. I was staying in garden tower for a weeks plus. Food is good too. Perhaps the wireless connection at certain areas can be improved. Close distance to train station. Pool usage comes with charges.

I stayed for six nights in October. Stayed in the Garden Tower, on the 36th floor.Quick check in and check out. Concierge service very useful. I had all I needed. Shame they don't have iron in their rooms.The room was clean and the view was reslly cool :-)Do not use the shampoo provided: must be some very strong detergent, gave me very itchy scalp... :-/I would recommend it. Not cheap, but good.

I stayed in the Garden Tower wing. The rooms could do with refurbishment but are adequate. The hotel is linked to the Tower wing by a long corridor. Check in & out were smooth. The garden is well designed & very relaxing. Lots of Koi in the ponds. The Teppanyaki in the garden is superb. A meal in the revolvin restautant gives a great view of the city.

We stayed in the Garden Tower section, the view of downtown Tokyo was breathtaking from our 35th floor room, on a clear day we could see Mt. Fuji. The room was clean and adequate, There was a safe for our use, hot tea, and a minibar. The hotel has its own art museum, free to guests. Prices in the restaurants and shops can be shocking, but local restaurants are a five minute walk away. We had included the breakfast buffet, the hot and cold selections in the 40th floor room were extensive and came with a great view. The hotel is not new, but well maintained and a first rate helpful staff. For instance, we had directions to a restaurant translated into Japanese to hand to the cab driver. No wifi in the room, only downstairs lobby, wired internet in the room if you can use it. We had a good stay. The 400 year old imperial garden with koi and water fall is a real plus!

There are two of these hotels combined into one. If you stay in the New New Otani you will be happy, maybe. If you stay in the old New Otani not so much. The old one, where I ended up is called the same name but I ended up in the Garden Tower. It has older rooms, kind of OK but a little bit in need of renovation and a bit not so nice feeling.The bathrooms are quite old, and the beds a bit on the saggy side. The help is way below what you expect in a nice Japanese business hotel. First, beware, some of the rooms do not have wifi, at least not when I was here. The first room had none, so after I unpacked I headed down to the front desk, and only then did they inform me I would have to repack and have another room on another floor. No sorry. Later, when I asked for a map and location it was all the bell desk could do but to mumble a few words and clearly wanted no further talking with me.The restaurant at the top of the Main Building, the New New Otani, that turns, has a deal of around $100 USD for not very good food at all. Stay away from this place for dinner! The breakfast on the other hand in the new building has a great buffet that comes with the room. Coffee for two in the coffee shop betwen the two buildings was $15 per person for a cup of coffee. Quite ridiculous. We wanted to just share a spread sheet and it cost $30.In short, you can do so much better and the location is kind of off the beaten path in Akasaka although it is right across from the Metro stop Akasaka Mitsuke.

The Hotel New Otani is one of the established grand hotels in Tokyo. It has two wings, the more salubrious Main Building and the newer Garden Tower and these are interconnected by an arcade containing shops and restaurants. Lobby decor is a bit 'arte nouveau' influenced. We stayed in the Garden Tower on the 22nd floor, the room was comfortable and had a great view across to the Tokyo Tower that is lit up colourfully at night. The hotel service was impeccable. As indicated by many reviewers the real unique feature of this hotel is its Japanese Garden complete with a large waterfull and walking around this is a real treat, particularly in central Tokyo. Along the arcade is a bar and tea house and you can sit in the afternoon and admire the Garden from above with a drink in hand. The major frustration of the hotel is the cost of all the add-ons. There is no WiFi in the room but internet is available via cable for ~1500 yen for 24h and this then gives you access to WiFi in the lobby and arcade. The outdoor swimming pool, adjacent to the Garden, is very nice but costs 2000 yen for guests and was quite busy on the hot summer day we visited. Breakfast is expensive and I would recommend that your purchase fruit and pastries at the Sakogami food shop on level 1 in the shopping centre below the Garden Tower if you want a cheaper option. The hotel is very well situated next to subway stations and if you walk down the hill, over the bridge and across the road there is a street of restaurants to chose from, where we found magnificent made to order Sushi. The central location of the hotel means that many of Tokyo's important sites, e.g. Imperial Palace, are close by. All in all we really enjoyed our stay here, sure it is a bit old and not a big new glamour hotel but the New Otani has some features, like its garden, that cannot be matched elsewhere.

Stayed for business in one of the Garden Tower rooms and was a little disappointed. The hotel itself is quite amazing - huge with shops, a gallery and lovely Japanese Gardens however our room was a bit dated and dark and dingy.

review_body: Big, expensive, clean hotel in the middle of central Tokyo. We stayed in the Garden Tower and are really satisfied. Chosed the hotel because of a special price 40% discount if you stay 4 nights and we don´t regret. Very close to the subway and a nice street with several restaurants. The room was very big and with three windows. Clean and quiet, but stiff beds. The staff was helpful and polite. Joined the new otani-club for cheaper breakfast, but it was not that great. Used the gym late at night when it was empty, and it was ok, had a few workout-machines and weights. Didn´t have any time to see the beutiful garden and to visit the pool, to bad.. The lap of wifi made us buy an wireless wifi connector in the electric street for about 95 Y and it workt fine. Overall are we very satisfied.

The Garden is beautiful and the lobby is large and full of amenities. I stayed in the Garden Tower in a standard king room. The room was a very nice size. My only complaint is the windows look like port holes in a ship. Overall, the bed was decent and furniture was nice. I found the staff very attentive and all spoke good English which made the stay easy. It was also in a very good location. Less than a 5 minute walk to Akasaka for bars and restaurants.

review_body: Stayed many times in the Garden Tower. Larger non smoking rooms are fine,View to Shinjuku is nice.Restaurants expensive, but plenty of local alternatives.Fitness cente is dismal, but full gym is expensive.Very busy with local families and groups on weekend. Week days ae dominated by foreign guestsNo wifi in rooms, only wired, however wifi is available in lobby and internet seems to be free since march '12

Beautiful Hotel. The gardens are amazing. I stayed in the garden tower, room was average great view fridge and well stocked bar. location was great and the shops and restaurants inside the hotel were good but pricey. Overall a great stay

My second stay here on a business trip and it remains a reasonable hotel which ticks every box, but at the same time, doesn't really stand out in any area. The rooms are clean and tidy with comfortable beds, but the furniture is very basic. The bars are nice, especially the one on the 40th floor in the garden tower with lovely views over the city. Service is, as you would expect, outstanding. I only ate breakfast in the hotel and it was over-priced and not particularly good. Overall, a reasonable hotel, but I have stayed in better.

I stayed here in the Garden Tower for a couple of weeks on a business trip. There is nothing "New" about the New Otani. At first I felt for the money the hotel was very dated. But after a couple of days it kinda grew on me. It was clean and the service was very good. That said, everything is expensive at the hotel. You pay extra for use of the pool which is kinda crazy. But that's in the middle of Tokyo business district, so I will not complain about anything cost related. If you want cheap, go somewhere else. I found in the end it met all my needs. The most disappointing part was that the pool closed for the season on September 4 when the weather was still very hot. There is also no wireless internet.

With 1500 rooms this is a ridiculously huge hotel. But it offers great value. We stayed in the cheapest room type, a standard room in the Garden Tower, but there was nothing wrong with it. It was big enough, certainly for Tokyo, with a great view, quiet, ok beds, good shower. It is a bit old, but everything is in working condition. Even the beds were big enough, and we are quite tall (6'1 and 6'4 / 185 and 192 cm).The service in the hotel is impeccable. Everybody speaks at least some English, even the cleaning staff greets guests in English. Service of the bell boys is also great; they escort you to your room with your luggage which I like much better than the usual procedure in US hotels where you sometimes have to wait for 15 minutes or more in your room before your luggage gets there.Special mention for Ms Takahata of Guest Relations / what one would call a concierge in the US. Our purpose for visiting Tokyo was to eat some of its great Japanese restaurants, but unfortunately it is very hard to get reservations if you do not speak Japanese. Ms Takahata made all the reservations for me, including ones that could only be made a month in advance and thus she scheduled to contact the restaurant on my behalf on exactly the right date without any reminder from me. She also provided a letter with reservation details upon arrival at the hotel and excellent directions on how to get there.There is no Wifi in the hotel, put the wired internet for 1260 Yen per day worked very well and considering the low rate that's not bad. I really enjoyed the Japanese breakfast, but a Western breakfast is also available.The location in Akasaka is also fine, close to the subway and in walking distance from areas like Roppongi and the imperial gardens.Next time we're in Tokyo, we'll definitely stay here again!

I stayed here for 2 nights when here for work. I rolled in on the airport limo bus from Haneda (I don't recommend that if you are a) coming to the international terminal b) are familiar with using trains in tokyo and c)traveling light given all the different airport terminal stops) and it pulled up at 11pm to a large, empty hall with an escalator leading up to check in. I had booked a cheaper room in the Garden Tower, and so after the fairly rapid check-in was escorted by a very personable porter to my room down a long hallway to the Garden Tower. The room itself was clean, functional, of average size and to be honest fairly unremarkable, except for the pretty blue bathroom tile murals which was a nice touch. The bed was very comfortable, the yukatas and slippers were great, and I slept like a baby both nights. I also always like the complimentary salty plum tea which was one of many options. I am sure the Main Building rooms are much more luxurious as previous reviewers have commented.There is a typical paid-for gym in the hotel, with spa and sauna facilities. Used to travelling in Asia outside Japan though I couldn't bring myself to pay for that and used the small gym in the Garden Tower. Very basic, with a few cardio machines and some free weights, but it did the job.What impressed me about the hotel were the sheer number, scale and variety of restaurants in the hotel, including three separate bakeries. The patisserie in the front of the hotel is highly rated by guests and locals alike, but I actually quite like the pastries at Aux Bacchanales at the street level just outside the Garden Tower ground floor entrance (their steak frites was quite tasty too!). I ate at the Lounge area between the Garden Tower and the Main Building for breakfast, which was a limited continental breakfast one day. That was perfectly alright (I can never have enough Japanese yoghurt, living in Hong Kong) but a fairly limited selection with no real hot foods. I would have loved to have tried some of the fancier places but being by myself I was going to save it for a return trip.The location of the hotel is pretty good, not too far away from a number of different subway lines, and very much within striking distance of both the business districts and the shops of Shibuya, Aoyama, and Omotesando. Quite a pleasant experience overall, but the rooms in the Garden Tower really ought to be a little more impressive.

Our room overlooked the 400 year old garden with waterfalls, bridges, and trees. Unfortunately they have not upgraded the rooms in the Garden Tower yet. However, once we decided to overlook that, the rest of the experience was great. There is a subway entrance just across the bridge that gives access to the entire city. This is a convention hotel, so there was a lot of such activities. Many shops and restaurants, though we didn't partake in that. Many other restaurant choices nearby. There are two restaurants in the ancient garden. Had we discovered them earlier, we probably would have tried one - if even just for the location and atmosphere. Join their free New Otani club in advance. That got us a room upgrade and free daily newspapers.

We stayed at the Hotel New Otani for two nights as part of an 8-day tour of Japan. It was easy to reach by subway, had a wonderful breakfast buffet, clean rooms, and a rotating restaurant/lounge on the top floor with amazing views. Our room had an unbelievable view of the Tokyo skyline (we were in the garden tower). The garden and grounds surrounding the hotel are amazing, we enjoyed the floor to ceiling windows in the main ground floor restaurant during breakfast. Nice, accommodating staff.

The New Otani in Tokyo was the best hotel we stayed at during our Japan trip.Expensive, but worth the price. We reserved a triple room (2 adults + one 9yo girl) in the garden tower. We got a room with a spacious sitting area separated from the beds area, with an armchair, a sofa, a big flat television set and tea facilities. There was one additional sink outside of the bathroom, which was very helpful, being three people. 2 wardrobes, to easily unpack our luggages. Very helpful staff, wonderful garden, free outdoor swimming pool (get the New Otani membership card). Good location, close to several subway lines. The only negative point: no free internet. We found it amazing, in such a high level hotel. I would definitely stay there again

If you want to stay in an old Las Vegas-style hotel this is the place to be. Huge and impersonal, it is well below average in comparison with other hotels of the same price in Tokyo. We stayed in the Garden Tower which unlike the main building has not been renovated and it is a little bit cheaper. We never expected that a non-renovated building would be synonymous with poor conditions such as a very,very, old bed and a barely working air-conditioning system.The highlight of the hotel is the Japanese garden but you never get the feeling of being in a true Japnese hotel as the service is below average and you always get the impression that the administration just wants to make more money out of you. We asked for an early check-in (9:30 AM) and were told that an extra charge would be made. When we got our final bill we were shocked to see that the extra charge amounted to a 100% charge so we ended paying twice the daily rate for just checking at 9:30 AM (a year before we checked-in early at the Prince Park Tower and the extra charge was 50%). Don't stay here¡¡

This huge hotel complex in central Tokyo saturated all of our expectations. We lived in the Garden Tower, with a magnificent view over the city. Every morning we ate our breakfast with a fantastic view of the Japanese garden.The pleasant and knowledgeable hotel staff did everything to make us feel at home.Recommended highly.

This hotel would have to be my least favourite in terms of customer service. For a hotel of this magnitude I was expecting a bit more. Being our first trip to Japan and Tokyo itself, we didn't exactly get the friendliest of welcome from their staff, not something you need in the morning after a very long flight. Apart from the level of customer service not being up to scratch, their english was also not so great. Especially when I asked not one, but a few of their staff a really basic question and when they couldn't give me a straight answer I was really quite shocked. In the end, I managed to figure out the answer to my own question, without their help.We stayed in the Garden Tower for four nights. The twin room here was quite spacious and modern. We had a nice view of the the skyline at night and when the day cleared we were pleasantly surprised that our room also had a view of Mt Fuji. This was by far the most expensive hotel we stayed in on our Japan trip and the only one that did not offer either free wi-fi or internet access. Although I knew this prior to booking, it got me thinking that if the other hotels which I stayed at, where we paid much less for, were able to either provide us with free wi-fi or computers to access the internet in the lobby- why can't Otani? This is something very handy when you're trying to look for something in Tokyo and communicating with the staff is just way too frustrating.I chose to stay in this hotel because it seemed to be located in the centre of all the places we were planning to visit, plus my friend wanted to see a beautiful Japanese garden and express check-in is offered to their members. On the morning we arrived, all the rooms were fully booked, there was a wedding on that day and it was during cherry blossom season, so it was understandable that we couldn't get express check-in. (FYI: If you do plan to stay here, sign up for their free membership card, it helps, a little).In terms of location it is not so bad. To access the hotel we used the Akasaka-mitsuke station, which is a short walk from the Garden Tower. On the orange Ginza line it was the G5 stop and the on red Marunouchi line it was the M13 stop (note: these lines are the Tokyo Metro line which are not covered by the JR pass if you intend on purchasing one). The station is near other shopping and dining areas such as Roppongi Hills, Tokyo Midtown and if high-end designer label shopping is your thing, Ginza and Ometesando are not far from this station. However, if you're on a budget or you just want to be located in the heart of the action, then you are best to base yourself in either Shibuya or Shinjuku which is exactly what I'll do next time I'm there. These places are amazing at night and have a great energy to them. Plus there are plenty of restaurants, shops and entertainment to choose from in contrast to the neighbourhood around Otani which is rather quiet with a demographic of mostly business workers. Sure, the hotel has it's own restaurants, but if you haven't made any reservations then you could always go for a little explore into your neighbourhood like we did for dinner. We ate at Akasaka Square Dining, the food there was pretty average as reflected in the price. We also had a rather healthier version of the American buffet breakfast at the Garden Lounge located at Otani's Main Tower. This lounge had really nice views of the garden and we could imagine how spectacular it would have been had the cherry blossoms been in full bloom, but unfortunately at the time, they were just beginning to bud.

This was a great Hotel, incredibly large and very good staff all speaking english and very helpfull. We stayed in the Garden Tower and the rooms were reasonably spacious, internet was around 1270 yen for 24 hours, but that was OK. We felt a little out of place in the public areas as this is mainly a Business Hotel and people are dressed in Buisness clothes, we were tourists in shorts etc. The location was perfect and close to the Metro and centre of the City. There were many Restaurents nearby which was great as the only downer on this place was the Restaurent prices they were incredibly expensive and you could eat just as good for about 25/30% of the price outside the Hotel. This Hotel would have scored 5 if it had some moderate priced Dining facilities and a good Bar.

Stayed here one night 8/28. This is not our normal airline crew hotel, but due to an issue at our normal hotel, we were substituted here. The FIRST thing that you have to get your arms around is the sheer size of this hotel property.. It's huge.. The hotel consists of three major buildings plus one of the largest private hotel gardens in Tokyo. When you first arrive you really don't get a sense of just how large it is.. Check-in was a bit complex as the Otani's Credit Office had to communicate with my airline's billing office (it's a pre-paid room) to confirm payment arrangements. In typical Japanese service style, rather than being left standing at the check-in counter waiting, our bags were taken by the Bell Staff and we were shown to the adjacent lounge and offer a fruit juice drink while we waited for the details to be worked out.. This, in itself, is a small event, but is in my opinion a good representation of what level of service the Otani delivers..Within :15 were were assigned rooms and escorted with our bags by the Bell Staff. Rooms in the lower and older Main Building are priced a little cheaper than rooms in the newer, taller Garden Court/Tower buildings. Luckily we were assigned rooms in the Garden Tower building. It takes a solid :10 to get from the Front Desk to our rooms-- an indication as to the sheer size of this hotels property.The room itself is typically Asian, in that it's small. Nicely furnished with darker, cooling colors with dark natural wood trim. As you would expect, all the furnishings are top-rate like the plasma TV, work desk with multi-line phone, multi-power outlet, high-speed internet connection, data ports, coffee/tea serviette, iron and ironing board and room slippers and plush teri-cloth bath robe. The windows are nearly floor to ceiling and provide on of the best views in a city hotel I've ever seen. The drapes are not "black-out" but do shut out a substantial percentage of the natural light when closed. The room also has one leather sitting chair and coffee table. I turn the chair to face the city view.Like the bedroom, the bathroom is also noticeably small but also very well equipped. Full toiletries provided, tub and shower. Anti-fog mirror, radio and telephone for those who need to make or receive a call from the bathroom. A wall-mounted hair dryer is also included. Nice strong water pressure and very hot water.As expected everything in my room was in working order and it was cleaned to an immaculate standard.The hotel itself is like a semi-city. For the first-time guest, you may get temporarily lost. The hotel has two large pool, a full gym with classes and free weights/machinery, a day-salon and a day-spa. The hotels private Japanese waling garden is NOT to be missed. You can get a guide so you can better understand the symbolism of the gardens and the native plants as well.You won't be at a loss for eating options either: Japanese, Western, Chinese, French/Pastry, Cafe and Bar/Lounge are all available. They do also offer 24/7 room service at typical room service rates. The hotel is so centrally located in the Chiyoda-ku district that there are literally hundreds of eating and drinking options withing a short walk or subway ride from the hotel.I can't say enough about this hotel.. It's sheer size and level of amenities are unrivaled. I do know that it is not cheap by any measure, but in my opinion, for the location, the level of amenities and guest services it's a good value. But for me it's the staff politeness, promptness and overall level of guest satisfaction that make it a winner for me!

We were in the Garden Tower - there are 3 blocks. Heaps of restaurants and shops, very busy but a good place to kick off trip to Japan when you know nothing! Easy to get everywhere, close to metro. Room was slightly jaded but clean and comfortable. Staff extremely helpful and friendly. Disappointing to have to pay for internet (100 yen for 10 min) in such a hotel but seems to be everywhere in Japan. Even when it froze and I lost the money they would not give a free session, had to pay again.
